The overhead-powered rail is the first part of a $10 billion, 150-mile rail grid planned into the next century for Los Angeles, where freeways get so jammed that relatively short commutes can take an hour or more. A projected 5,000 to 7,000 riders a day are expected to board the coaches that travel at speeds reaching 55 mph. Included in that system is the $1.3 billion Metro Rail subway, which suffered a setback Friday when fire ravaged a maintenance tunnel under construction. The first 4-mile segment was scheduled to open in 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Wounded Pour Into Hospital; Heavy Fighting In Suburb
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The following is partly based on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, among them Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.
DOC.TEXT: Amid fears Monrovia will soon fall to rebels, hundreds of civilians are fleeing the city center and a steady stream of refugees are heading toward neighboring Sierra Leone. Witnesses reported heavy fighting between government and rebel forces on the capital's heavily populated eastern outskirts on Sunday, half of which were said by Western military observers to now be under rebel control. About a quarter of this West African nation's 2 million people live in Monrovia. There was no official casualty count. However, French and Belgian doctors at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic hospital said people were brought in from the eastern suburbs all day Sunday with gunshot wounds. St. Joseph's is the only hospital operating in the capital. Diplomatic and international relief sources reported a flow of refugees heading toward Sierra Leone by truck, car, bicycle or on foot. Refugees had stopped flowing across Liberia's borders until Friday because of reports the rebels had cut the roads out of the country. When it became clear Saturday that escape routes were still open, the refugee flow resumed. An air of lawlessness settled over the city as people streamed toward the countryside to seek refuge and food, and doctors from the French relief group Doctors Without Borders struggled to help the injured. A 24-year-old city resident, Alice Bahn, said she was with two young boys Saturday when government soldiers surrounded them. ``Both the boys were shot and killed,'' she said. ``I put my hands up, but they shot anyway. I was lucky to get away. ...'' Ms. Bahn was brought into St. Joseph's with a serious bullet wound in her face. Next to her were two girls, ages 10 and . They were brought in Sunday morning, two weeks after they were shot somewhere in bush country. ``We hope they will survive,'' said their surgeon, Robert Kpoto. ``They have not been treated for a long time, and the younger one is in quite critical condition.'' Temporary refugee camps have been set up all around the city and many of the fleeing civilians are seeking refuge there. Twenty-two such camps now house 40,000 refugees in Monrovia, and the total is growing daily, said a Dutch member of the international medical team, Dr. Ron Oud. Workers in the camps said government soldiers had been roaming around the camps every night, shooting wildly and threatening to break in. The workers also said soldiers have been threatening to seize Gio and Mano tribesmen at the camps. They are considered enemies of President Samuel Doe's Krahn tribe in the six-month-old insurgency that has turned into tribal warfare. Witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity, said government soldiers were becoming increasingly undisciplined, holding up vehicles to demand money and cigarettes. ``Every soldier is doing his own thing,'' one victim of such an incident reported. Monrovia remained without electricity and water main service on Sunday. The only fresh drinking water came from wells. Virtually all food stores were closed, and prices of staples were skyrocketing. A small packet of biscuits was offered by a street trader Sunday for $10. The insurgent National Patriotic Front is led by Doe's former associate, Charles Taylor. The rebels, who began their revolt in December, accuse Doe of corruption and human rights abuses. Human rights groups have accused both sides of slaughtering hundreds of civilians. Doe seized power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of American slaves who founded this country in 1847. While besieging Monrovia, the insurgents are consolidating their control of the rest of Liberia. On Saturday, they were reported to have captured the provincial capital of Voinjama, about 140 miles north of Monrovia. On Sunday, the rebels' chief negotiator left Sierra Leone after peace talks mediated by the Economic Community of West African States. Thomas Woewiyu said he was going to confer with the rebel leadership about whether ``there is some sort of political option to resolve the conflict without taking that final step and without destroying what is left of the country.'' He expected to return to Freetown, the Sierra Leone capital, on Monday and resume negotiations Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Linger in East, Southwest and Plains
DOC.TEXT: Rain lingered over the flood-ravaged Southwest today, while storms developed over the East Coast and the Plains. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms over parts of California, Texas, Nevada, Arizona, South Dakota, Nebraska and Iowa, and from New England to the Middle Atlantic Coast. On Sunday, heavy rain brought flooding to parts of West Virginia, Maryland, Ohio, Pennsylvania, New Mexico, Arizona and Texas. In south-central Texas, more than 12 inches of rain fell near Eldorado, and the rain-gorged San Saba River rose about 15 feet, flooding several dwellings and forcing campers to higher ground. A tornado touched down outside Kerrville, damaging about 20 homes and injuring one person, police said. Tornadoes also touched down near Elmwood, Okla., and close to the Texas towns of Roosevelt, Panhandle, Charlotte and Conway. Sandbags were needed to shore up the rain-swollen Rio Grande near Albuquerque, N.M. Large hail fell near Garden City, Kan., and storm winds gusted to 70 mph at Lake Powell, Utah. Unseasonably cool weather was scattered from Florida to Nebraska. The high temperature for the nation was 110 degrees at Taft, Calif. DOC.TEXT: The dollar was stronger against key currencies today. Gold prices fell. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 148.43 yen, up 1.01 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 148.20 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar's soft recovery followed Friday's cut in the U.S. key federal funds rate. Friday's U.S. producer price and retail sales data also showed stronger economic activity than expected, they said. Other dollar rates compared with late Friday: _1.6570 West German marks, up from 1.6430 _1.4100 Swiss francs, up from 1.3925 _5.5545 French francs, up from 5.5115 _1,212.90 Italian lire, up from 1,203.25 _1.1600 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1576 The British pound traded at $1.7980, down from $1.8055 late Friday. The morning quotation for the Dutch guilder was unavailable. Dealers said gold fell as broad-based short-covering, which rallied bullion Friday, has exhausted itself for the time being. Dealers added that it might take a move above $365 or more before another round of stop-loss buying. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $362.50 per troy ounce this morning, down from $364.55 late Friday. In Zurich, gold traded at $362.50, down from $364.20 late Friday. Gold closed in Hong Kong at $363.11, down 48 cents from Saturday's close. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid $4.93 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos, Acquitted in New York, Faces New Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: Former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos, acquitted of fraud two weeks ago by a federal jury here, faces new questioning by a grand jury in Pittsburgh. Mrs. Marcos said two federal agents on Friday served her with a subpoena to appear in Pittsburgh on Sept. 25. The case involves a never-used nuclear power plant Westinghouse Electric Corp. built in the Philippines in the early 1980s, when her late husband Ferdinand Marcos was president. ``They said they want me to come and bring all my documents. I don't really know what this is all about,'' Mrs. Marcos said Saturday during a party thrown to thank jurors from her New York trial. A source close to Mrs. Marcos who asked not to be identified said she will appear as ordered unless the government advises her that she is a target of the inquiry, in which case she would refuse. The subpoena was issued on behalf of the Justice Department's fraud section in Washington. It does not indicate whether Mrs. Marcos is a target of the investigation. U.S. Attorney Thomas W. Corbett Jr. of Pittsburgh declined to comment, citing the secrecy of grand jury proceedings. The subpoena dated July 11 instructed Mrs. Marcos to ``bring all documents in your possession or under your control ... relating directly or indirectly to the payment of commissions or anything of value'' by Westinghouse or Burns & Roe Inc. to the Marcoses or their agents since Jan. 1, 1973. Burns & Roe, an engineering firm, was a subcontractor on the Philippines project. Mrs. Marcos, 61, and Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi, 55, were acquitted July 2 after a 10-week federal trial. Prosecutors alleged that she helped her husband loot the Philippines' treasury of more than $220 million, using the money to buy four New York buildings, artworks and jewelry. Khashoggi was accused of falsifying documents to show that he, not the Marcoses, owned the New York properties and some paintings. Prosecutors said that was done to circumvent a March 1986 court order that froze the Marcoses' assets following their ouster from power. Marcos illegally skimmed millions from the Philippine treasury by demanding kickbacks from companies and banks doing business with his government, prosecutors said. Westinghouse was not mentioned in the case. In Pittsburgh, Westinghouse spokesman Paul B. Jones said the subpoena may stem from a lawsuit filed against the company by the government of Philippines President Corazon Aquino, which is still seeking to recover the money allegedly stolen by the Marcoses. Jones said safety concerns delayed the nuclear plant's opening and after Marcos was deposed and Aquino took office, the plant became a political issue. ``The Philippine government sued Westinghouse because the plant was sitting there. They chose not to operate it,'' Jones said. He said the suit alleges Westinghouse built a plant that could not be operated, but declined to comment further. Despite the subpoena, Mrs. Marcos' was jovial at the party Saturday in the penthouse of her posh Manhattan apartment complex. Among 100 guests were 10 of the 12 jurors who acquitted Mrs. Marcos and Khashoggi. ``It's just a gathering of friends,'' said ex-juror Luellen White, a subway worker, who left carrying a decorated cake. Others departed with bouquets of flowers. ``I invited the jurors to thank them and because I thought they should see some of the good things about the Philippines,'' said Mrs. Marcos, who entertained her guests by singing ``God Bless America'' and Philippine songs.

DOC.HEAD: Toxic Fumes Kill One, Injure 17 at Steel Plant
DOC.TEXT: Toxic fumes at a steel plant killed one worker and injured 17 others, fire officials said. Subcontractors working on a steam drum at the Great Lakes Steel plant in this Detroit suburb were overcome by fumes Sunday afternoon, said fire Sgt. Art Andring. Two men inside the 5-foot-diameter, 35-foot-long drum suffered the most intense exposure and one later died, he said. The source of the toxic fumes and the chemical that made them were unknown. Andring dubbed the lethal release ``mystery fumes,'' adding that company investigators did not release any information. The drum has an opening on one end that's so small, rescue workers couldn't get through wearing their scuba-like breathing equipment, he said. They had to pull their oxygen tanks in behind them and then strap them on, he said. The fumes also wafted through three of the six stories at the building where scraps of metal are melted down to make steel. The area was cordoned off but none of the hundreds of workers were evacuated, Andring said. Ron Harris, 47, was killed. David Bittner, 32, was listed in serious condition early today at Outer Drive Hospital. Sixteen other workers complained of symptoms ranging from chest pain to difficulty breathing and scratchy throats. They were treated at hospitals and two were held for overnight observation, Andring said. The factory, which employs about 5,000 people, is owned by National Steel Corp., of which 70 percent is owned by NKK Corp. of Japan. A plant guard, who refused to give his name, said Sunday night that no one was available to comment on the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Former Model, Ex-Cop Who Killed Husband's Onetime Spouse Escapes
DOC.TEXT: Lawrencia Bembenek, a former model and Milwaukee police officer serving a life term for the 1981 murder of her husband's ex-wife, escaped from prison through a laundry room window, officials said. Footprints indicated Ms. Bembenek fled into a wooded area east of the Taycheedah Correctional Institution, Warden Nona Switala said. She was discovered missing during a bed check Sunday night. Prison guards joined by Fond du Lac County sheriff's deputies and a sheriff's scent dog searched the wooded area without luck, Ms. Switala said. Prison officials found a section of the 7-foot fence surrounding the prison where barbed wire had been pulled down. No other inmates were missing and there was no sign Ms. Bembenek had received help from anyone, the warden said. Ms. Bembenek, 31, was last seen shortly after 8 p.m. when she went to do her laundry, Ms. Switala said. The State Court of Appeals rejected Ms. Bembenek's request for a new trial June 20. It was the third time the appeals court had denied similar requests for a new trial. She has maintained her innocence during her eight years in prison and sought the new trial on grounds her old lawyer, Donald Eisenberg, had a conflict of interest when representing her. Her lawyer for the appeal, Martin E. Kohler, said late Sunday he was surprised to hear of her escape. Kohler said he last contacted her two weeks ago and was in the process of petitioning the state Supreme Court for a review of her case. He said he would continue with the appeal despite Ms. Bembenek's escape. She was convicted of murder in the May 28, 1981 shooting of Christine Schultz in Milwaukee. Mrs. Schultz was the former wife of Elfred Schultz, a Milwaukee police detective who was married to Ms. Bembenek at the time of the slaying. Schultz has since left the police department and moved out of state. Ms. Bembenek and Schultz divorced after her conviction. Ms. Bembenek would have become eligible to apply for parole after serving 11 years and 3 months, Ms. Switala said. The prison houses about 200 women prisoners in lockups where conditions range from minimum to maximum security, she said. Authorities had not determined what prompted the escape. Guards reported no problems with Ms. Bembenek as an inmate, Ms. Switala said.

DOC.HEAD: 500 Residents Evacuated During Chemical Fire
DOC.TEXT: A chemical plant fire that burned out of control today forced the evacuation of up to 500 residents, authorities said. The blaze erupted about 9 p.m. Sunday when a car rammed into the FMC Chemical Co., police Lt. Roger Enmark said. No serious injuries were reported, but 10 firefighters were checked at a nearby hospital for possible exposure to toxic chemicals, Enmark said. Chemicals including sulfur caused a cloud to form above the company and surrounding neighborhood, prompting the evacuation, Enmark said. Area residents were taken to a nearby junior high school while firefighters worked to douse the flames. It was not immediately known what happened to the car's driver after the crash, the lieutenant said.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Parliament Declares Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: The Parliament of the Ukraine, following sovereignty decrees by other republics, declared today that its own laws to take precedence over Soviet law, the official Tass news agency reported. The Ukraine is the Soviet Union's second-largest republic, with more than 50 million people. It also is a key industrial and farming region. The republic's Parliament, meeting in the capital of Kiev, declared the ``supremacy, independence, absolute authority and indivisibility'' of Ukrainian authority on the republic's territory, Tass said. But the news agency added that the majority of deputies who spoke during the Supreme Soviet's debate did not support secession from the Soviet Union. Instead, they said, sovereignty ``should not break the existing social, economic and cultural and other ties with republics, but develop them,'' Tass said. In its declaration, the Ukraine followed the lead of the huge Russian republic, the Baltic republics, and several other Soviet republics clamoring for more independence from the central government. Some Ukrainian nationalists support total independence for their republic, but the movement is not as far advanced as it is in other Soviet republics like the Baltics. Last week, debate over sovereignty in the republic's Parliament had caused sharp disagreements and led indirectly to the resignation of the republic's president, Vladimir Ivashko. Ivashko was then chosen deputy chief of the Soviet Communist Party. Today's declaration called for the Ukraine's ``independence and equal rights in external relations,'' and stated that the republic has the right to have its own armed forces, Tass said. Now, the Ukraine's youth cannot perform military service outside the republic without parliament's permission. The declaration sets a future goal of establishing a ``constantly neutral government, which does not take part in military blocs'' and opposes the production, proliferation and use of nuclear weapons, Tass said. Ivashko and other deputies to the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet were called back last week from the Soviet Communist Party congress for the debate on sovereignty. Ivashko refused to go, and turned in his resignation. He said he interpreted his dispute with Parliament over the issue as indicating that he did not have enough authority to govern the republic. The same day he was nominated to be Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Communist Party deputy, and he was elected easily.

DOC.HEAD: 30 Injured in Ethnic Strife; Airport Chief Killed in Azerbaijan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with airport manager in Nagorno-Karabakh killed in bombing, husband, son injured. Picks up 3rd pvs, `The news...'
DOC.TEXT: An airport manager in the ethnically troubled region of Nagorno-Karabakh has been killed in a bomb explosion that destroyed her home, the Tass news agency said today. Her son and husband were reported injured. In the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia, at least 30 people were injured in renewed ethnic fighting over the weekend, the official Soviet news agency reported. Tass said the bombing in Nagorno-Karabakh occurred Sunday night. It said investigators from the Azerbaijani Interior Ministry earlier had investigated threats against the life of Yevgenia Ishkhanova, manager of Stepanakert airport. According to the Tass report, Ishkhanova's son was seriously injured in the blast and hospitalized. Her husband escaped with slight injuries, Tass said. Tass said Ishkhanova had been ``engaged in an all-out effort to increase discipline there and ensure that incoming flights from Yerevan complied with the schedule.'' Yerevan is the capital of the neighboring republic of Armenia, which has been involved in a dispute with Azerbaijan over the sovereignty of Nagorno-Karabakh, an autonomous Armenian-dominated enclave. Tass said the bombing was carried out by ``those who do not want the situation in the region, where a state of emergency has been declared, to improve and want ethnic strife to continue.'' At least 200 people have died in ethnic violence in the Caucasus Mountain republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia over the past two years. The dispute is centered on control of Nagorno-Karabakh. In Kirghizia, officials reported that new fighting has broken out between Kirghiz and Uzbeks. In the city of Osh, near the Uzbekistan border, shops were closed, public transportation was at a standstill and troops were patrolling the streets in armored personnel carriers, Tass said. The news agency quoted Kirghiz Interior Minister Viktor Goncharov as saying that at least 30 people were injured in weekend fighting, and that 15 were hospitalized. ``Crowds of people were gathering in the cities of Osh and Uzgen and nearby villages in defiance of a ban on rallies and there were frequent fights between Kirghiz and Uzbeks,'' Goncharov was quoted as saying on local television Sunday night. Ethnic clashes in Kirghizia broke out in early June over the allocation of land to ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks, both Sunni Moslems, in the densely populated region where housing is scarce. Officials said 148 people died in the June fighting and another 885 were injured. Tass said an analysis of the unrest by the Kirghizian Communist Party showed the clashes ``were provoked by grave social problems in an area with over 50,000 jobless, a severe housing shortage, and a lack of kindergartens and hospital facilities.''

DOC.HEAD: China Launches New Carrier Rocket
DOC.TEXT: China today launched a new carrier rocket with the ability to carry an eight-ton satellite into low-level orbit, according to the official Xinhua News Agency. The improved Long March 2 rocket, with four boosters, carried a simulation satellite and a small, experimental Pakistani satellite when it blasted off from the Xichang launch site in southwest China's Sichuan province. Xinhua said normal operations were reported for the rocket's first and second stage boosters, and the satellite control center called the launch a complete success. The rocket blasted off from a newly completed launch pad, China's largest, built to launch large carrier rockets. China entered the international satellite launching business in April with the sendoff of a 2,750-pound U.S.-made telecommunications satellite from a Long March 3 rocket. China has put 26 of its own satellites into orbit since 1970. In 1988, it signed an agreement with the United States promising to safeguard satellite technology and to abide by market practices in pricing and insurance. Some experts accuse China of ignoring the agreement and offering launches on its Long March rockets at half the price of its U.S. and European competitors. China already has contracts to launch an Arab communications satellite and two Australian satellites within two years.

DOC.HEAD: No. 1 Jewelry Retailer to Stop Selling South African Gold
DOC.TEXT: Britain's largest jewelry retailer today said it would stop selling jewelry made with South African gold. The decision followed pickets of its stores by anti-apartheid groups. A spokesman for the company, Ratners PLC, said the move was part of a continuing switch to North American gold supplies. One anti-apartheid group, End Loans to South Africa, said it has suspended its action against Ratners and is asking other groups to do the same, pending a meeting with Ratners officials. Ratners said South African gold is found in 2 percent to 3 percent of its gold jewelry. It had total sales of $1.6 billion in its fiscal year ended Feb. 3. ``It's a fairly simple process for us to remove the final few percentage points,'' said a Ratners spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The process should be completed in the next year or two, he said. The spokesman denied the move was in reponse to anti-apartheid pressure. He said he believed only three of its more than 1,000 British stores were picketed. ``We're a commercial organization, not a political organization,'' he said. End Loans to South Africa said it and other groups had applied pressure on Ratners in response to African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela's call to intensify sanctions and boycott South African goods to end apartheid. The ANC is South Africa's leading black opposition movement. It is seeking to end white minority rule of South Africa's black majority. Ratners has purchased much of its gold jewelry supplies from Italy, which according to a U.S. General Accounting Office report gets 91 percent of its gold from South Africa, the group said. South Africa produces one-third of the world's gold, the group said. South African supplies dominate the European gold market and almost all gold jewelry sold in Britain is made with South African gold, the group said. Non-South African supplies of gold are plentiful, it said. ``This historic victory will send clear signals to South Africa and will hasten an early end to apartheid,'' said Cosmas Desmond, head of End Loans to South Africa. ``It shows that British business can no longer avoid the moral implications of collaborating with apartheid.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Patrols City After Bombs Kill Dozens
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of soldiers and paramilitary police today patrolled this ethnically troubled city after a series of bomb blasts a day earlier killed at least 45 people and injured 125, police officials said. Police manned roadblocks and searched vehicles, but most of the streets in this city of 3 million appeared deserted. Police said they arrested 39 people in connection with the bombings, but no one has yet been charged with the blasts. Earlier, police said they suspected Sindhi nationalists had carried out the attacks. The nationalists want either greater autonomy for their province of Sindh or independence. On Sunday afternoon, six bombs exploded in several sections of this city and a seventh ripped through a southbound train as it left Hyderabad station. Witnesses said the blasts killed a total of 55 people. There was no explanation for their discrepancy with the police toll. The two largest cities in Sindh province, Hyderabad and Karachi, have become urban battlefields in a war between Sindhi nationalists and Indian immigrants who came to Pakistan following the partition of the subcontinent in 1947. Sindh governor Fakhruddin Ebrahim appealed to residents of both cities to ``exercise patience.'' He labelled the bombings ``the most heinous act against humanity.'' The leadership of the Mohajir Qami Movement, a politicial party that represents the immigrants, declared a three-day mourning period in Hyderabad and areas of Karachi populated by the immigrants. In the last several years, more than 1,000 people have died in ethnic violence in Sindh province. The army has been patrolling Karachi and Hyderabad since May 28. The immigrants dominate the cities in Sindh while nationalists control most of the countryside. The immigrants have demanded to be recognized as Pakistan's fifth ethnic nationality. The bombs are believed to have been planted by Sindhi nationalists protesting the immigrants refusal to honor a one-day strike called for Sunday. Most businesses in Hyderabad remained open Sunday. The strike was called to protest the arrest several weeks ago of a Sindhi activist, Qadar Magsi, who was charged with inciting violence.

DOC.HEAD: Albanians Head For Reception Centers
DOC.TEXT: After a warm reception, more than 500 Albanian refugees headed north today to reception centers where they were to be taught French and learn about their new country. Eight of the refugees were hospitalized with what the Red Cross said were unspecified benign ailments. Most of the rest of the 544 Albanians who arrived in Marseille Sunday were sent on special trains to Reims, on the way to three reception centers outside Paris. The Interior Ministry will give temporary residence permits to the refugees, many of whom are gypsies. All have the right to apply for political asylum. The refugees are the last arrivals of about 5,000 Albanians who boarded five ferries seeking asylum in Western Europe. Albanians began rushing into foreign embassies in the capital of Tirana on June 28 after word spread of a family that had been allowed to emigrate to Italy after spending five years in the Italian Embassy seeking political asylum. The majority of the refugees _ some 3,000 _ traveled to West Germany during the weekend after about 4,500 refugees were ferried from Albania to the southern Italian port of Brindisi. Italian and Egyptian officials reported today that no new Albanians had sought asylum in their embassies in Tirana, the Albanian capital. The Czechoslovak Embassy and the Hungarian mission were reported empty of refugees. The Red Cross conducted preliminary health checks on the latest arrivals on the train and at Reims. The refugees were then broken up into three groups and bused to Creil, Emance and Mourmelon in the Paris region. ``The health of most of the refugees is good,'' said a Red Cross spokesmen in Reims. ``But they all need rest.'' Carrying little luggage and dressed for the most part in T-shirts, simple trousers, sandals or clothing donated by the crew of the ferry Orient Star, the tired refugees settled into their temporary quarters in Reims for a long sleep. Soldiers had stockpiled 160 gallons of beverages and 660 pounds of fruit for their arrival. About 30 others arrived earlier by bus at another way station in Perigueux, southwestern France. Extremely tired, they turned down a prepared meal and simply asked for drinks and cigarettes. Several wept as they got off the bus. Most said all they wanted was sleep. They were later driven to two separate camps. They were jubilant on their arrival in Marseille, crying ``Long live France'' in Albanian and ``Long live the Albanian people'' as they disembarked. They then sang the Marseillaise, the French national anthem, just as they had done as their ferry docked in this French port. Geological engineer Arian Cipa, who arrived in Marseille Sunday, summed up the problems of his homeland: ``No freedom. No money. No future,'' he said. ``I could no longer tolerate the complete absence of freedom in my country,'' the 25-year-old said. ``I know it won't be easy for me in France, but I hope to succeed. I won't go back to Albania until the Communists are gone.'' Cipa took refuge in the French Embassy in Tirana for eight days before a U.N.-mediated settlement allowed him and thousands of others to leave for the West. The secretary of state for humanitarian action, Bernard Kouchner, escorted them to special trains bound for reception centers where fresh clothes, soap and toothpaste awaited.

DOC.HEAD: Inter-Shiite Fighting Flares, Arab Envoy In Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with 12 killed. Pickup 6th graf, `The police...'
DOC.TEXT: Hezbollah fighters attacked a major stronghold of the rival Shiite Moslem Amal militia in south Lebanon today, touching off a fierce battle. Police said at least 12 people were killed and 50 wounded. The flareup coincided with a new effort by an Arab League envoy to persuade Christian and Moslem leaders to agree to a settlement of the 15-year-old civil war. A police spokesman said militiamen of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, mounted a three-pronged attack at 6 a.m. behind a massive artillery barrage. The target was Jarjou village. The Syrian-backed Amal and Hezbollah, or Party of God, have been fighting each other intermittently for three years seeking control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Today's casualties raised the overall toll to 1,061 people killed and 3,201 wounded. The police spokesman, who could not be identified, said the identity of those killed was not known. But he said the wounded included 22 combatants and six civilians. Amal's leadership confirmed the attack in a statement, but said only 20 Amal militiamen were wounded. Hezbollah accused Amal earlier of shelling its positions in Jabal Safi, Mlita and Luweizeh with artillery and rockets. Ambulances raced in and out of the combat zone, ferrying victims to hospitals in Sidon. The mountainous region overlooks Sidon, provincial capital of south Lebanon, from the southeast. Sidon is 25 miles south of Beirut. Also in south Lebanon, militiamen of Sunni Moslem Nasserite organization clashed with the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army in Kfar Falous to the east of Sidon. There were no immediate casualty reports but the thud of exploding rockets and artillery shells shook the region. The Arab League envoy, Lakhdar Ibrahimi, met for 90 minutes late Sunday with rebel Gen. Michel Aoun over a peace plan endorsed last October by Lebanese legislators in a special meeting in the Saudi Arabian town of Taif. The conservative newspaper Al-Anwar, which is close to Aoun, said the discussion was ``rough.'' Ibrahimi refused to disclose details of the talks at the shell-wrecked presidential palace in Baabda, east of Beirut. Aoun, the Al-Anwar said, ``stressed the need for a reconsideration'' of the peace plan. The independent newspapr An-Nahar said the mere fact that Ibrahimi met Aoun was a ``positive'' development. Ibrahimi has made several trips to Lebanon since October, but met only once with Aoun, when he officially conveyed to him the agreement immediately after the Taif meeting. Aoun has rejected the accord, ostensibly because it did not include a fixed timetable for the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops from Lebanon. The Syrian forces control 70 percent of Lebanese territory under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the 22-nation Arab League. The Taif plan would redistribute power equally between Moslems and Christians, who have dominated the government, Parliament, judiciary and army since independence from France in 1943. It was welcomed by Moslems and most Christian leaders, including warlord Samir Geagea. Geagea is Aoun's main rival in the Christian camp. Differences among Christians over the Taif peace accord have sparked a bloody conflict between Aoun's troops and Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. The inconclusive power struggle that erupted Jan. 30 so far has killed 1,044 people and wounded 2,793, by police count.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Releases Nurse Jailed in Spy Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th pvs, `I hope...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY one quote from Foreign Ministry, not foreign minister. Pickup 5th pvs, `Mrs. Parish...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has released a British nurse who was jailed as an accomplice of a journalist executed as a spy, the Foreign Office said today. Daphne Parish was put on a private jet bound for Lusaka, Zambia, the Foreign Office said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, responding to overtures from President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, released the nurse for ``humanitarian reasons,'' the office said. The Foreign Office statement said: ``We are grateful to both presidents.'' ``I hope it is part of a move to put relations with Britain back onto a more even keel,'' Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said in an interview on BBC television. Mrs. Parish, 53, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for allegedly assisting Farhad Bazoft, who was hanged March 15 in Baghdad. Bazoft had been in Iraq working for The Observer, a Sunday newspaper published in London. Bazoft, an Iranian native who traveled on British documents, was arrested in September trying to check out reports of an explosion at a military installation. Colleagues insisted he was not a spy, just an enthusiastic reporter going after a scoop. Mrs. Parish was accused of driving Bazoft to the Al-Iskandaria military complex. Following Bazoft's execution, Britain recalled its ambassador from Iraq and expelled six Iraqi military trainees in protest. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd also announced a freeze on visits by government ministers to Iraq and canceled a trade mission. However, Hurd rejected trade sanctions against Iraq. Relations between the two countries were further strained in late March when British customs officers seized 40 components for nuclear bomb triggers at Heathrow airport, before they could be put aboard an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad. In April, customs officers seized massive steel tubing that had been ordered by Iraq. British authorities said the tubing appeared to be designed for a massive artillery gun. ``Through the the recent difficulties with Iraq, our desire has been open and honest dialogue,'' the Foreign Office said. ``The release is a constructive signal that they share our desire. We hope that Mrs. Parish's freedom is the latest step toward a new and more fruitful relationship with Iraq.'' Waldegrave said Mrs. Parish appeared to be in good health. The Foreign Office said it was up to her how long she would remain in Lusaka. The Foreign Office said it had approached a number of states to seek Mrs. Parish's release, and had not worked solely through Kaunda. Bazoft was one of several journalists who had accepted invitations to cover elections in Kurdistan in September. Just before he was hanged, Bazoft gave British Consul-General Robin Kealy a note of apology to Mrs. Parish, whom he had befriended on an earlier visit. Mrs. Parish was held at Abu Ghraid prison, the Foreign Office said. Adrian Hamilton, deputy editor of The Observer, said the release came as a surprise. ``Of course, they can never clear the decks when an innocent man has been hanged, but we are still delighted by Mrs. Parish's release,'' Hamilton said. ``She has been the most stalwart and formidable of women and has refused to give in to any kind of pressure to make a false statement.''

DOC.HEAD: Lightning Kills Hiker Atop Mount Whitney
DOC.TEXT: Hikers spent hours trying to revive a climber struck by lightning when they sought shelter in a stone hut atop Mount Whitney during a thunderstorm. The hiker died after he was flown out Saturday from the summit, said Ann Melle, Inyo County sheriff's spokesman. At 14,494 feet, Mount Whitney is the tallest mountain in the Lower 48 states. Thirteen hikers in all sought shelter in the hut, and two had to be revived after the hut was struck by lightning Saturday afternoon. The hut was built in 1909 for astronomers. The group performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation on Matthew Edward Nordbrock, 26, of Huntington Beach for five hours before rescuers arrived by helicopter to take him to a hospital where he died. ``That tore us apart,'' said hiker Glen MacLeod. ``But we looked around and realized that it could have been all 13 of us that didn't make it. We were very lucky.'' Three others were also flown Saturday to Southern Inyo Hospital in Lone Pine, a small town at the base of Mount Whitney. The rest of the hikers remained on the summit overnight and were flown out Sunday morning. The hikers described a chaos in the moments after the lightning bolt hit. ``You could smell the burning flesh, burning fur and burning clothes,'' said Calif Tervo, one of the rescued hikers. MacLeod's brother, James, on Sunday showed reporters where lightning had carved bite-sized chunks of flesh from his shoulders, back and under an arm. He was revived bu the others after he was hit. ``Every article of clothing I have has holes in it, except my shoes,'' he said. ``Every muscle in my body must have contracted. I'm sore all over.'' MacLeod said doctors told him the electrical charge entered his right shoulder, where a 4-inch diameter wound could be seen, and then caused nearly a dozen smaller wounds where it exited his body. ``It's unbelievable what it did to me,'' he said. ``It's so scary to think about how it just went right through me.''

DOC.HEAD: AP and CWA Reach Tentative Three-Year Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press and its technical employees have reached a tentative agreement on a new, three-year contract. The package now is subject to ratification by the 310 members of the Communications Workers of America, the two sides announced. In the agreement, reached on Saturday, the AP dropped its proposal for a deductible on hospital bills. However, the new contract contains a ``managed care'' system for the health plan that the AP had sought. Under the tentative accord, the weekly salaries of top-scale technical workers would increase $23.50 the first year, $24 the second and $24.50 in the third year, bringing wages to $636.50 weekly. ``We believe this is a good contract for both sides,'' said Byron Yake, AP's director of human resources. ``Adding a third year to the agreement provides everyone with more stability.'' ``The negotiating committee is recommending acceptance of the agreement,'' Ed Cotter, a member of the Communications Workers of America bargaining committee, said in a taped telephone message to members. The CWA said its members earlier had rejected a two-year contract offer. The new agreement includes increases in pension benefits and geographic differentials in the third year. The contract would be retroactive to May 19 and expire May 18, 1993. The technical employees have been working under contract extensions since their old agreement expired in May.

DOC.HEAD: Bishop Asks Army, Civilians to Fight for Democracy
DOC.TEXT: An Anglican bishop is calling on the government to resign and has appealed to all Kenyans, including members of the armed forces, to join in a struggle for democracy. In a statement made available to The Associated Press today, Bishop Henry Okullu also blamed President Daniel arap Moi's one-party government for recent clashes that left 28 people dead and scores injured. Most of the casualties were pro-democracy protesters. ``I appeal to the sons and daughters of Kenya, wherever they are, in the armed forces as well as ordinary civilians, to join in the struggle for democracy, for peace and justice,'' Okullu said in a statement. ``Kenyans are fightfully frustrated with this government and there is no other way of putting it than that we want to elect a new and proper government,'' he said. Okullu also reiterated his opposition to the policy of detaining government critics without trial. He said he intends to ask Moi to have seven current detainees tried in court. Kenyan laws permit the indefinite detention of people the government considers a threat to security. The government detained seven people, including two former Cabinet ministers, this month in a crackdown on advocates of multiparty democracy in this one-party East African nation. The U.S. State Department has also expressed concern over the government crackdown on supporters of pluralism in Kenya and several Congressman have proposed halting U.S. military and economic assistance to Moi's government. Moi has said that pluralism would result in tribal conflict between Kenya's almost 40 ethnic groups. Okullu said people are frustrated with government mismanagment of health services and municipalities, widespread poverty, rigging of elections, and the government's refusal to call for a national convention to discuss the country's future. The clergyman told the government ``to stop intimidating people.'' They ``will not give up,'' he said. Okullu said Parliament should be dissolved and he called for the creation of a transitional government of national unity. The bishop also said an assembly should be convened to write a new constitution. Okullu is one of several Kenyan clergymen who have critized the government's crackdown on advocates of multiparty politics. On Saturday, four clergymen, including Anglican Archbishop Manasses Kuria, issued a statement calling on Moi to establish a forum for Kenyans to express their views on the country's future.

DOC.HEAD: Attacks Leave 46 Dead; Drug Traffickers, Police Suspected
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded in front of police headquarters in the cocaine capital of Medellin, killing a pedestrian, and a series of attacks by gunmen left 39 people dead, police said. In the southern jungle town of Puerto Asis, a bomb exploded Sunday killing six people and wounding five, police said. Police have blamed previous Medellin attacks on cocaine traffickers. Authorities in Puerto Asis said there was no known motive for the attack. Medellin, with nearly 3 million inhabitants, is Colombia's second-largest city. The cartel of the same name has supplied up to 70 percent of the cocaine sold in the United States. The violence began late Saturday when a car bomb exploded in front of the Medellin police headquarters, killing a 19-year-old pedestrian, police said. The bomb contained more than 110 pounds of dynamite but only 65 pounds exploded, they said. Car bombings this year in Medellin have killed 60 people and wounded hundreds more. Two hours after the bombing, unidentified gunmen drove into one of the city's poor northeastern neighborhoods and killed seven youths, according to a police statement. Two other youths were wounded. Three more youths were killed in Medellin's San Javier neighborhood when a group of assailants broke into a party and began firing. Three people were wounded in the attack, police said. Assassins also killed two police officers and a soldier in separate incidents in the city, the report said. The other 26 people were killed in scattered incidents. Terrorists allegedly working for drug dealers have killed 144 police officers in Medellin this year. The Medellin cartel has reportedly offered to pay $4,300 for each police officer assassinated. Authorities say cocaine traffickers are trying to force police to give up a search for Pablo Escobar, leader of the Medellin cartel. Medellin police chief Col. Jorge Ferrero said massacres in Medellin's poor neighborhoods are the work of rival gangs working for drug traffickers, but human rights activists said many of the incidents are carried out by police retaliating for attacks. In Puerto Asis, a bomb containing 44 pounds of dynamite severely damaged the Chilimaco hotel, a police statement said. All the victims were hotel workers. In a U.S.-backed crackdown on drug traffickers, about 2,000 soldiers and policemen are hunting for Escobar in the northeastern region, using helicopters and land patrols. The search began six days ago and is part of the government's 11-month-old war against trafickers that began when drug barons allegedly assassinated leading presidential candidate Sen. Luis Carlos Galan. The traffickers retaliated with a campaign of car bombings, massacres and police assassinations that has left hundreds dead.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Kohl Says He, Gorbachev Agree Germany will be Free to Choose its Alliance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev has removed his objection to a unified Germany belonging to NATO. The agreement between Kohl and Gorbachev cleared a major obstacle to German unification. Kohl also announced agreement on several other major issues, including a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from East German territory and the size of the armed forces for a united Germany. Kohl, speaking at joint news conference with Gorbachev in the Soviet Union that was broadcast live on West German television, said he and Gorbachev had agreed that a unified Germany will be free and sovereign to choose if and which alliance it will belong to. Kohl said he told Gorbachev that Germany wanted to stay in NATO. The Soviet Union had been objecting to NATO membership for a unified Germany. The chancellor was speaking at the end of a two-day visit to the Soviet Union and talks with Gorbachev aimed at removing Soviet concerns over German unification. The news conference was held in the southern Russian city of Zhelosnovodsk. Kohl said that Soviet troops should be withdrawn from East German territory three to four years after Germany is united. The Soviets now have about 380,000 troops in East Germany. During the same period, the armed forces of a united Germany will be reduced to 370,000 soldiers, Kohl said. The combined strength of the East and West German armed forces is now about 600,000, with West Germany providing 480,000 men. Kohl said the rights of the four World War II victorious powers will cease immediately after unification, but that their troops could stay in Berlin as long as the Soviet troops are in East Germany. He said a united Germany and the Soviet Union will sign a comprehensive treaty that will govern all aspects of their relations.

DOC.HEAD: Pipeline Accidents Disrupt Gas, Oil Flow
DOC.TEXT: A pipeline has ruptured in the Ural mountains, spewing 735 million cubic feet of natural gas into the air, the official Tass new agency reported today. In a separate incident this weekend, a corroded oil pipeline sprang a leak, the oil caught fire, and 27 wells had to be shut down, Tass said. An official blamed the accidents on poor construction and maintenance. In the first incident, the pipeline rupture halted supplies of more than 3,500 million cubic feet of natural gas coming from the Tyumen region, 900 miles east of Moscow, the official news agency reported. ``Over 21 million cubic meters (735 million cubic feet) were released into the air,'' Tass said. ``The site of the accident cannot be accessed by road, further complicating the problem.'' Rescue teams, helicopters and equipment were sent to the scene, and bridges were being built across marshes to allow workers to reach the ruptured pipeline, it said. At the Belozerneft field in the same region, a corroded oil pipeline sprang a leak, Tass said. ``The oil caught fire, 27 wells had to be shut down and some 400,000 tons of valuable raw materials were lost,'' the agency said. Tass quoted L. Roketsky, chairman of the Tyumen executive committee, as blaming the accidents on slipshod construction and sloppy maintenance. ``We saved by not building standby lines, took no care to build roads, and did not properly repair pipelines,'' Roketsky was quoted as saying. ``And who will calculate the cost of spills, pollution of rivers and land?''

DOC.HEAD: No Trace of Stolen Air Force Plane, Suicide Suspected
DOC.TEXT: Military officials believe the reserve pilot who stole an air force plane committed suicide by crashing into the Mediterranean, but have not ruled out the possibility that he defected to an Arab country, newspapers said today. A military spokesman said no trace of the plane or pilot has been found despite three days of the most widespread land, sea and air search ever conducted by Israel's armed forces. The pilot, a 33-year captain in the reserves, took off in the twin-engine Dornier-28 aircraft before dawn Friday. It was the first time an Israeli air force plane was stolen. Newspapers said today the air force has not ruled out the possibility the pilot had defected to a neighboring Arab country. The Jerusalem Post said the plane could have made it to the friendly nations of Cyprus or Turkey, but that authorities there said the plane had not been seen. The army waited until late Saturday night to publicize the incident. The missing West German-made aircraft is of a type often used for reconnaissance. The military would not say whether it was equipped with weapons. Military sources told the Israeli press authorities believe the pilot flew out to sea until he ran out of gas and crashed. ``We believe (the incident) was connected to personal problems,'' a military spokeswoman told The Associated Press. She could not be named according to regulations. After taking off, the pilot reportedly flew over most of the country and ``buzzed'' his house in the northern port city of Haifa. The plane was last seen heading to the Israeli border with Lebanon, the Maariv and Davar newspapers said. Newspapers identified the pilot by the name Captain H. and said he was studying for a doctorate in physics at Technion, a prestigious scientific institute in Haifa. They said he had been having maritial problems and was not living with his wife. ``H. was a strange guy who wasn't accepted by society,'' a friend of the pilot told the Al Hamishmar newspaper. Senior military officers told Al Hamishmar they will take steps to prevent a recurrence of the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood Freeway Partially Opens To Traffic After Subway Fire
DOC.TEXT: Repair crews working round-the-clock enabled authorities to reopen a small segment of a key downtown freeway for weekday commuters, transportation officials said today. One regular lane of the Hollywood Freeway and a temporary lane on the shoulder opened for northbound traffic at 6:10 a.m., said Stephanie Brady, a county transportation comission spokesman. A 1{-mile section of the 10-lane highway had been closed since Friday, when an intense fire burned out a subway tunnel being built under the highway just east of downtown. By 6 a.m. today, workers had used steel and wooden braces to shore up about 152 feet inside a 17-foot-diameter tunnel, Ms. Brady said. ``They were able to make more progress overnight than anticipated and will continue working around the clock, with 25-man crews, until the work under the freeway is completed,'' she said. ``Their primary objective at this time is to enable Caltrans to open the freeway lanes.'' ``This is a fix-as-you-go effort,'' said Edward McSpedon, president of Rail Construction Corp., which has supervised the tunnel repair effort. All five southbound lanes of the Hollywood Freeway would remain closed until further notice, Caltrans officials said Sunday. And on the lanes that were reopened, trucks will be prohibited, the agency said. State transportation officials closed the freeway because they feared it could collapse into the tunnel. More than 250,000 vehicles travel the highway daily. CalTrans officials advised motorists to leave early, use car pools or take the bus during the week. Buses run on a separate elevated roadway that parallels the freeway and was not affected by the fire. Damage to the $10 million tunnel was estimated at $2.5 million to $5 million, said Southern California Rapid Transit District officials.

DOC.HEAD: Protester Moved From Site Of King Assassination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to add detail; clarifies that while a half-doen deputies were on hand, just two picked her up. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `When the...'.
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff's deputies picked up a protester and carried her away today from the construction site of a museum at the small motel where Martin Luther King Jr. was murdered. Jacqueline Smith has camped in front of the Lorraine Motel for two years to protest the construction project and had defied a judge's order to move. Two deputies picked her up from a lawn chair this morning and moved her bodily from her campsite to a sidewalk across the street. She offered no resistance and did not appear to say anything as she was being moved. Then workmen from the construction project began moving her belongings into the street. Ms. Smith, 39, a former worker and resident of the motel, is protesting the decision to remodel it into a museum in honor of King, who was assassinated in 1968. She wants it to be used to serve the poor instead, saying King's memory and ``this sacred ground is being exploited.'' She also complains that the museum is part of an overall movement to upgrade housing and raise rents in the generally low-income neighborhood. ``It is my right and any other poor person's right to remain in this area,'' she said today. When the motel was closed two years ago, deputies had to evict her then, too. Tom Marshall, a deputy chief with the Shelby County Sheriff's Department, said his officers did not arrest Ms. Smith this morning. ``We're enforcing a court order,'' Marshall said. He said it would be up to the city to deal with her tent and other belongings left in the small side street in front of the motel. Ms. Smith said she did not know if she would continue her protest from the location across the street. ``I just don't know,'' she said. ``It's been a shock.'' On Friday, a judge had set a deadline of Saturday for Ms. Smith to move, saying she was trespassing on a construction site. But authorities decided to take no action over the weekend. The Lorraine was shut by the state in January 1988 to make way for the museum project. Sheriff's deputies evicted Ms. Smith two months later. The deputies deposited her on a sidewalk outside the motel, where she set up a tent and remained. Work on the museum site got under way last year, but authorities generally ignored Ms. Smith until now. Anthony Vaccaro, project manager for Jameson-Vaccaro Construction Co., said she was camped on a spot that must be torn up for utility lines, and the company petitioned the court to have her moved. This morning, Ms. Smith was surrounded by about a dozen supporters when sheriff's deputies arrived. None was arrested and there were no confrontations. There were about 50 onlookers. The Lorraine was a popular stopping place for blacks when Memphis hotels were segregated, but it was falling apart in 1982 when a group of citizens bought it at foreclosure auction. The group formed the Lorraine Civil Rights Museum Foundation and spent the next several years persuading the state, county and city governments to build the $9 million museum. Title to the property was turned over to the state. The museum, to be called the National Civil Rights Center, is scheduled to open July 4, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Forms Human Chain to Rescue Fire Victim
DOC.TEXT: Four people formed a human chain by gripping each other's ankles to save a neighbor trapped in his burning house. Three neighbors and a motorist lay on their stomachs and crawled into the home of Morris Fondaw after spotting flames Saturday night. ``The guy was yelling for help, `I'm here! I'm here!','' said Kenneth Cassibo, who led the chain into the house. Cassibo was forced to momentarily break the chain to reach the last few feet and find the 63-year-old man. Then the group backed out of the house. Jeannie Bauers, another neighbor who helped form the chain, said Fondaw said he had fallen asleep while smoking in bed and got lost in the heat and smoke trying to escape. Fondaw's wife, Margaret, said her husband was treated for smoke inhalation. No one else was injured. Mrs. Bauers said she didn't consider herself a hero. ``I always figure if something like that happened to me, I'd have neighbors to help me,'' she said. Cheboygan is on Lake Huron near the northern tip of Michigan's Lower Peninsula.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed in Drive-by Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Shots fired from passing cars into a crowd at an oudoor taco wagon killed two men and wounded 12, authorities said. The gunfire early Sunday sent people running, some of them scaling barbed wire fences, others hiding behind and under parked cars, witnesses said. ``I didn't have time to get scared,'' said Jesus Sanchez, who was eating at the outdoor stand when he was hit in the abdomen. ``I felt something hot in my side. I reached down and I saw my hand covered in my blood. But I hid under a car until the firing stopped,'' Sanchez said through an interpreter. Three men were arrested, and police were looking for other suspects in the shooting in this northern California city. ``There was some type of an altercation between some men over a young lady,'' said police Sgt. Edward Williams. ``Some of the fellows left and then subsequently returned with additional people, armed with what we believe at this time was a shotgun and a couple of rifles, and started firing on the people in the parking lot.'' The dead were identified as James Guiterez Perez, 19, and Leobardo Barajas, 18. Police Sgt. Patrick O'Hern said today that one of the 12 injured people was hospitalized in critical condition. Four were in stable condition and three in serious condition; the others were treated and released. Witneses said the assailants drove by in three cars and opened fire on the crowd, many of them customers of the taco wagon outside a liquor store. ``Everybody just started hiding and running,'' said Jeff Jones.

DOC.HEAD: Apollo, Soyuz Crew Members Finally Seeing Cooperation They Expected
DOC.TEXT: The crews of the Soviet and American spacecraft that linked in orbit 15 years ago say that only now are they beginning to see the cooperation on research they expected after their historic mission. ``I would have hoped we'd see some changes happening sooner than this. But it's very positive now,'' said Donald ``Deke'' Slayton, pilot of the docking module that linked the Apollo and Soyuz ships on July 15, 1975. Slayton and others who served on the 1975 mission predicted Sunday that warming U.S.-Soviet relations will help the two countries work together to put man on Mars within 20 years. ``The two most notable times in relations between these two countries were World War II and the Apollo-Soyuz mission,'' said retired Air Force Lt. Gen. Thomas Stafford, 59. Thomas and Slayton were on hand at a Seattle air show to commemorate the mission anniversary, along with Soyuz commander Alexei Leonov and Soviet crew member Valeriy Kubasov. The four are currently touring the United States. Leonov said he was disappointed by what happened after the mission. ``We finished our joint program perfectly, and Mr. (President) Ford said we are ready to have our cooperation,'' he said. ``I don't know why, but President Carter broke our programs. It was very bad for relations between our country and America.'' Thomas pointed out that the freeze in joint programs occurred after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. Leonov said he has high hopes for a joint Mars program, and said a joint program may be the only way to reach the planet. ``If America will do Mars alone it will be very expensive. If the Soviet Union will do it alone, also. We are going to work together because the Soviet Union and America have very good results,'' he said. Slayton said a U.S.-Soviet Mars mission is ``inevitable. It's just a matter of when. We're probably 15 or 20 years away from that because of resources. But it will be a major international venture.'' Slayton said the Soviet and American crew members have met many times since their 1975 orbital flight. The third Apollo mission member, command-module pilot Vance Brand, 59, was unable to attend Sunday's meeting. He is preparing to command the space shuttle Columbia's next mission.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Repays its Last World Bank Loan
DOC.TEXT: Japan, which has moved from the second-largest World Bank loan debtor to the world's largest creditor nation, repaid its last World Bank loan today. The last $7 million installment on a 25-year, $75 million loan to the Japan Highway Public Corp. was paid, said World Bank spokeswoman Keiko Sato. Between 1953 and 1966, Japan borrowed $862.9 million from the World Bank to finance 31 projects. Only India borrowed more money from the World Bank at that time. The loans financed the construction of power plants, steel mills and other development projects. ``The World Bank provided money during Japan's roughest times,'' said Seiichiro Yonekura, professor of business history at Hitotsubashi University. ``Without its help, Japan's postwar recovery would have been inconceivable.'' The bank's strict scrutiny over borrowers also forced Japanese companies to improve their management and accounting practices, Yonekura said. In a statement released by the World Bank, J. Burke Knapp, chairman of the bank's loan committee during the 1950s and 1960s, said ``there was considerable skepticism in the bank regarding Japan's economic viability and creditworthiness.'' When the bank awarded its first loans to Japan, the economy was ``in an almost primitive condition, barely recovered from the ravages of war, and struggling with seemingly intractable balance-of-payments problems,'' he said. But Burke Knapp added that when Japan stopped borrowing from the World Bank in 1966, ``the World Bank too had cause to regret the termination, since for many years we had been saying that every loan we made to Japan improved the quality of our general portfolio.'' Japan is now the second largest contributor after the United States to the international loan institution, bearing 6.69 percent of its total shares. The bank also borrows up to one-third of its finances from the Tokyo money market. The United States lost its position as world's largest creditor nation to Japan in the early 1980s. By 1985, the United States was a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. In 1989 the United States tightened its grip on the title of world's largest debtor by ending the year with a net debt of $663.7 billion, up 25 percent from the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: While Child Driving, Car Plunges in Creek; Death Toll Climbs To Five
DOC.TEXT: A man who allowed his 13-year-old niece to drive a car while he helped steer, only to have it plunge into a rain-swollen creek, died today, bringing the toll from the weekend accident to five, a hospital official said. Donald Duncan, 27, who was pulled from Pequea Creek late Saturday, died at Lancaster General Hospital, a spokeswoman said. His niece, Heather Cunrod, the only survivor of the accident, was in fair condition today. The other four victims were children age 3 to 7. Heather was behind the wheel and Duncan was in the passenger seat when the car overshot a parking lot and went into the creek, police said. Conestoga Township police Samuel S. Goss said the girl told him Duncan had offered to let her drive and she had gone about two miles when the accident happened after they turned into a parking lot. ``There was no way they could have stopped, even if she jammed on the brakes,'' he said. ``The car carried 40 feet into the water,'' he said. ``It was doing 40, 45 mph, even faster _ it just sailed like a boat.'' Heather managed to escape the sinking car, but people at a nearby boat club were unable to rescue the others. ``We did our best, we tried,'' said Bruce Kline, 28, a steelworker who operated the winch that pulled the car toward shore. He estimated that Duncan and the children were under water for 20 minutes. Heather was already on shore, he said, adding: ``She was flipping out. I don't remember what she said, just that there's guys and kids in the car.'' The younger victims were identified as Heather's 7-year-old sister, Jennifer, and 3-year-old brother, Timothy, and Duncan's 3-year-old son, Donald, and 6-year-old daughter, Jessica.

DOC.HEAD: Locals Thank Protesters of Prairie Dog Shoot, Say Business Boomed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The two-day...', to CORRECT Calhoun's first name to Rusty sted Randy.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NATX1
DOC.TEXT: Protesters eager to shut down the Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot instead helped make it a booming business success _ and all the hubbub may have made the curious critters easier to kill. Locals thanked animal rights protesters for publicizing the event that kept cash registers ringing as more than 100 shooters, about five dozen reporters and hundreds of partying visitors descended on this rural ranching area. ``They didn't mean to do it, but they did us more good than anything that's been done around here in years,'' said Beulah Colcord, owner of the Yellow Rock Cafe, the area's social center in nearby Naturita. An animal advocate appalled at the killing of prairie dogs for sport and $7,000 in prizes said prior to the shoot that 5,000 protesters would disrupt the weekend event, but no more than two dozen showed up. The two-day prairie dog death toll was 2,956, with local rancher Earl Reams and partner Rusty Calhoun claiming top dog honors with 112 kills between them. Reams said New York can have Broadway. He prefers more rustic diversions. ``Some places have theaters, we have turkey shoots,'' he said. ``This is good for the town and now we're on the map.'' Protesters hooting and blowing whistles in hopes of keeping the targeted rodents inside their burrows during the shooting actually hurt the curious animals' chances of surviving, participants said. ``All their noise does is bring the prairie dogs out of their holes to see what's doing on,'' said Terrye Logan, 32, of Clyde, Texas, one of three women competing in the event. ``My brothers yesterday ended up laughing so hard they had to put their guns down.'' A 25-man special sheriff's force was on patrol. There were a number of verbal confrontations but no fistfights. Two protesters were cited for trespassing. Nucla Mayor John Vanderpool, who wore a flak jacket all weekend after receiving death threats, said local merchants reported ``everything has at least tripled'' because of the prairie dog shoot. Organizer Mike Mehew said he'd be writing thank-you notes today to Robin Duxbury of the Rocky Mountain Humane Society, Gov. Roy Romer and U.S. Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell ``because they really made this what it turned out to be.'' Duxbury had promised to deliver 5,000 protesters to the event, but was not even among the small number that showed up. Romer and Campbell said they understood that ranchers need to control prairie dogs to protect livestock and prevent soil erosion, but criticized the shoot that turned rodent control into a spectacle. The Moose Lodge in Nucla, headquarters of the hunt, reported skyrocketing revenue. Bar receipts for the week hit $22,000, compared with $800 normally tallied each week, lodge administrator Leo Laremore said. The Yellow Rock Cafe did even better, Colcord said. ``We did enough in four days to double what we do in an entire (big game) hunting season,'' she said. ``And we couldn't be happier with the protesters. They made the publicity that brought all these people in here.'' Reams and Calhoun won two top-of-the line Kimber rifles after the event that awarded more points for long-distance kills and deducted points for missed short-range shots. The shooters' pace was deliberate and careful, with a shot coming about once every five minutes when a prairie dog poked his head into the air. Four hunters were stationed at each ranch and each was allowed 50 shots a day. Only four local shooters were entered in the 106-shooter field, which drew hunters from California to North Carolina. Three young protesters were all that remained Sunday of the larger band of demonstrators operating the day before. ``If nothing else, we're bothering the mighty hunters,'' said Jon Ellenbogen, 24, who moved from Detroit to Durango three months ago. ``I don't take their arguments about damage from prairie dogs. If the prairie dogs are ruining it for the cows, don't raise cows. Shooting them is not much of a philosophy.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Cooperation, Environmental Management Top Governors' Agenda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with meeting under way, new chairman elected. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Sinner wants...'.
DOC.TEXT: Building cooperation with Canadian neighbors, water management and the handling of nuclear and other hazardous aste top the agenda at the annual meeting of the Western Governors' Association today. Governors from 12 western states and American Samoa are attending. This morning, South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson was formally elected chairman of the group. He will succeed North Dakota Gov. George Sinner at the end of the annual meeting Tuesday. Wyoming Gov. Michael Sullivan was elected vice chairman. For the first time, Canadian officials were invited to attend the governors' gathering. Premiers Grant Devine of Saskatchewan and Gary Filmon of Manitoba were scheduled to attend sessions later today, and representatives from Alberta and British Columbia also were expected to meet with state leaders. Sinner said Sunday that he hoped the meeting would lead to regular discussions between U.S. state leaders and their Canadian counterparts. Sinner wants to promote closer ties with western Canada, but he says it is premature for the association to consider making Canadian premiers members of the organization. Water management, hazardous waste and nuclear waste disposal and state-tribal relations are other prominent agenda topics. On Tuesday, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan and W. Henson Moore, a deputy U.S. energy secretary, will meet with the governors to discuss issues of mutual interest to western states and the federal government. The governors of Colorado, Idaho, Minnesota, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, Wyoming and American Samoa are attending the conference.

DOC.HEAD: UN Report Lauds De Klerk, Black Leaders
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. report declared today that South Africa is beginning to dismantle apartheid and ``has reached the threshold of a new era'' of nonracial democracy. Introducing the report, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar praised South African President F.W. de Klerk for his ``bold and courageous'' policy of dismantling apartheid and also lauded black leaders for ``vision and forbearance.'' The report was prepared by a U.N. team that traveled to South Africa. Perez de Cuellar said he was ``greatly encouraged by the positive developments'' in South Africa this year. He added, however, the process of dismantling the apartheid system of racial segregation was still at an early stage and emphasized the system has inflicted grave social injustice on the majority black population. Perez de Cuellar, in an apparent reference to both blacks and whites, cited ``the urgent requirement to end the violence.'' In December, the General Assembly convened a special session that called on South Africa to negotiate an end to apartheid and transform their country into a nonracial democracy. It also called upon the secretary-general to make a report on progress in ending apartheid. Perez de Cuellar dispatched a team to South Africa from June 9 to 19, led by Abdulrahim A. Farah, undersecretary-general for special political questions. The team met government officials, opposition and black leaders and gathered information on steps to end apartheid. ``South Africa has reached the threshold of a new era,'' Farah said in his report. ``The political process on which it has embarked holds encouraging prospsects of leading to the dismantlement of apartheid.'' But he added, ``So long as racial attitudes persist and apartheid structures at the local level remain, the process for change will encounter difficulties.'' Perez de Cuellar cited steps taken by the de Klerk government, including lifting a ban on political parties and movements. The national state of emergency has been lifted in all but Natal Province. ``While it is evident that an important process has been set in motion,'' he said, ``many believe that the government should implement all measures in their totality to create the appropriate atmosphere.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Cities Face Serious Water Shortage
DOC.TEXT: China needs 10 million tons of additional water each day to meet the needs of 300 major cities that are facing serious water shortages, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Monday. Last year, China lost $2.6 billion worth of industrial output due to water shortages in 94 cities in five provinces, according to Wang Guangtao, director of the Construction Ministry's urban construction department. China's per capita water supply is only one-fourth the world level because of pollution, shortage of water supply facilities and huge long-term waste caused by the low price for tap water set by the state, Wang said. In the past seven years, China has spent $1.7 billion on water supply projects, increasing capacity by 20 million tons a day, he said. Each summer, residents of major cities like Beijing and Shanghai are urged to control their water consumption. The demand can be so large that at times no water is available in parts of the city.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Extremists Kill 8 Relatives of Police Constable
DOC.TEXT: Sikh extremists barged into the house of a Sikh policeman Monday and killed his four brothers and four other relatives, police said. Senior police superintendent Anil Sharma said the shootings occurred in Trindi village, 55 miles east of Amritsar, the stronghold of Sikh militants fighting for a separate homeland in the state of Punjab. Six to eight gunmen came to constable Kashmira Singh's house early Monday and asked for the policeman, Sharma said. When told by one of Singh's brothers that he was in a neighboring village, the extremists fired their automatic weapons in the courtyard, killing the eight people. The extremists came in a jeep and fled after the killings, he said. The reason for the killings was not immediately clear, but the extremists have been increasingly targeting policemen and their families in their 8-year-old campaign for independence. At least 1,391 people have been killed by the extremists this year. Extremists among the Sikh community claim cultural and political discrimination by the Hindu-dominated government. Sikhs are in a slight majority in Punjab, but nationwide they comprise 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pollution at Fish Farm Kills 60,000 Trout
DOC.TEXT: Water polluted by farming chemicals spilled into aquaculture basins over the weekend, killing about 60,000 young trout, fish farmers said Monday. The water, used to clean a piece of farming equipment, was apparently tainted by chemicals used to raise potatoes, the fish farmers said. The run-off reached a stream feeding the fish-raising basins and poisoned the 7- to 8-month-old trout, the fish farmers said, estimating the cost at 18 cents per fish. That would make the total loss more than $1 million. The Breton Trout Association has demanded a meeting with regional authorities in western Brittany to complain about what it claims is frequent river pollution by farmers.

DOC.HEAD: Police Follow Trail of Luxury Boats to Tax Evaders
DOC.TEXT: Frustrated by the legions of Italian tax evaders, revenue agents have taken a new tack _ boarding luxury boats to see if the owners' income declarations are as high as their lifestyles. Treasury officers checked out 217 yachts anchored in the Bay of Naples over the weekend, RAI state television reported Monday. The report didn't say how many tax evaders were discovered by the visits. But among the yacht owners was a man who had described himself in tax forms as a Naples street vendor with little earnings, RAI said. The government has declared war on tax evasion in an attempt to cut away at a budget deficit expected to reach $125 billion by year's end.

DOC.HEAD: Three Men Sentenced To Death For Drug Trafficking
DOC.TEXT: The High Court on Monday sentenced three men to death for trafficking in 37.8 ounces of cannabis. Judge James Foong held that Zainudin Baharudin 30, Zawawi Zainon, 24, and his brother, Zakaria Zainon, 29, had custody and knowledge of the drug, which police found in a room rented by Zawawi. Mere possession of more than 3.53 ounces of cannabis, often used to make marijuana or hashish, is deemed to be trafficking under Malaysian law. No sale need be proved. Since parliament passed laws in 1975 allowing the death sentence for drug trafficking, 256 people have been sentenced to death. Of these, 92 have been hanged. It was not known yet if the three would appeal to the supreme court.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Wanted By Law Enforcement Officials
DOC.TEXT: Wanted by the Czech Ministry of Justice: Vaclav Havel. For at least one bureaucrat within the ministry, Havel remains the shady enemy of the state and former convict instead of Czechoslovak president. The daily Mlada Fronta on Monday carried the facsimile of a request from the Ministry of Justice to the criminal department of Prague police on the ``whereabouts of a Vaclav Havel, born Oct. 5, 1936.'' The suspect ``moved without notifying the authorities,'' the daily quoted the request, dated May 2, as saying. Havel was jailed for 4{ years by Communists during the 20 years he acted as a human rights activist and dissident under Czechoslovakia's harsh Communist regime. He was under permanent watch of the secret police until last year's democratic changes resulted in his election as president.
