The ministry inquiry appeared not only out of date but based on inaccurate information as well. Unlike his predecessors, Havel, who starts serving his second term as president on July 5, still formally lives in his private apartment in downtown Prague, although he spends much of his time at the presidential residence in Lany, near Prague, and his country house at Hradecek in northern Bohemia.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Minister Says Robbers Killed 100 Train Passengers
DOC.TEXT: Robbers raiding a train in Cambodia killed more than 100 passengers, the country's official SPK news agency said Monday. The report quoted the defense minister, Gen. Tea Banh, who mentioned the raid at a news conference in Phnom Penh on Saturday. He had been speaking about the war against guerrillas opposing his Vietnamese-installed government. He said the railway sometimes was raided at vulnerable points in Kampot province. In the recent attack in its Kompong Trach district, he said, ``the robbers killed more than 100 passengers and robbed their property and foodstuff.'' The report did not say whether Banh identified the assailants, and it was impossible to confirm the report. Previous claims by the Communist government have been exaggerated. The most active guerrilla group in Kampot has been the Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of people while ruling Cambodia from 1975 until Vietnam invaded in late 1978 and installed the current government. The Khmer Rouge is allied with the forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front.

DOC.HEAD: China Finds Dinosaur Fossils, Among World's Largest
DOC.TEXT: Chinese and Canadian scientists have found what they believe may be the largest dinosaur fossils in the world, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Monday. The discovery last month of the remains of a dinosaur believed to have been 99 feet long was made in northwest China's Gobi desert by members of the Sino-Canadian Dinosaur Project, the report said. The fossils, including a complete skull and 10 pieces of cervical vertebrae, were found in the Junggar basin in the Xinjiang Autonomous Region, it said. Chinese paleontologist Dong Zhiming said the remains date back 140 million years and are believed to be the largest found in Asia and possibly the world. The fossils have been shipped to Beijing for laboratory analysis, Xinhua said. The report did not say what kind of dinosaur it was believed to be. The Dinosaur Project, begun in 1986, involves experts from the two fossil-rich countries of Canada and China who have made three large expeditions into the Gobi desert. Their dinosaur and other fossil discoveries, including 12 major dinosaur skeletons, will be part of a traveling exhibit to 12 cities around the world scheduled for 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Yellowstone Park Authorities Give Up `Let it Burn' Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The park's..', to CORRECT spelling of blackened.
DOC.TEXT: When a lightning bolt sent flames crackling from a cottonwood tree in Yellowstone National Park, half a dozen firefighters responded within minutes. They were too late; the fire had been reduced to embers by heavy rain from the storm that got it going. But ever since blazes blackened nearly half of Yellowstone's 2.2 million acres during the dry, hot summer of 1988, even a single burning tree quickly draws firefighters' attention. The heavily criticized ``let it burn'' plan under which fires caused by nature were left untouched unless they endangered people or structures has been suspended and is under review. This year, firefighters have fought about a dozen fires, most of which were a quarter-acre or smaller and several of which involved just one tree. The park's 13th lightning fire, which had blackened 15 acres north of Yellowstone Lake, was 95 percent contained by fire lines today, and 13 firefighters were at work, down from a peak of 82, said park spokeswoman Marsha Karle. The costs are high. The summer's biggest fire, spotted July 5 near Yellowstone River, was contained at 220 acres by 315 firefighters, and the bill is expected to be around $750,000, said park spokesman Marsha Karle. ``When we have a big one where we bring in overhead and we bring in outside crews, that's where it adds up real quick,'' she said. ``Any time you call in outside resources _ retardant drops, smokejumpers, helicopters, crews _ it adds to the cost. Firefighting is an expensive business.'' At the height of the 1988 blazes, public and political outrage prompted the Interior Department to go back to its pre-1972 policy of fighting all fires. The agency also mobilized a U.S. Forest Service-National Park Service team to analyze the ``let it burn'' policy. The team found the policy to be basically sound but asked for some refinements. Steve Frye, a park ranger, said the proposed revisions, if adopted, will leave little room for guesswork when rangers decide which backcountry fires to fight. Rangers would have to take into account recent rainfall, humidity, fuel moisture, wind speed, fuel types and the slope of the forest floor when deciding whether to fight fires, Frye said. These factors have been considered in the past, but there were no predetermined limits that they had to fall within, he said. It wasn't always so complicated. During the park's first 100 years, rangers battled every fire they could reach. Then in 1972, the National Park Service agreed to manage natural areas of Yellowstone as ``vignettes of primitive America'' and adopted the ``let it burn'' policy. From 1972 to 1987, the policy guided action over 235 fires that burned roughly 34,000 acres, according to park records. How soon the park's firefighters will be given leeway in deciding which fires to fight, and which to leave alone, is difficult to gauge, Frye said. ``Our fire management plan is in the regional forester's office for review at this point,'' he said. If an environmental assessment of the revisions is required, the plan may not take effect until next summer, Frye said. An environmental impact statement would require even more study, he said.

DOC.HEAD: La Raza Concerned Education Reform Leaves Out Hispanics
DOC.TEXT: Education reform efforts that have swept the country during the last 10 years may be leaving Hispanics behind, the head of a civil rights group said today. Raul Yzaguirre, director of the National Council of La Raza, said Hispanics remain the most undereducated segment of the U.S. population, despite being the fastest growing. ``The problem is getting worse rather than better,'' Yzaguirre told a news conference at the start of NCLR's three-day national conference. More than 4,000 Hispanic leaders from all over the country are attending. NCLR's statistical portrait of Hispanic education found, in some cases, the gap between Hispanics and non-Hispanics in test achievement scores was growing. Yzaguirre said the group is worried that education reform efforts are helping whites, but hurting minorities. He compared some education reforms to a track coach who raises the bar on the high jump and does nothing to train his athletes to leap higher. ``What that means is those who have had the training, the preparation, the nutrition will jump higher than those who have not,'' he said. ``That's exactly what we fear will happen to the Hispanic community.'' President Bush and Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos are scheduled to address the meeting later this week. Yzaguirre said the group does not expect Bush to announce any new policy initiative to cope with the problem. Hispanics, compared with blacks and whites, enter school later and leave it earlier. They are also less likely to complete high school, enter or complete college, the NCLR report said. Hispanics have more problems in school and have lower expectations, sometimes because teachers expect less from them, Yzaguirre said. ``We have to understand this problem as the system's failure, not a failure of children,'' Yzaguirre said. NCLR is a Washington-based non-profit advocacy group for the nation's 20 million Hispanic citizens. It has a field office in McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Editor's Daughter Gets Proposal in Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Ted Vagelos figured the proper way to pop the question to an editor's daughter was in print. So he decided to take out a quarter-page advertisement in Sunday's editions of The Knoxville News-Sentinel newspaper. ``Dear Tina, Will you marry me? Love, Ted,'' the $1,274 ad asked in big bold letters. The proposal surprised Tina Moskos and her father, Editor Harry Moskos, whose 28th wedding anniversary with his wife, Victoria Marie, happened to be Sunday. Ms. Moskos accepted. Vagelos, an American Telephone & Telegraph Co. consultant in Nashville, and Ms. Moskos, a Vanderbilt University nursing graduate student, will be married in Knoxville early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Gaggle of Geese, Ducks Take Daily Traffic-Stopping Walk
DOC.TEXT: Never mind that nonsense about why chickens cross the road. In this eastern Texas city two ducks and two geese cross the street every day to get from their hotel to a fountain. About 5 p.m., a manager from The Fredonia escorts the birds safely through traffic. The daily procession has quickly become a popular attraction for hotel guests. ``It's getting to where they'll wait in the lobby,'' said general manager Jim Boiles. ``They get the biggest bang out of it.'' Although motorists are sometimes stopped in their tracks, they don't seem to mind. Often, they wave at the waddling procession. The four birds came to the hotel as temporary guests, part of a petting zoo for the Easter season. The geese, Pate and Jimbo, and ducks, Snip and Snap, arrived when they were only a few days old. ``The customers really wanted us to keep them,'' said Cafe Fredonia manager and ``duck mom'' Donna Crabtree. She said it didn't take much to persuade Boiles to let the birds stay. They got a luxurious home next to the lobby. She's the one who trained the birds for their street-crossing routine. ``It's grown to be such a tradition,'' Ms. Crabtree said.

DOC.HEAD: From Red Stars to Red Lights in `Bangkok on the Danube'
DOC.TEXT: The change from communism to democracy has made sex a growth industry in Hungary. Red lights now glitter where red stars once shone brightly. Budapest kiosks feature at least a dozen sex magazines. A pornography shop joint venture with Austria opened downtown six months ago. In June, the city got its first peep show. A cab company ferries passengers exclusively to its massage salon. The explosion in Hungary's sex industry began after censorship laws were repealed last year as the nation moved from Communist rule to democracy. This paved the way for hardcore pornography, which remains unrestricted in the absence of any new press law. King of Budapest's new trade in bodily pleasures is Antal Laszlo Voeroes, a 37-year-old travel journalist turned nude photographer and now sex and porn entrepreneur. Sitting in a swing chair in his garden, barking explicit instructions to a photographer over a cordless phone, Voeroes explained how he struck it rich. Last summer, Voeroes launched ``Sexy Lady,'' a 24-page, explicitly pornographic magazine selling for 90 cents an issue. The initial print run of 60,000 has soared to 1 million copies a month. A follow-up, ``Sexy Man,'' was a flop. But two new publications with lewd English and German language titles, designed to boost foreign sales and give the allure of the west to Hungarians, are doing well, Voeroes said. He hopes to break into the new Yugoslav and Romanian markets this summer. Voeroes' starting capital of $16,700 came from profits on girlie calendars and what he calls a photo model school, where he says had trained some 1,400 girls by 1988. Taking that capital and $585,000 raised from non-banking sources he refuses to reveal, Voeroes established his present company, Intermozaik, in May 1989. Besides the lucrative magazines, the company also makes pornographic videos that are also sold in Austria and Poland, and is an agent for girls to Italian and West German movie makers, Voeroes said. Not everyone is happy with Voeroes' new-found freedom. Anti-porn campaigners have complained that Hungary is fast becoming the ``Thailand of central Europe.'' Roman Catholic church leaders, who are campaigning to get religion back into schools and restrict abortion, are pressing for restrictions on the growing sex industry. But after 45 years of censorhip under Communist rule not even leading anti-pornography campaigner Pal Becker, head of the Catholic Youth Movement, wants pornography banned. He has, however, argued that it should be restricted to the ``narrowest circles'' well outside the center of Budapest. Like a good capitalist, Voeroes is constantly reinvesting and expanding his sex empire. On June 15, his nudist cruise boat took its maiden voyage on Lake Balaton. Daytime trips, strictly for sunbathing, cost $8 and $5.50 for children. Evening sex cruises, advertised as ``live show, sex games, video and nudist disco,'' cost $50 or $108 with a sex massage thrown in. Business is so brisk that Voeroes plans to have a second boat cruising the lake, Hungary's most popular foreign tourist spot. In a country where the average wage is $135 a month, Voeroes doesn't seem to have difficulty finding masseuses who earn $25 a client, or a couple to perform live sex for double that amount. Parliament, which was democratically elected earlier this year, has not legalized prostitution, stalling Voeroes' plans for two brothels, 50 cabs driven by girls available for more than a ride, and buses cruising round Lake Balaton with five girls aboard. At Intermozaik headquarters, not everybody is as explicit as the magazines, calendars and posters surrounding them. Both secretaries answering phones that constantly ring with demands for pornography declined to give their names, and said their families don't know where they work. ``We take home a lot more than at our previous jobs,'' one said defensively. ``After all, filling out invoices for `Sexy Lady' is no different than filling out invoices for anything else.''

DOC.HEAD: State Leader Quits, Defusing National Political Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh won a power struggle with his deputy Monday, ending a crisis which had paralyzed his minority government for three days. Singh's victory came with the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal's son, Om Prakash Chautala, as head of the government of Haryana state, five days after he was reinstalled by his father. Chautala was forced to quit the post in May after 12 people died in repeated election violence in his constituency. Chautala's supporters were accused of inciting the troubles, but a promised inquiry into his role never began. Chautala's re-appointment Thursday, which prompted 13 ministers to resign in Singh's 38-member Cabinet, was seen as an effort by Devi Lal to promote his son's political career. ``The crisis has blown over,'' Somappa Rayappa Bommai, president of the Janata Dal Party, announced at a news conference late Monday. ``Chautala resigned at my request to improve the image of the government and the party. I congratulate him. He has risen to the occasion,'' Bommai said. The crisis began Friday when three Cabinet ministers resigned. Ten more ministers resigned after that, and on Saturday, Singh also offered to quit. The National Front rejected the offer. Top leaders of the alliance rallied behind Singh, forcing him to retract his resignation letter. Some commentators suggested the maneuver was meant to garner support in his fight with Devi Lal, the 75-year-old political patriarch of Haryana state. Several major newspapers had been demanding Chautala's ouster as a solution to the crisis. ``If you bow to Mr. Devi Lal today, you will have to crawl tomorrow,'' wrote the conservative Hindustan Times in an editorial. Singh led the front in ousting Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party in November's national elections, campaigning on a platform of a clean government. Neither party got a majority of the seats in Parliament, but the National Front formed the government on the strength of outside support by a right-wing Hindu fundamentalist party and left-wing parties.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Agrees Germany Free To Choose NATO Membership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 11th pvs, `West Germany ...' to UPDATE with State Department, NATO welcoming Gorbachev's move. Pickup 12th pvs, `Kohl and...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today removed his objection to a united Germany belonging to NATO, saying Germany was free to choose its allies. The Soviet objection had been a major obstacle to full German unification. Gorbachev spoke at a joint news conference with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in southern Russia that was broadcast live on Soviet and West German television. Kohl said West Germany wants to new unified state ``to be a member of NATO.'' He said he was sure the government of East Germany concurred. Gorbachev said that the four-power agreement of the victorious World War II allies that has governed Germany since the end of the war will cease when Germany is unified. `Unified Germany receives complete sovereignty,'' Gorbachev told the news conference. ``It has the right to use this sovereignty to make its choice, that is its internal choice, meaning its variant of social development, and meaning what it would like to be a part of, what blocs to support,'' he said. The two leaders spoke following a two-day vsiit by Kohl aimed at removing Soviet concerns over German unification. The news conference was held in Zhelosnovodsk, in southern Russia. Gorbachev said that no NATO forces must be stationed on the territory of what is now East Germany during a period of three to four years, when Soviet troops will be withdrawing. He said the Soviet Union hopes that after that period, no NATO forces or nuclear weapons would be stationed there. Previously, the Soviets had insisted on a neutral Germany, and recently had suggested a form of associate membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after an unspecified transition period. West Germany and its NATO allies had insisted that a united Germany be a part of the western alliance. In Washington, the State Department said Gorbachev's comments were ``most interesting and welcome.'' But it withheld further comment pending study of Gorbachev's remarks. NATO, in a statement from Brussels, also praised Gorbachev's acceptance of a unified Germany as member of the Western alliance. It said such membership ``will increase stability for all ... including the Soviet Union.'' Kohl and Gorbachev also announced agreement on several other issues, including the size of the future army of a united Germany and a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers from East Germany. Gorbachev said the two sides, in talks that started Sunday in Moscow and continued in Gorbachev's native Stavropol region, had managed to ease each other's concerns about the future of Soviet troops on the territory of what is now East Germany. Kohl said Soviet troops should be withdrawn from East German territory three to four years after Germany is united. The Soviets now have about 380,000 troops in East Germany. During the same period, the armed forces of a united Germany will be reduced to 370,000 men, Kohl said. The combined strength of the East and West German armed forces is now about 600,000, with West Germany providing 480,000 men. Kohl said the rights of the four World War II victorious powers will cease immediately after unification, but that their troops could stay in Berlin as long as the Soviet troops are in East Germany. He said a united Germany and the Soviet Union will sign a comprehensive treaty that will govern all aspects of their bilateral relations. The two leaders were in southern Russia after a visit Sunday to Gorbachev's home region, Stavropol. The Soviet leader said he thought the ``fresh air'' of the northern Caucasus mountains would help both leaders formulate their thoughts clearly, the Tass news agency reported. It was Kohl's second visit to the Soviet Union since February and Gorbachev's hospitality indicated the Soviets seek close ties with the economically powerful Germans. Tass said parallel talks were held Sunday between Foreign Ministers Eduard Shevardnadze and Hans Dietrich Genscher as well as Finance Ministers Valentin Pavlov and Theo Waigel. During Kohl's visit, the two leaders discussed how West German economic aid can help Gorbachev restructure _ and revive _ the ailing Soviet economy. The West German government has backed a $3.1 billion loan to support Gorbachev's efforts _ so far ineffectual _ to transform the Soviet Union's centralized economy to a market-oriented system. At last week's Houston summit of leading industrial democracies, Western leaders rejected a proposal strongly supported by West Germany and France for a $15 billion aid plan to shore up the Soviet economy and demonstrate Western support for Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor McDonnell Douglas Laying Off 11 Percent Of Work Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with quote from news conference, picking up 6th graf pvs, `The cuts...'. ADDS 1 graf on end with further quote. ADDS byline. Version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Aircraft maker McDonnell Douglas Corp. will cut 11 percent of its work force, or up to 17,000 jobs, by year's end under a plan to reduce costs by more than $700 million, the company said today. ``We tried to do everything else,'' John F. McDonnell, chairman and chief executive officer, told a news conference. ``But in the final analysis we had to come to this.'' The company, the nation's biggest defense contractor, has been struggling financially because of cutbacks in the defense industry and costly development problems in both military and commercial aircraft projects. The cost-cutting plan also includes reduced capital budgets, significant cuts in budgets for travel, consultants and advertising and restrictions on overtime. In a statement, McDonnell told employees he ``deeply regretted the pain and hardship these cuts will cause to thousands of people who have valued and dedicated employees.'' Job fairs, resume services and counseling would be offered to help laid-off workers find new jobs, McDonnell saidJ. The cuts had been expected for several weeks, since the company announced plans for significant layoffs in an effort to cut expenses and bolster its sagging financial performance. The company's stock was down $1.50 a share at $43.37{ in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange. McDonnell Douglas earned $2 million during its first quarter, down 98 percent from a year earlier. The drop stemmed mainly from huge losses at Douglas Aircraft, which primarily builds commercial jets. The layoffs will affect salaried and hourly jobs at all of McDonnell Douglas' companies and facilities. The news release said 4,500 jobs in St. Louis would be lost. About 9,000 jobs will be lost, including about 8,000 at the Douglas Aircraft Co. commercial airplane facility in Long Beach, Calif. An additional 1,000 jobs are being eliminated in 25 other states where the company has offices and manufacturing operations. McDonnell said he believed the company can make the cuts ``so that they will not jeopardize our technological capability or undermine our ability to deliver quality products on time.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Signals Continued Economic Expansion
DOC.TEXT: A rebound in business sales in May helped keep inventories growing at a moderate rate, the government said Monday in a report that analysts say signals continued economic expansion. The Commerce Department said inventories held on shelves and backlots totaled a seasonally adjusted $799.4 billion, up 0.4 percent after April's 0.3 percent gain. Business sales shot up a seasonally adjusted 0.9 percent in May, nearly recovering from a 1 percent drop a month earlier. It was the strongest increase since February, when sales rose 1.4 percent. The report, which was in line with economists' expectations, provided fresh evidence that the economy was not in danger of toppling immediately into a recession. ``There's no excessive inventory building, so economic growth can continue just fine,'' said economist John Silvia of Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. The combination of strong sales and a moderate increase in inventories produced a 1.48 ratio of inventories to sales, down slightly from 1.49 in April. The ratio means that it would take 1.48 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the May sales pace. ``Usually when the inventory-to-sales ratio ... gets high, businesses cut down on production and that tends to generate a recession,'' Silvia said. The ratio hit a peak of 1.7 in October 1982 during the last recession. Although inventories appear well-controlled overall, some analysts are worried that inventories rose more strongly on the retail and wholesale levels. The increase in inventories was greatest at wholesale establishments, up 1.2 percent. Retail backlogs rose 0.4 percent while inventories at factories were unchanged. ``Retail and wholesale ... (are) where a cycle of rising inventories would start and eventually work back to manufacturing. ... It seems to suggest the economy still has problems,'' said economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International. Manufacturers showed the biggest sales gain in May, 2 percent, while sales fell 0.6 percent at retail stores. Wholesalers reported a 0.6 percent increase. In an advance estimate, the Commerce Department said last week that retail sales rose 0.5 percent in June, the first increase in five months.

DOC.HEAD: US Providing Help for Quake-Stricken Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said today it is providing an Air Force transport plane to carry civilian rescue workers, dogs and support equipment to the Philippines to assist in the hunt for earthquake survivors. Meanwhile, the State Department said it was checking into unconfirmed reports that American government officials may have been killed or injured in the quake that rocked Manila and surrounding Luzon island today. Officials reported at least 44 people killed, most when a six-story college building north of Manila collapsed during the quake, registered at 7.7 on the Richter scale. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the department was looking into a report that an Agency for International Development conference was under way at a hotel in the badly damaged resort city of Baguio when the quake struck. An official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said there was an unconfirmed report that one American attending the conference in an official capacity was killed. Rene Bafalis, a spokeswoman for the AID office of disaster relief, said she had no information on the report. Boucher said a U.S. Embassy team would fly to Baguio Tuesday morning, Philippine time, to assist Americans. He said the U.S. ambassador in Manila, Nicholas Platt, had been in touch with President Corazon Aquino and had committed $25,000 from his emergency fund as a first step in disaster relief. Boucher said there were no reports of injuries to private American citizens in the Philippines. The Pentagon said it is providing an Air Force C-141 transport plane to carry 16 civilian search and rescue personnel, plus four dogs and support equipment to assist in the hunt for survivors. The rescue personnel are from Fairfax County, Va., and Dade County, Fla. The plane was scheduled to leave from Andrews Air Force Base, Md. later today.

DOC.HEAD: Bear Enthusiasts Just `Grin and Eat It'
DOC.TEXT: New members of the World Bear Eaters' Association may feel like growling after getting their first taste of the dark, greasy meat. ``But I tell them not to worry,'' said the Rev. Joseph Gluck, pastor emeritus and historian of the Forks-of-Cheat Baptist Church. ``After that passes, they'll feel stronger, more powerful, with a new zest for life.'' The church, founded in the mountain wilderness 215 years ago, marked its anniversary Sunday with a ``bear feast'' to honor the animal that helped keep early members alive. ``It wasn't easy for the settlers to bring cows, sheep and other domestic animals across the Allegheny Mountains,'' said Gluck. ``That's why the black bear became one of the great sources of meat for the people who founded our church.'' For the past 30 years, bear meat has been served ``as a sort of memorial'' at the picnics marking the anniversary of the church's founding on Nov. 5, 1775, Gluck said. The picnic is held in July to take advantage of summer weather. The hilltop church, which overlooks the Cheat and Monongahela rivers near the Pennsylvania line, depends on hunters to supply the meat. Gluck, 75, is also ``Bear Master'' at the church and initiates new members into the bear-eating club. ``I say some magic special Indian words, tap them on the head three times with the magic tooth taken from a West Virginia black bear and give them a certificate so they can prove to people they've actually eaten bear,'' Gluck said. ``Mostly, they just grin and eat it.'' About 1,500 people from two dozen states and several other countries are members, said Gluck. Lena Nicholson, 90, who has helped prepare the feast for decades, said cooking the hind quarters takes all day. The meat is divided into roasts and boiled in water three times before being covered with onion, apple and celery and roasted in the oven for several hours, she said. ``That bear meat is awful strong and greasy,'' said Nicholson. ``I have to open all the windows and the door, the smell gets pretty strong.'' When it's done, the meat tastes like a cross between beef and pork, she said. ``People seem to like it real well,'' said Nicholson. ``There's never any left and I've never had anyone complain yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Rock Band's Alleged `Subliminal' Lyrics Questioned in Suicide Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with trial under way. No pickup. CORRECTS date of shootings to Dec. 23, 1985, sted Dec. 27. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Two young men who shot themselves in 1985 were influenced by subliminal messages in a rock 'n' roll album produced in the interest of greed, an attorney charged today as a trial got under way. ``What this case is, is about making money,'' Vivian Lynch said in her opening statement in the case against the band Judas Priest and CBS Records. ``Excitement is what the defendants were selling,'' she said. ``Excitement is what the consumers were buying.'' The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages. Relatives of the victims claim hidden messages in the album ``Stained Class'' spurred the two men to form a suicide pact. The band members strongly deny any such messages exist. On the afternoon of Dec. 23, 1985, Raymond Belknap, 18, held a sawed-off shotgun to his chin and died instantly from a single blast. James Vance, 20, managed only to blow away the lower portion of his face. The two had been listening to the album repeatedly while drinking and smoking marijuana, their relatives said. Though he survived the shootings, Vance underwent repeated operations and eventually died three years later of complications from his injuries and a reaction to medication. Ms. Lynch, who represents Vance's family, told the court the audience targeted by the band was a ``stained class'' in itself that craved excitement and touted Satanism, sexual aggression, violence, suicide and death. ``This case is about mind control. In this case, what pushed the boys over the edge into eternity was the subliminal push.'' Lawyers for Judas Priest and CBS Records will argue it was the young men's troubled lives, including a history of drug and alcohol abuse, psychiatric disorders and physical abuse, that pushed them over the edge. They deny that the band promotes suicide or Satanism. Washoe District Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead is presiding over the non-jury trial. He already has denied a defense motion to dismiss the case on grounds the record was protected by the First Amendment. Whitehead said freedom of speech protections would not apply to subliminal messages. He said he was not convinced the hidden messages actually existed on the album, but left the argument to attorneys. The lawsuit is proceeding as a products liability case, with the band and record company accused of negligence and intentional and reckless misconduct. In one of the album's songs, ``Beyond the Realms of Death,'' the band sings: ``Yeah, I have left the world behind. I am safe now in my mind. I'm free to speak with my own mind. This is my life, this is my life, and I'll decide, not you.'' But the trial will focus not on what the lyrics may have suggested, but whether there was a second, all-but-inaudible set of lyrics in the background. ``I don't believe that we'd have had the support and following that we've had for the past 17 years had we deliberately attempted to contrive to create songs where people did harm to themselves,'' lead singer Robert Halford said in a 1988 deposition. Attorneys for the families said the young men's troubled lives made them ``susceptible, influenced and vulnerable to the ideas, suggestions and emotions'' allegedly hidden in the music. More than 100 witnesses are expected to testify during the trial likely to last four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Seeks College-Bound Sailors for a Two-Year Hitch
DOC.TEXT: The Navy says college-bound young people will benefit from a new, two-year enlistment program designed to fill some of the service's toughest jobs. About 600 men and women have signed on for the program, which began last month. It is geared toward attracting ``the college-bound kid'' interested in earning benefits for higher education and seeing the world before starting school, Vice Adm. Jeremy Boorda, the chief of naval personnel, said in a recent interview. The lure is the Montgomery GI Bill, under which participants can receive a $250 monthly stipend over three years of college. While sailors can leave the service after two years of active duty under the program, they must stay serve an additional six years with the non-drilling naval reserve. The program was created in response to congressional calls for military spending cuts and leaner armed forces. ``We're looking for high school graduates,'' Boorda said. ``We're looking for quality people, but also people who may not want to make the Navy a career.'' Instead of attracting young men and women for a normal four- or six-year enlistment with the promise of high-tech training, the new program enlists sailors for ``general detail,'' the deck and engineering assignments that are often dirty, labor-intensive and hard to fill. ``These are tough jobs,'' Boorda said. He envisions bringing 2,000 such sailors into the service this year, 14,000 over the next year. Now, 580,000 men and women serve in the Navy. The program should help the service in coming years, when Pentagon spending is expected to decline and the military's active-duty roster of 2.1 million is expected to shrink. ``I have to figure a way to bring the Navy down in size without hurting readiness or hurting those people who want to stay,'' Boorda said. ``We know we are going to get smaller.'' Boorda said the move is only part of a ``bigger reduction strategy'' that means the Navy will have to look at cutting enlistments, enforcing retirements and, as a last resort, involuntary separations. The two-year recruits will be finishing their duty ``exactly when we need to get smaller,'' Boorda said. ``I'm not looking for large numbers to stay.'' The program also helps boost the numbers of trained sailors in the reserves, a force that will need to grow in light of the changes in the world environment and the lessened Soviet threat. Defense experts on Capitol Hill, such as Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., have called for cutting active duty personnel back by 100,000 in the next fiscal year. Nunn also has backed proposals to put more emphasis on reserve and national guard forces, which can be called up if national security is threatened. That's a much cheaper option than paying for large numbers of active-duty personnel. The two-year enlistment program comes at the right time, according to Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., a specialist on military personnel issues. ``It's a good approach when you need to fine tune'' the nation's forces, said McCain, the ranking Republican on the Senate committee's manpower subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Police Chief Says Ceausescu's Son Opposed Parents
DOC.TEXT: The former secret police chief testified Monday that Nicu Ceausescu, accused of ordering the massacre of 89 civilians during the revolution that toppled his father, often opposed his parents' policies. Gen. Col. Iulian Vlad, who headed deposed-dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's Securitate secret police, also said that during the revolution there were no special security measures taken in Sibiu, the town where Nicu was party boss. The 40-year-old youngest son of Ceausescu was arrested Dec. 22 while he was driving into Bucharest from Sibiu, 155 miles northwest of the capital. Vlad testified that there were ``several occasions'' during which Nicu was the only member of the state leadership to openly oppose his parents' policies. ``His opposition to their political policies intensified when he became first party secretary in Sibiu,'' he added. According to the indictment, Nicu ordered troops to ``shoot without warning'' at protesters during the revolution that toppled his father. The indictment says 89 people were killed in Sibiu as the result of those orders. Nicu was party boss in the southern Transylvanian town, from 1987 until his arrest. The trial is held at the Trade Union Culture Center in Sibiu. Vlad said ``no special arms or ammunition'' were sent to Sibiu during the revolution. ``Although the rest of the country was in a special state, no such measures were taken in Sibiu,'' he said. He added, however, that after the Dec. 16 massacre in the western city of Timisoara that sparked the revolution, Nicu agreed to special security measures for himself for the first time. Vlad said Nicu had ``a distaste'' for Securitate personnel ``including many in its leadership.'' Nicu, who had a reputation for reckless drinking and the abuse of women, was widely considered the most-hated Ceausescu after his parents Nicolae and Elena. Surprisingly, people in Sibiu seem sympathetic to his plight. According to unofficial sources, the trial, which began in late May, will continue until Wednesday. Fourteen witnesses, including a former girlfriend of Nicu's, will be called to testify, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Nicu, who is recovering from a stab wound and reportedly suffering from cirrhosis of the liver, was dressed in a gray jacket and gray corduroy slacks. He wore tinted glasses. Ana Muresean, Commerce Minister under Ceausescu, also testified Monday and reversed her original testimony that Nicu arrived in Bucharest to take over after his parents' overthrow. She said the testimony had been ``forced'' out of her by the prosecution during pre-trial interrogation. She also said there was ``great dissension'' between Nicu and his parents. After Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted in December, the dictator and his wife were shot by a firing squad on Christmas Day.

DOC.HEAD: White House May Ask Outside Experts to Review NASA Program
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, chairman of the National Space Council, asked NASA today to establish an outside task force to consider the long-term direction of America's space program. Quayle discussed the request in an hour-long meeting with NASA Administrator Richard H. Truly. Reports circulated over the weekend that the White House was considering restructuring the agency in the wake of its recent setbacks, the grounding of the space shuttle fleet and a flaw in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope that prevents it from being focused perfectly. The vice president said in a three-paragraph statement that ``contrary to some published reports, there is no White House investigation of NASA.'' The statement said Quayle had asked Truly ``to put together an outside task force that will consider the future long-term direction of the space program.'' It said the NASA chief and the task force will report to the vice president. There was nothing in the statement about shaking up the agency. NASA sources said Quayle privately had expressed confidence in Truly's leadership. ``Space continues to be a top priority for this administration,'' the Quayle statement said. ``We all want the best ideas on how we can move into the next century maintaining our leadership in space.'' Quayle, Truly and White House chief of staff John Sununu talked with several NASA critics in a meeting aboard Air Force Two on the flight home Wednesday from the economic summit in Houston. Participants included former astronaut Eugene Cernan, former NASA Administrator Thomas Paine, Cal Tech scientist Bruce Murray and Hans Mark, chancellor of the University of Texas system. The White House may enlist a team of space experts from outside government to aid in reviewing NASA, said the official, who spoke Sunday on condition of anonymity. The administration source said Quayle and Truly are leading the internal effort to find ways to get the space program back on track. Space News, a weekly industry newspaper, said in today's edition that the restructuring ``stems from concern that a lack of public support for space and federal budget pressures make it difficult for NASA to carry out its missions'' and that the White House is concerned the problems are institutional, rather than technical. The decision has not yet been made to convene a blue-ribbon panel of experts, the source said, but ``if something is done, it will be done with a combination of outside and inside advice.'' CBS News reported Saturday that the administration likely will name a panel of outside experts this week. Until its recent problems, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration seemed to be recovering from criticisms following the 1986 Challenger explosion that killed seven astronauts. The shuttle fleet was grounded after hydrogen leaks were discovered on space shuttles Columbia and Atlantis, but engineers have located the leaks and officials say they are easy to fix. Also, NASA revealed that the $1.5 billion Hubble _ launched April 25 _ has a focusing flaw that has sharply reduced its usefulness. The agency blamed the problem on a defect in one of the telescope's two mirrors. In addition to Quayle and Truly, the National Space Council includes Sununu, budget Director Richard Darman, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and other officials.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Spanish soprano Montserrat Caballe was slightly injured early Monday when a row of VIP seats collapsed while she was watching a ballet, throwing her and other audience members to the ground. The temporary seats gave way just as Caballe, Spanish tenor Jose Carreras and the rest of the audience at Merida's Roman amphitheater began applauding a production of Mstislav Rostropovich's ``Romeo and Juliet,'' conducted by the composer. Caballe and Carreras opened the Merida Festival on Saturday, singing in the Jules Massenet opera ``Herodiade.'' Caballe fell more than 5 feet to the ground but walked away. She suffered minor injuries to her wrist and leg, a regional government spokesman said. Carreras, who was sitting in the same section, said he managed to avoid falling.

Teen-age star Danny Ponce of CBS's ``The Hogan Family'' sums up his relationship with his mother this way: ``Once the money started to come in, it (messed) everything up,'' according to TV guide. The magazine, for its July 21 edition, interviewed Ponce and some others who achieved fame and fortune before they reached voting age. Ponce, 17, recently bought his own four-bedroom house with a swimming pool. ``I don't live with my mother anymore, but we still talk,'' Ponce said. ``I see her once in a while.'' His mother, Dianne Ponce, claims Danny was using much of his $400,000-a-year salary on drugs that he obtained from a cast member. ``None of it is true,'' Danny said. ``No one on the set would give me drugs.'' Bonnie Gold, whose daughter Tracey is on ABC's ``Growing Pains,'' suggested: ``Before any kid gets on a series, I think the parents should be interviewed and analyzed because that is where the problem lies.'' David Faustino, 16, of Fox's ``Married...With Children,'' said that now that he's on a series, girls and drugs have been offered to him but he is aware of the dangers of living too high. ``Every time there is an article about a Hollywood kid who has shot himself or done drugs or ended up in jail, my parents clip it out and paste it somewhere in my bedroom,'' Faustino said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Romanian gymnastics star Nadia Comaneci arrived Monday to tour Olympic sites and for talks on her modeling in South Korea. Comaneci, the 1976 Olympic gold medalist in Montreal, fled from Romania last December and sought refuge in the United States. She was scheduled to visit Sports Minister Chung Dong-sung. Korean fashion promoters have been interested in her modeling.

Chung Myung-whun, conductor of France's National Paris Bastille Opera and Orchestra, returned home to perform Monday. He said that while he stumbles in speaking Korean and French, music is universal. Chung will conduct the Bastille Orchestra in five performances in Seoul July 18-21. The orchestra also will perform in Japan, Germany and Spain in 1990. The Korean-born Chung, who grew up in the United States, took over as head of the orchestra last year. ``When I held my first press conference in Paris, I couldn't speak French ... only a few words and phrases,'' Chung told reporters. To the amusement of the mostly Korean reporters, he also apologized for his Korean language skills, somewhat forgotten during his youth. ``My level of Korean is considerably worse than English,'' he said in Korean. ``But as long as I can express feelings to music, that's all I care about,'' he said. ``Music is not owned by a particular country. It's shared by all people in the world. It doesn't matter if you're Korean or Japanese, or someone else.''

Haley's Comets, today's version of the 1950s band Bill Haley and the Comets that includes original bass player Al Rex, will kick off Guitar Gala II. ``Rock Around the Clock'' propelled Haley and the Comets to the top of the pop charts in 1955, and Guitar Gala organizers hope the rock 'n' roll classic will put them in the record books. Up to 1,000 musicians are expected here Thursday in an attempt to break the world's record for the most guitarists playing one song together for the longest time. Last year, 465 guitarists showed up at the Peach Festival and played ``Louie, Louie'' together for 30 minutes. That record fell in April, when 532 guitarists picked out ``Shake, Rattle and Roll'' for 43 minutes in Santa Cruz, Calif. ``We felt like we wanted to do what we could to get the record back to the East Coast and to South Carolina,'' said Cecil Ringer, coordinator of this year's event.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes Gorbachev Statement on United Germany and NATO
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today welcomed Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's willingness to accept a united Germany as a member of NATO. ``This comment demonstrates statesmanship and strengthens efforts to build enduring relationships based on cooperation,'' Bush said in a written statement. Bush added, ``We think this solution is in the best interests of all the countries of Europe, including the Soviet Union.'' The president's statement was issued after Gorbachev said that Germany was free to choose its own allies. ``Unified Germany receives complete sovereignty,'' Gorbachev said, standing alongside West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl at a news conference in southern Russia. ``It has the right to use this sovereignty to make its choice, that is its internal choice, meaning its variant of social development, and meaning what it would like to be a part of, what blocs to support,'' Gorbachev said. Kohl said West Germany wants a new unified state ``to be a member of NATO.'' He said he was sure the government of East Germany concurred. In his statement, Bush said that Gorbachev's position ``can be seen as a response, perhaps in part, to the outcome of the NATO summit in London where the alliance displayed its readiness to adapt to the new realities in Europe and reach out to former adversaries in the East.'' NATO agreed to reduce nuclear and conventional weapons and proposed a non-aggression declaration between the alliance and the states of the Warsaw Pact. It also declared that nuclear arms would be used only as a last resort. West Germany and its NATO allies have steadfastly insisted that a united Germany be a part of the Western alliance. In Washington, the State Department said Gorbachev's comments were ``most interesting and welcome.'' But it withheld further comment pending study of Gorbachev's remarks. NATO, in a statement from Brussels, also praised Gorbachev's acceptance of a unified Germany as member of the Western alliance. It said such membership ``will increase stability for all ... including the Soviet Union.''

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Soviet View of Unified Germany
With AM-Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at how the Soviet Union's view of a united Germany's military allegiance has changed since fall:

Nov. 15: Shortly after the Berlin Wall is opened and in the middle of East Germany's political turmoil, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says unification ``is not a matter of topical politics,'' and to even discuss it is to interfere in Germans' internal affairs. Feb. 10: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl visits Moscow. Afterward, he says he has received assurances from Gorbachev that the Soviet Union will respect the German people's wish to live as one nation. Feb. 14: Meeting in Ottawa, the United States and its major European allies reach agreement on a two-stage formula for unification. March 6: Gorbachev says a united Germany's membership in NATO is ``absolutely out of the question.'' The Soviet Union seeks a neutral Germany. April 6: After three days of talks between Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and U.S. officials in Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III says the Soviet Union is dropping its demand that Germany be neutral, but still opposes NATO membership. April 29: East Germany's prime minister, Lothar de Maziere, meets with Gorbachev and says Gorbachev still opposes NATO membership for a united Germany. June 6: Shevardnadze and Baker meet in Copenhagen to discuss a nine-point U.S. plan to meet Soviet security concerns about a united Germany. Shevardnadze says the Soviet Union cannot agree to all parts of it. June 12: Gorbachev says the Soviet Union might accept an undefined associate membership in NATO for a united Germany, if NATO is transformed from its Cold War stance against the Soviet Union. West Germany and its allies reject the idea. Monday: Gorbachev and Kohl announce that a united Germany may choose whatever alliance to which it wants to belong, clearing the way for NATO membership.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans Break into Czechoslovak Embassy, Take Diplomats Hostage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE to with Cubans breaking into Czechoslovak Embassy, taking diplomats hostage. Pickup 2nd pvs, `About 30...'
DOC.TEXT: Seven Cubans broke into the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana today and took four diplomats hostage, the state CTK news agency reported. The Mexican government news agency Notimex, in a report from Havana, said the seven demanded a plane to take them to the United States. The incident came after five Cubans seeking asylum occupied the apartment of the charge d'affaires Friday and held him hostage for a few hours. Charge d'affaires Jan Doemoek was among the diplomats CTK said were being held hostage. According to the report, the seven Cubans broke into the embassy building this morning and took the diplomats hostage as they were holding a meeting. It said the Cuban citizens were acting ``very violently,'' but that it was not clear whether they were armed. The news agency said no one was hurt. It said that the diplomats held hostage included, in addition to Doemoek, a commercial counsellor, a press secretary and a foreign ministry official who had come to Havana to help negotiate a solution for the 12 Cubans who have sought refuge in the embassy over the past week. Czechoslovak state television quoted foreign ministry spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky as saying that a deputy foreign minister would leave for Havana immediately because ``it is necessary to protect the safety of Czechoslovak citizens.'' The brief CTK report did not give the demands of the seven Cubans. The Mexican news agency quoted unidentified journalistic sources in saying the seven Cubans demanded a plane to the United States. It said the hostage-taking followed an argument between two groups of Cubans seeking to leave their Communist homeland. Twelve Cubans remain at the embassy, Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry officials said. Two students, identified as Igor Campana Dada and Alejandro Rosendo Lugo, decided to leave Friday. The first Cubans gained access to the compound July 9. Dependents of some Czechoslovak diplomats have left Havana. About 30 Czechoslovaks left Sunday on a regular airliner, the daily Lidova Demokracie reported. Among them were 12 or 13 wives and children of Czechoslovak diplomats, Foreign Ministry official Jindrich Opava said. Ten more were dependants of diplomats whose tours had ended, Opava said. The rest were tourists. ``It was not an evacuation, they left at their own request,'' Opava said of the departure of the diplomats' relatives. Five Cubans, meanwhile, were still holed up today at the abandoned apartment of the Czechoslovak charge d'affaires, Jan Doemoek, officials said. Doemoek fled his home July 12, after the five forced their way in. Doemoek's apartment is not in the embassy compound. Cuban President Fidel Castro, in his first official statement on the affair, called the Cubans ``antisocial elements encouraged by Czechoslovak diplomats,'' Lidova Demokracie said. He also was quoted as saying that Cuba has no agreement on diplomatic asylum with European countries, and the embassies of these countries have no right to grant the asylum. ``Czechoslovak diplomats in Havana try to interpret the situation in a way that indicates that Cuban government should solve the situation ... the affair should be solved by the Czechoslovak side,'' the daily quoted Castro as saying. The influx of asylum-seekers has heightened tensions between Cuba and Czechoslovakia, close allies before last fall's democratic upheaval toppled Prague's hard-line Communist leaders. Castro has resisted the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, sticking to his orthodox Marxist policies. Three Cuban asylum-seekers have also taken refuge in the Spanish Embassy in Havana. And on Sunday, the Foreign Ministry in Madrid said Cuban police violated the embassy by chasing a fourth asylum-seeker into the compound and hauling him away.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Homeless Activist Shot, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0526,0377
DOC.HEAD: Seattle Homeless Activist and Civic Gadfly Shot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT victim's age to 50 sted 60. SUBS 4th graf to update condition.
DOC.TEXT: One of Seattle's leading advocates for the homeless remained in critical but stable condition today after being shot by a man he was trying to evict from his homeless shelter, police said. Robert Willmott, 50, a civic gadfly who ran unsuccessfully for mayor last year, was shot in the neck and chest in the confrontation late Saturday, authorities said. Police said they questioned and released a man who told them he fired in self-defense after Willmott pointed a rifle at him. Police later said Willmott's weapon was not loaded. In surgery at Harborview Medical Center, a .22-caliber bullet was removed from Willmott's back but a second remained lodged in his neck, hospital officials said. Though still in critical condition this morning, Willmott had partially regained consciousness, said hospital spokeswoman Janet Skeels. Officers sent to the scene of the shooting at Willmott's shelter, Strand Helpers, took a 36-year-old man into custody, said police spokeswoman Tina Drain. She said the man told officers Willmott had threatened him with a pistol for reasons unknown, then later burst into his family's room with a rifle. The man grabbed his own weapon and fired, Drain said. Detective Jay Mooney later confirmed that Willmott's weapon was unloaded. There were no witnesses except the tenant's family, and evidence at the scene corroborated what he said, so police released the man pending further investigation, Drain said. Larry Branigan, who operates the Strand Helpers office during the day, said the man questioned by police had been causing trouble almost from the time he arrived with his wife and children on June 8. The man often made suggestive remarks to women residents and threatened men, he said. ``Will (Willmott) finally said enough was enough and told the guy he'd have to leave,'' Branigan said. A Strand Helpers brochure says the group has relied on donations and volunteer work without drawing from federal, state or local agencies to serve more than 1.3 million meals and provide 280,000 free nights of housing since it was founded in 1962.

DOC.HEAD: Living on the Edge in a City Under Siege
DOC.TEXT: Children forage among mangroves for weeds to fill the dinner pot, and two women scoop water into buckets, their eyes averted from the headless corpse polluting the swamp. The beachside scene near the clifftop British, French and U.S. Embassies has become commonplace in Monrovia, a capital at the mercy of lawless troops and rebels bent on vengeance. After nearly a month under rebel siege, food, water and fuel are running out, epidemics threaten, and bodies litter the capital, turning up on beaches, in creeks and on streets. One hundred corpses are rotting in the morgue of the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital. Every night after curfew, people go to bed to the sound of gunfire from soldiers frightening witnesses away from their looting. They often wake up to the sound of cannons and rockets. Monrovians wait for the rebels to break through, expecting either a blood bath or redemption, depending on their tribe. About a quarter of this West African nation's 2 million people lived in Monrovia before the fighting led to an exodus. At the only working hospital, an emergency field station has been set up by Belgium's Doctors without Borders, a boy of about 10 is treated for a bullet wound to the hand, flinching but never crying. He explains that his father sent him with $5 to the grocery store that had opened for the first time in more than week. A soldier stopped him, and demanded the money clutched in his fist. When he refused, the soldier shot his hand, snatched the money and sauntered off to a beer stall, he said. Doctors at the hospital, staffed by Liberians, Belgians and nuns from hospitals no longer operating, said his hand would be saved. Others are less lucky. ``I have been in war situations before and never has it been as it is in Monrovia, never before,'' said Reginald Moreels, a war surgeon and president of the Belgian chapter of Doctors without Borders. ``The people who are shooting are totally undisciplined, totally uncontrolled,'' he said. Western defense attaches said the gunshot wounds are particularly bad because the soldiers and rebels often fire their rifles at point-blank range. But no one at the Roman Catholic St. Joseph's Hospital, in Sinkor suburb, asks patients whether they are soldiers, rebels or civilians. The only rule, on a sign outside, is: ``ABSOLUTELY NO WEAPONS ALLOWED.'' All uniforms are burned at the hospital, to protect patients on both sides from being victimized. A Liberian relief worker got a shock when a bullet exploded in the pocket of a uniform he was burning. The American Embassy sends water tankers escorted by Marines to collect water from a creek near Presdient Samuel Doe's fortified mansion. Few others go near the creek for fear of soldiers. Others go to the polluted swamp near the U.S. and British Embassies, where the headless body rots. Another solution is to collect rainwater. A coconut grove near the bridge at the end of Randall Street is a dumping ground for bodies flung into trenches dug by bulldozers. Dr. Robert Kpoto, Liberia's chief medical officer, is concerned about water-borne diseases like cholera and typhoid. Risking rebel gunfire, a motley fleet of aircraft ranging from a Soviet-made Antonov transport to Cessna executive planes has ferried thousands of people out of Monrovia from an airstrip three miles from the city center. The price of an air ticket to Freetown, capital of neighboring Sierra Leone, has quintupled to $500 in six weeks. At least one plane already has several bullet holes. Peace talks are under way in Freetown, but they have been inconclusive. Meanwhile, the rebels continue their siege of Monrovia. The rebel National Patriotic Front has accused Doe of corruption, nepotism and human rights abuses. They want him to resign and stand trial. There is also a strong tribal aspect to the war. The rebels are apparently mostly members of the Gio and Mano tribes. Doe, a Krahn, has strong backing from his own tribe and the Mandingo. Human rights groups have accused both sides of slaughtering hundreds of civilians. Liberia was founded by the descendants of freed American slaves in 1847. They dominated the native peoples until Doe, an army master sergeant, seized power in April 1980. He had most of the ousted Cabinet ministers shot on the beach.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Killed, 50 Wounded in Intra-Shiite Battles
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem fighters on Monday attacked a stronghold of their Syrian-backed rivals in the rugged hills of southern Lebanon, touching off clashes in which at least 12 people were killed. Police also said 50 people were wounded in the daylong battles. Police said militiamen of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, launched an attack on the village of Jarjou, held by the more secular Amal militia, behind a tank, artillery and rocket barrage. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting intermittently for three years for dominance of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Monday's casualties raised the overall casualty toll to 1,061 killed and 3,201 wounded since mid-1986. Police said six Amal militiamen, four Hezbollah fighters and two civilians were killed. The wounded included 38 combatants, 31 of them from Amal, and the rest were civilians, police reported. Amal's leadership said in a statement that its fighters ``crushed the attackers who belonged to the Party of Satan'' in a five-hour battle. It said 25 of their men were wounded. Police said the fighting continued despite Amal's claim it had beaten off the Hezbollah assault. Heavy artillery exchanges raged through the afternoon. At times, 15 shells a minute were exploding in the battle zone, police said. Hezbollah earlier accused Amal of shelling its positions in the villages of Jabal Safi, Mlita and Luweizeh with artillery and rockets. It said in a statement that four Hezbollahis were killed and seven wounded. Columns of black smoke billowed from the hilly region as ambulances darted in and out of the battle zone carrying casualties to hospitals in south Lebanon. Also in southern Lebanon, fighters of the Sunni Moslem Nasserite Popular Organization fought a two-hour gunbattle with militiamen of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army around Kfar Falous, east of the provincial capital of Sidon. Both sides used rockets and artillery. Police said two people were wounded before the clashes died down around 1 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 53 Killed In Major Quake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with death count rising to 53. Pickup 4th pvs, `The U.S. ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MLA2,3, LaserColor MLA6
DOC.TEXT: A major earthquake rocked Manila and surrounding Luzon island today and officials reported at least 53 people killed and scores of buildings destroyed. Scores of people were believed trapped under the rubble of crumbled buildings, including 150 reportedly trapped in the Hyatt Hotel in the mountain resort of Baguio. Rescue efforts were hampered by poor communications and lack of equipment. Different government agencies maintained their own casualty counts, and some put the death toll at nearly 70. Hundreds were injured. The U.S. Geological Survey in Golden, Colo. registered the quake at 7.7 on the Richter scale. The June 21 earthquake in Iran registered between 7.3 and 7.7 and killed at least 40,000 people. There were scores of aftershocks. The Office of Civil Defense said the Philippine Christian College collapsed in the provincial capital of Cabanatuan City. The city of more than 80,000 is 60 miles north of Manila and was near the epicenter. The office said at least 34 people were killed in the city and outlying area, but earlier reports from the office had said 41 were killed in Cabanatuan. Officials in Cabanatuan said hundreds of students were unaccounted for, but it was uncertain how many were in the building when it collapsed. In Baguio, 110 miles to the north, portions of several luxury hotels collapsed. The Manila radio station DZRH said 150 people were trapped in the Hyatt Hotel. A woman who identified herself as a public relations officer of the hotel said most of those trapped were in the casino. She did not give her name. Officials in Baguio appealed for heavy equipment and for blood which they said was in short supply. U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said medical supplies had been sent to Baguio by helicopter. Air Force Master Sgt. Dan Fuller, reached by telephone at the U.S.-run Camp John Hay in Baguio, said the city was without electricity and that damage was widespread. ``We're without power,'' he said. ``We've had structural damage here on base. We do have seven buildings down downtown which as far as we know they are compeletely fallen in.'' He said U.S. personnel assisted in rescue efforts. The Red Cross reported five dead in Baguio but feared the toll could go much higher. The Red Cross reported four dead in the northern province of Pangasinan. One person died of injuries in Manila, where the temblor cracked buildings, knocked out electricity and communications and sent thousands fleeing into the streets. A radio station in Dagupan, 100 miles north of Manila, said 13 people were killed there, but the report could not be confirmed. It said all died in stampedes as panic-stricken people tried to flee a movie theater and schools. The quake struck at about 4:30 p.m. In Manila, numerous buildings were damaged and one fire broke out in the city's Santa Cruz district. The Institute of Seismology and Vulcanology, said the tremblor was centered just south of Cabanatuan, capital of Nueva Ecija province. The temblor knocked several radio stations temporarily off the air. Stop lights in Manila were knocked out of service, creating huge traffic jams. Officials reported widespread damage throughout Luzon, where many towns and cities were without power. Radio station DZRH quoted an affiliate station as saying a church in the northern province of Ilocos Sur collapsed. President Corazon Aquino ordered the military to launch an islandwide rescue operation. Her spokesman, Adolf Azcuna, said the president was meeting senators in her office when the quake struck and took cover under a table. Reynaldo Punongbayan, director of the Philippine Institute of Seismology and Vulcanology, said the quake measured 7 on the Richter scale in Manila. Officials said it was the capital's strongest quake since 1968. A quake measured at 7.8 struck the Philippines in 1976, killing 8,000 people. Most of them died in a tidal wave which struck the southern island of Mindanao. Manila radio stations reported cracks in the walls of many buildings, including the downtown ticket office of Philippine Airlines and The Manila Hotel, a luxury hotel on Manila Bay from which hundreds of guests were evacuated into the streets. In the capital, office workers rushed into the streets in panic. Several were seen praying or making signs of the cross. The Richter scale measures the magnitude of a quake according to ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one digit represents a tenfold increase of magnitude. A quake of magnitude 7 is capable of widespread, heavy damage. The quake that struck Iran on June 21, which was measured at between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale, killed 40,000 people, injured another 60,000 and left half a million homeless.

DOC.HEAD: East German Church To Get Help With Missing Treasures
DOC.TEXT: An East German church is getting help from West Germany to retrieve art treasures believed pilfered by an American soldier at the close of World War II, a West German official said Monday. East and West Germany also agreed to build an information database aimed at the return of other art works that vanished when the Third Reich fell. Litigation to retrieve the so-called Quedlinburg treasures from bank vaults in Texas is already under way. The Foreign Ministry said Monday that West Germany would pay the legal costs. Bonn's help in meeting the expense will be a major boost for the Lutheran Church of Quedlinburg, which claims its treasures were stolen at the end of World War II, said Klaus Maurice, director of the West German Cultural Foundation of the States. ``Nobody knew until now who had to pay, but they will pay and this is marvelous,'' Maurice said. The Quedlinburg treasures include two rare medieval manuscripts, a jeweled, ivory-carved container for relics and several rock-crystal and ivory objects. They were allegedly removed from a mine shaft where they had been hidden in the final days of the war. Maurice said there was no doubt the art works in question were authentic. The Quedlinburg treasures, among Germany's most famous art works, were allegedly taken by a U.S. army officer stationed in Quedlinburg, now East Germany, in 1945, and brought to his hometown of Whitewright, Texas. The church is suing the sister and brother of the officer, the late Joe T. Meador, to recover the treasures. Maurice said officials have no clear idea of how many other works were allegedly looted from Germany's artitistic heritage in the final months of the war. ``The problem up to now is that we had two states and it wasn't easy to speak with East Germany,'' Maurice said. ``Now, this is easier.'' Maurice spoke after attending a two-hour meeting to dicuss coordinated approaches toward retrieving lost German art. Also attending the meeting was a Ministry of Culture representative from East Germany, which is expected to formally unite with its Western neighbor in December. The new database is to be established in Berlin and collect information from museums, churches and other institutions throughout the two Germanys, Maurice said. The database will compare pre-World War II inventories with current records in an attempt to get a complete picture of what is missing, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Iranian Newspaper Accuses Western Reporters of Spying
DOC.TEXT: A radical Iranian newspaper Monday said many western reporters sent to cover events in Iran were spies and warned the government to beware. The Persian-language Jomhuri Islami, which reflects the views of government hard-liners, said many western journalists visited Iran ``to fulfill their missions assigned by the Zionists and western spying agencies.'' The article, which was obtained by The Associated Press in Cyprus, blamed officials of the Ministry of Islamic Guidance, which is in charge of regulating the activities of foreign reporters, for giving reporters too much freedom on their trips to Iran. Journalists who visit Iran are assigned agents from the ministry who accompany them on all trips outside their hotels. Reporters are also required to submit their film and tapes to ministry officials for approval. ``It is simplicity if we think that the CIA, the (Israeli) Mossad and other intelligence services simply use one device to obtain information from Iran. ``In addition to their set formula, they send reporters, photographers and and cameramen as a cover-up,'' the newspaper alleged. The Iranian government allows few western news organizations to base representatives in Iran and reporters are only to visit the country only on special occassions. Recently, reporters were allowed in to cover the first anniversary of the death of Iran's spiritual leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and the June earthquake that left about 40,000 dead. On such visits, the paper alleged, many reporters ``take full advantage to carry out their mission and take interesting gifts to their masters and receive handsome rewards.'' To support its claim, the newspaper said an American television crew that visited Iran in June to cover the anniversary of Khomeini's death had four members, none of whom had majored in journalism. ``When the United States has tens of colleges and schools for the training of mass media men, they don't need other people to be used in the media field,'' the article said. In a section of the article subtitled ``sample of mischiefs,'' the paper said the American crew took a picture of an unfinished building which was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Iran at the international court in the Hague. The article said the television team had ``full knowledge about the geographical situation of Tehran and its streets,'' and that it attempted to visit a public park and the main shopping center in central Tehran. The paper took umbrage at an alleged remark by the American reporter, claiming that the shopping district was full of Michael Jackson fans and that he intended to interview them. The article accused a reporter from another major American television network of compiling a full list of leaders of fundamentalist Moslem, pro-Iranian Lebanese and Palestinian groups invited to Tehran to participate in the first anniversary ceremonies. The full list of the guests was, however, also reported by the state-run radio and television and all major newspapers. The paper gave the following as other examples of ``non-journalistic activities'': _A reporter from a major British televsion network tried to take an unauthorized photograph of a refinery. _Another British radio journalist visited downtown Tehran and tried to compile a report of illegal, black market sales of hard currency. _A Danish reporter tried to compile ``a negative report of the economy,'' and accused him of attempting to photograph a woman at the weekly Friday prayers, dressed in ``western clothes.'' The newspaper also accused Western reporters of ``mischiefs'' in reporting on the quake which killed some 40,000. It said they used their visits to collect information on the condition of women, the economy, politics and the military. The newspaper also accused reporters of counting the number of Iranian helicopters involved in relief operations. Jomhuri Islami said the guidance ministry should offer facilities only ``to genuine journalists and not spies.''

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Question CIA Analyses of Soviet Economy
DOC.TEXT: U.S. presidents have for four decades relied on CIA assessments of the Soviet economy that vastly overstate the economic strength of America's chief rival, witnesses told a Senate committee Monday. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., said the faulty numbers could well have created an unjustified level of concern about Soviet strength that in turn led the United States to overspend on defense. The CIA has come to be relied upon as the principal Western source of information about the Soviet economy, including its overall gross national product and the proportion of the GNP devoted to military might. The spy agency has rated Soviet economic growth as higher than that of the United States for most of the period since it began its assessments in the early 1950s. Last year, the CIA put the Soviet GNP at 51 percent of the U.S. GNP of $5.23 trillion. That figure puts the CIA near the top of a range of estimates, which go as low as 14 percent, and Moynihan said a more realistic number would be around 33 percent. ``If we had kept with that one-third number, we would have behaved differently,'' Moynihan said. Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, said the one-third figure is probably a good estimate. The spy agency's chief analyst of the Soviet Union, George Kolt, conceded the agency's number is probably too high but maintained ``we have done a good job on a very complex issue.'' Kolt said the CIA would adjust its figures downward, perhaps nearer to an economic growth of 35 percent, if it can get better information on the quality of Soviet goods and can improve its own analytical methods. But he said the agency's estimates have been accurate when it comes to Soviet defense spending. Boskin pointed out that any estimates of the Soviet economy are made difficult because of problems in getting accurate data about production and consumption, the inability to compare currencies and the fundamental problem of assigning value to items in a system without market pricing. The process is fraught with distortions, such as the Soviet plant that produces an excess of easy-to-make ball bearings, then ships them to a steel mill where they are melted down and sent back to make more bearings, Boskin said. Moynihan pointed out that it is difficult, as well, for Americans to conceive of a system where fully one-half of agricultural production can be lost to spoilage because of a defective distribution system. Those difficulties will confront the International Monetary Fund when it seeks to carry out a study of the Soviet economy mandated last week by the world's seven most developed nations. The IMF study is to be the basis for any future aid to the Soviet Union. Congress ran into its own problems in trying to assess the CIA's performance. A witness from the General Accounting Office, Allan Mendelowitz, said he had been stymied by the agency in seeking information for a congressionally mandated study of CIA methodology. ``This is discouraging,'' Moynihan said, promising to take the matter up with CIA Director William Webster. ``Didn't I read somewhere ... that the Cold War is over?''

DOC.HEAD: There's Trouble in Michigan City: Fuming Over Where Firefighters Sit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `City policy ...' to CLARIFY why chief was opposed to firefighters sitting outside during the day
DOC.TEXT: It took a lot to rile residents of this farming community best known as the birthplace of Thomas E. Dewey _ until firefighters were barred from sitting in front of their firehouse. About 250 people have signed a petition to protest the order by the fire chief and city manager. And more 50 people turned out for a City Council meeting July 9 to press for the ban to be dropped. ``I figure, they've done it for years, why not keep doing it?'' said Don Hornus, a regular patron at the Roundtable restaurant. ``I don't know why they're making such a big deal over it. We don't get that much controversy over things that matter.'' The motto of this tree-lined city about 100 miles northwest of Detroit proclaims that it's ``a shade better'' than other communities.
