The city of 16,455 is the birthplace of Dewey, the Republican presidential candidate in 1944 and 1948, and was a leading manufacturer of caskets in the 1920s. City policy permitted the 18 firefighters who work 24-hour shifts to sit in front of the station after 5 p.m. But two months ago, Chief John Kenney banned it around the clock after seeing some firefighters in front of the station at midday. He said it looked unprofessional. Firefighters can still sit outside on the other sides of the one-story fire station or in its air-conditioned lounge when they're waiting for emergency calls. Chamber of Commerce Executive Director Mike McCloskey said opinion is virtually unanimous that the city went too far with the ban. ``I think it's probably a way of life for firemen to sit in front of the fire station,'' he said. Heat from the public prompted City Council last week to order City Manager Gregg Guetschow to solve the dispute. Guetschow said the firefighters' union has asked for a meeting to discuss the sitting situation. Union President James Treadway did not return a message left on his answering machine Monday. In a letter to The Argus-Press newspaper, he wrote, ``Sitting in front of the fire station in the evening is a tradition that predates all of the current firefighters.'' In a letter published Monday, Dick Marr, 24-year firefighter, wrote: ``If you wonder just what the firemen get out of sitting in front of the station, it is just watching the people go by, tooting their horns, waving and watching the smiles on the kids and their parents when we wave back. It's the thank-yous from the people who stop by.'' The city manager or fire chief would neither discuss the ban nor allow on-duty firefighters to be interviewed. ``This really in the whole scheme of things is a very, very minor issue that should have been dealt with under the contract and will be dealt with under the contract just like every other grievance we get is,'' Guetschow said. He said the city is being unfairly ridiculed because it let a small matter get out of hand. But The Argus-Press said City Council deserved the criticism. ``There are few jobs that require their workers to go to work every day knowing it could be their last,'' an editorial said. ``We don't care what they talk about, to whom they talk, or if they want to play a few hands of gin rummy. Or snooze. Or eat. Or turn cartwheels or floss their teeth. Or just sit.''

DOC.HEAD: Jogger Testifies at Trial of Youths Charged with Attacking Her
DOC.TEXT: The woman known as the Central Park jogger climbed unsteadily onto the witness stand Monday and described the lasting effects of a beating she barely survived and does not remember. Speaking in a firm voice, the woman testified she has trouble walking and seeing, cannot smell _ and cannot remember why. She said she remembers breaking a dinner date with a friend on April 19, 1989, because of work, but does not remember entering the park to run around 9:30 p.m., when she was gang-raped and viciously beaten by marauding youths who left her naked and near death in a puddle of mud and blood. ``What was your very next memory?'' asked Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer. ``I remember waking up in the hospital on a Friday evening, late in May,'' she said. ``A very good friend of mine was in the room and so was a nurse. It was the Memorial Day weekend.'' She said she was in the hospital about six weeks before being transferred to a rehabilitation center. Before her testimony, tension filled the courtroom during the 2{ minutes from when she was called until she took the stand. It was not clear what took so long, but finally she walked shakily into the room, taking short steps as a court officer held her elbow and helped her climb the witness stand. During her 10 minutes on the stand, the woman did not appear to look at the three youths charged with maiming her; the three looked at their hands, fiddled with pens or stared into space. There were no obvious reactions by the jurors. Defense attorneys asked the witness no questions. ``Do you suffer any lasting injuries as a result of what happened to you on April 19, 1989?'' asked Lederer. ``I have problems with balance when I'm walking, and coordination. At times, I'll veer off to the right or the left,'' she said. ``I have trouble walking down steps. I also lost my sense of smell completely. That has not come back.'' ``I have double vision. When I'm reading, I hold papers over to the left to compensate. It takes a fair amount of concentration to make the image one.'' ``It's worse when my eyes are tired,'' and worsens still if she's in a dark room, she said. In an attempt to blunt assertions by defense attorneys that a rape may not have occurred, the jogger was questioned about her sexual activity and use of a diaphragm for birth control. The woman, who was attacked on a Wednesday, testified that she had last had sex the previous Sunday, with her boyfriend. Afterward, she went running with her boyfriend and with a diaphragm still inserted. A DNA expert, Dwight Adams, who works for the FBI, testified earlier that semen that matched her boyfriend's DNA profile was found on the jogger's black running tights. The prosecution apparently was trying to show the semen was deposited there on Sunday, and that she wore the same pants on Wednesday. Adams also said none of the other semen samples matched the defendants' or the boyfriend's. The victim, the prosecution's 34th witness, was called as the trial entered its fourth week. Antron McCray and Raymond Santana and Yusef Salaam, all 16, are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the woman and two male joggers. They are being tried in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders to up to 10 years in prison. Three other youths face trial later this year. The woman, a 30-year-old investment banker, has recovered enough to return to work at Salomon Brothers Inc., where she is a vice president in corporate finance. The witness was dressed in a purple, double-breasted business suit. Her blond hair was cut short and away from her face, permitting a view of the jagged scar which runs from above her left eyebrow down across her cheek. Justice Thomas B. Galligan told the courtroom artists not to draw the woman because she had expressed anxiety about having her likeness shown and was entitled, because of the nature of the crime, to make that request. Her name has been withheld by news organizations. The woman was asked to identify the clothing she was wearing the night of the attack. Lederer showed her a T-shirt, now almost completely brown with dried blood. ``Do you recognize this?'' Lederer asked. ``That's the shirt that I used to wear,'' she replied. ``Prior to April 19, 1989, what color was it?'' Lederer asked. ``It was white,'' she answered. The prosecution said the woman was attacked as she jogged after work. The T-shirt, twirled tightly to form a kind of rope, was used to bind her hand to her neck and gag her while she was raped and bludgeoned, detectives have testified. Robert Burns, Salaam's lawyer, said outside the courtroom he did not cross-examine the witness because, ``She came here as a helpless victim. She served no evidentiary purpose.'' Santana's lawyer, Peter Rivera, said, ``In the long run, I think her testimony helps us, the fact that she came in and couldn't identify any of the defendants, and could not even (remember) going to the park.'' As Rivera spoke, supporters of the defendants shouted, ``Sellout! Sellout! Who're you representing, the boys or the victim?''

DOC.HEAD: Car Crashes Into Convenience Store, Kills Patron
DOC.TEXT: A car crashed through the window of a crowded convenience store Monday, killing a patron and injuring seven other people, police said. Police said they don't know what caused the accident. Witnesses told police that the car may have been trying to avoid other vehicles. Construction worker Joseph Dougherty said he was sitting at a table with three others at the WaWa market when he saw a car coming through a light. ``We all jumped up. Three of the guys went down and I just kept on heading for the front door,'' he said. Dougherty said he had noticed a man sitting at a counter by the wall. ``The car just crushed him right to the wall,'' he said. Police Capt. Edward DiMato confirmed the man was killed. The victim's identity was not immediately released. The car's occupants included a man, a woman and two children, police said. It could not be immediately determined if they were among the seven injured. Two were admitted to hospitals and five were released after treatment, authorities said. The market at 38th and Spruce streets on the University of Pennsylvania campus has seating for patrons in a restaurant section.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Veterans Form Political Party Opposed to Walesa
DOC.TEXT: Two prominent Solidarity activists who oppose chairman Lech Walesa formed a new political movement Monday that sympathizes with the government and advocates a popular vote for president. The movement, called Democratic Action, said it would try to present a ``strong alternative,'' to the 2-month-old Center Alliance which backs Solidarity leader Walesa and wants him named president by parliament this year. The political movement's formation comes a few days after Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and Walesa declared a political truce in their fued over the pace of political and economic changes. More than 90 people attended the founding meeting held at Parliament. Those attending include many of the 63 senior advisers and longtime Solidarity activists who broke ranks with Walesa at a stormy June 24 meeting of the national Citizens Committee, which Walesa controls. The groups leaders include Zbigniew Bujak, former Warsaw regional leader of Solidarity and the head of the Solidarity underground during the martial-law period, and Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, the longtime leader of Solidarity in Lower Silesia. The new movement scheduled a founding congress for July 28 and representatives said they intended to meet with Solidarity members of both houses of parliament this Friday to invite them to join the movement. Bujak and Fransyniuk were once regarded as Walesa's potential heirs within Solidarity. But in recent months they have distanced themselves from him, complaining about his autocratic style. Bujak said the movement has its ``own proposals concerning the system of the state and style of politics.'' The group's first demand is for popular presidential elections this year. Both Center Alliance and Democratic Action presume President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader, will be persuaded to resign well ahead of his scheduled 1995 departure. ``A fast presidential election will thus contribute to improving the political situation, ... allowing the Sejm (Parliament) to complete its work.'' He said his party also sees it as essential that the next president is elected by the people, and not by parliament. Walesa's opponents have said polls indicate he may have a difficult time winning a popular vote for president. Walesa's supporters want parliament to appoint a president. They say popular presidential elections should be held after a new constitution is written. Bujak and Frasyniuk said some members of the Solidarity-led government support their movement but they did not know if Mazowiecki would join.

DOC.HEAD: White House Concedes It Underestimated Problem
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The White House, in its annual reality check, has confessed the government's deficit problem is far worse than it admitted last January. Now instead of being the Pollyanna of budget forecasters, the administration sounds more like Chicken Little, shouting ``the sky is falling.'' In submitting his proposed budget to Congress six months ago, President Bush foresaw a budget deficit, absent changes in law, of $100.5 billion for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Bush said that figure, which was $36.5 billion above the required deficit limit for 1991, could be handled with a collection of spending cuts and a hodgepodge of small tax hikes that would meet the Gramm-Rudman deficit target of $64 billion for 1991. Now comes the administration's ``Mid-session Review of the Budget,'' and the president sees a much more formidable challenge. Instead of a $100 billion deficit, the deficit has ballooned to $168.8 billion _ $231.4 billion if the savings and loan bailout is taken into account. What happened? In the real world, not a whole lot. The economy that was chugging along at a sub-par growth rate in January has changed little in the intervening months. Interest rates have been stuck at their December levels for most of the year. The cost of the savings and loan bailout has been what most people feared _ horrendous. The Congressional Budget Office and many private forecasters all had budget estimates in January that were far higher than the administration's However, since the president is required in his January budget to meet the Gramm-Rudman deficit targets only on paper, not in reality, the administration forecast a far different world six months ago. It saw economic growth rebounding smartly, thus bringing in more tax revenue. Normally, interest rates rise along with economic growth. But in the administration's world, interest rates would drop sharply as growth rebounded. This helps the bottom line as well because it reduces the government's borrowing costs on the $3 trillion national debt. And as for the S&Ls, the administration, despite widespread warnings to the contrary, low-balled the estimate of how much the government would need to clean up the mess. While the whole process may not win a ``truth-in-budgeting'' award, it did allow the president to submit a 1991 budget that honored his ``read-my-lips'' pledge against tax increases. But with the new budget year set to start Oct. 1, the administration by law must take another look at the economic and budget landscape, based on actual performance over the last six months. Bush's new budget estimates had to take into account the reality that economic growth has not picked up, that interest rates have not fallen and that spending on the S&L problem has been horrendous. It may well have been the fast-approaching deadline for the new budget estimate that forced the president's hand last month and caused his reversal on the tax question. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Budget Director Richard Darman and Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, all dodged the question Monday of just how much in new taxes the administration would be willing to accept to close the yawning budget gap, saying that issue would have to be addressed as part of the budget negotiations with Congress. But, in addition to offering the stark numbers, the administration seemed to be proposing the outline of a possible agreement Monday. The budget document estimated the deficit both with S&L spending counted against Gramm-Rudman target and not counted. While Darman insisted that the administration was not taking a stand on this issue, the administration seemed to be signalling a willingness to support an accounting change that will not count S&L spending against the Gramm-Rudman targets. That would still leave $100 billion in deficit reductions needed to meet the 1991 Gramm-Rudman limit of $64 billion. Boskin said a deficit fix of that magnitude could well tip the country into a recession. But the administration also warned that anything less than $50 billion to $55 billion in deficit cuts would not be viewed ``as a credible attack on the budget problem.'' Thus the administration appeared to signal a willingness to accept a spending and tax package totalling $50 billion to $55 billion while removing S&L costs from the Gramm-Rudman accounting and raising the Gramm-Rudman target for 1991 and following years. That law, whose targets were stretched out once before in 1987, now calls for a balanced budget by 1993. Despite the fact that the budget negotiations have been going nowhere for weeks, Darman expressed hope Monday that a deal could be reached before Congress leaves for its August recess. He said the negotiators had come perhaps 60 percent to 70 percent of the way toward striking a deal. ``The unfortunate thing is that the last 30 or 40 percent of the way is all of the hard stuff. That's where the really tough choices have to be made,'' Darman said.
Martin Crutsinger has covered economic issues in Washington for The Associated Press since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: T-Bill Interest Falls
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level in six months. The Treasury Department sold $9 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.62 percent, down from 7.81 percent last week. Another $9 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.52 percent, down from 7.75 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.57 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.44 percent Jan. 8. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.88 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,807.40 and 7.93 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,619.80. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 8.09 percent last week, up from 8.06 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Broadcasting Chief Fears `Orgy of Democracy'
With AM-Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The head of Soviet television and radio said Monday he fears ``an orgy of democracy'' now that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has acted to loosen controls on the state broadcasting monopoly. Mikhail F. Nenashev, the chief of Gostelradio and a Communist Party traditionalist, said in an interview broadcast on Soviet TV that the decree issued by Gorbachev Sunday will make ``managing television ... much more complex than in the past.'' Gorbachev's ``Presidential Decree on Democratization of Television and Radio,'' is designed to cut back on the Communist Party's monopoly on the airwaves. The decree ``recognizes the need to determine a legal basis for the activities of television and radio broadcasting under new conditions'' and recommended that parliament adopt appropriate laws, apparently corresponding to the press law passed June 12. That law gave non-government and non-party groups the right to own and operate newspapers and magazines, ending what effectively had been a decades-old monopoly held by Communist authorities. Growing democracy within the country requires a ``cardinal change in the nature of the country's television and radio broadcasting,'' said the decree, which also was carried by the state news agency Tass. The guidelines for radio and television currently are set by a state committee. Until now, only groups approved by the committee had access to Soviet television. As a result, the Communist Party received large segments of time on the airwaves. The decree emphasized the inadmissibility of monopolizing ``air time by this or that party, political current or group,'' Tass reported. ``For a lasting time the television was under the party influence, what we used to call and still call the party monopoly,'' said Nenashev, who formerly held the post of head of the state publishing committee. ``Now I am more afraid of an orgy of democracy rather than the party monopoly, when the monopoly is replaced by numerous demands put forth by various groups, parties, various councils, various organs,'' he said. Hundreds of new groups have sprung up throughout the country in the last several years. A spokesman for Democratic Platform, a group of radical reformers in the Communist Party who have announced that they are leaving the party, praised the decree. ``As a whole, we ... regard this as a very positive and radical decree,'' said Vladimir Filin. He said Democratic Platform would work to gain access to new channels, but said the group did not have the financial or technical means to start its own. ``I'm afraid it's going to be tough to get quick access to television on the strength of the decree,'' said Vladimir Zhirinovsky, chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party, which he claims has 12,000 members registered across the country. Zhirinovsky said since the press law was passed in June, putting out his newspaper ``has become much easier in general'' because he has the right to publish it as a person, rather than a party. ``As to the presidential decree (on broadcasting), I see it as a very good thing, though I am afraid that low-level holdover apparatchiks in the Moscow City Council will definitely try to delay the process should my party apply for TV coverage,'' Zhirinovsky said. ``Let's see how this decree will be realized,'' he added. In addition to stubborn bureaucrats, the many new parties also lack the money to buy time on Soviet Central Television, let alone set up their own TV or radio station. In the Baltic states and other republics at odds with Moscow over their status within the Soviet Union, elected governments have declared that local radio and television stations belong to them. However, the decree emphasizes control by the Soviet government over the legal status of radio and television stations in the republics.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Advocates Say Barry Had Promised to Veto Bill
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, who signed a bill scuttling the city's comprehensive overnight shelter law, had promised to veto it after homeless advocate Mitch Snyder's death, a Snyder associate said Monday. ``I was shocked that he signed it,'' said Carol Fennelly, another homeless advocate. ``We thought we had assurances that he wouldn't.'' But Barry spokeswoman Lurma Rackley said the mayor, who signed the bill Thursday, had made no promises. ``He said he didn't want to mix politics with Mitch's death, and didn't want to discuss it under those circumstances,'' Ms. Rackley said. The measure authorizes the city to restrict annual spending for shelter, limit the number of nights individuals and families may stay at the shelters and require those with money to help defray the cost of finding permanent housing. Snyder, 46, was found hanged July 5.

DOC.HEAD: Ukraine Parliament, Following Other Republics, Declares Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second most populous republic, followed sovereignty decrees by other republics and overwhelmingly declared Monday that its laws take precedence over national law. The pro-independence political movement Rukh said the sovereignty declaration was far more radical than one adopted in the Russian republic, stating the Ukraine has the right to set up its own armed forces, currency, citizenship and banking system in the republic of 50 million residents. The Supreme Soviet parliament, meeting in the capital of Kiev, declared the ``supremacy, independence, absolute authority and indivisibility'' of Ukrainan authority on the republic's territory, the Tass news agency said. It also called for the Ukraine's ``independence and equal rights in external relations.'' Its youth cannot perform military service outside the republic without parliament's permission, the declaration said. It sets a goal of establishing a ``constantly neutral government, which does not take part in military blocs'' and opposes the production, proliferation and use of nuclear weapons, according to Tass. The Interfax news service said the vote was 355-4 in favor of the sovereignty declaration, with one abstention. Anatoly Shibiko, a senior official of Rukh, said he was surprised the Communist faction in the parliament supported the declaration. ``We expected them to kill it today, after returning from the congress in Moscow,'' Shibiko said, referring to the 28th Communist Party Congress. ``But now I see that Communists want independence too, wishing to keep their power.'' The parliament set July 16 as a public holiday in the Ukraine. In its declaration, the Ukraine followed other republics such as Russia, the Baltic states of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, Uzbekistan and Moldavia that passed decrees seeking more independence from central authority. Lithuania began the independence movement with its March 11 declaration. Soviet Georgia also favors sovereignty, and last month established a commission to work toward independence. Some Ukrainian nationalists support total independence for their republic, a key industrial and farming region, but the movement is not as far advanced as it is in other Soviet republics, such as the Baltics. The debate over sovereignty in the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine had caused sharp disagreements and last week led indirectly to the resignation of the republic's president, Vladimir Ivashko, who then was chosen the deputy head of the Soviet Communist Party. Ivashko and other deputies to the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet were called back last week from the party congress for the debate on sovereignty. Ivashko refused to go, however, and turned in his resignation. He said he interpreted his dispute with the parliament over the issue as indicating that he did not have enough authority to govern the republic. The same day, he was nominated to be Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Communist Party deputy, and he was elected easily.

DOC.HEAD: Group: Unclear Israeli Firing Orders Result in Needless Deaths
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli human rights group accused soldiers of ``an itchy trigger finger'' in dealing with the Palestinian uprising and said Monday that unclear firing orders resulted in hundreds of unnecessary deaths. The army spokesman's office criticized the 60-page report by Betselem, saying it ``contains many inconsistencies'' and was ``haughty, incriminating and one-sided.'' The office refused to discuss specific charges, saying it could not comment until the Supreme Court rules on a suit filed this year challenging the army's orders in the occupied territories. According to figures compiled by The Associated Press, Israeli soldiers or civilians have killed 723 Palestinians during the 31-month-old rebellion against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. An additional 236 Palestinians were killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israeli authorities. Forty-five Israelis have died in the violence. The Betselem report said shootings by soldiers accounted ``for the overwhelming majority'' of fatalities, and that there were ``hundreds of cases in which death could have been averted.'' It blamed unclear firing regulations, saying they led to ``a tangle of interpretations'' on when and how weapons can be used. Betselem, also known as the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, was founded by liberal Israeli legislators, academics and lawyers to investigate human rights problems in the occupied lands. Amnesty International is among the international groups which have cited its findings. ``The facts evoke an image of an itchy trigger finger, a lax observance of regulations, the absence of exhaustive investigations and a failure to mete out deterring and educational punishment,'' Betselem reported. It said these suggest ``legitimacy is conferred on unjustified firing and violation of the law.'' The report was especially critical of army handling of Palestinian demonstrations, in which most deaths have occurred. Army orders require soldiers to fire at a demonstrator's legs and to shoot to kill only if the soldier's life is threatened. The report said just one of the nine soldiers killed during the uprising died during a riot. ``These figures show that no direct correlation exists between the intensity of the danger to life and the circumstances in which soldiers may open fire,'' it said. It also criticized army use of plastic bullets for punishment and deterrence, calling this ``an extremely grave and wholly improper usage.'' The army introduced plastic bullets in July 1988, trying to reduce fatalities. It says the bullets are not lethal when fired from at least 230 feet. Betselem said at least 128 Palestinians have been killed with plastic ammunition. Brig. Gen. Amnon Strasnov, the army's chief legal officer, told Israel radio the army ``takes every step to decrease the number of deaths and injuries'' and said plastic bullets resulted in ``a significant decrease'' in deaths. He noted that 122 soldiers have faced courts-martial proceedings during the uprising, 41 for illegal killing, causing death or illegal use of firearms. Most were found guilty, he said. But Betselem said only two soldiers have been tried for manslaughter during the uprising. Dedi Zucker, a founder of Betselem and a Parliament member from the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement, told a news conference in Tel Aviv on Sunday the findings suggest the army should adopt regulations closer to those used by police. Police must exhaust non-lethal riot controls measures, such as tear gas and rubber bullets, and face life-threatening situations before they can get commanders' permission to fire lethal weapons. Zucker observed that Jerusalem is under police jurisdiction. He noted it has seen considerably less violence and fewer people killed than towns in the West Bank and Gaza, where the army functions. He said, ``The police have adopted totally different criteria and with much more success. The army should adopt the police criteria.''

DOC.HEAD: Statements from German Chancellor in Soviet News Conference
With AM_Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the statement by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl during a live news conference Monday from the Soviet Union on the results of his talks with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev: ``Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, this press conference concludes a two-day encounter between President Gorbachev and myself ... an encounter that I think in the history of German-Soviet relations produced a new high point. That covers the depth and the intensity of our talks in Moscow, in the airplane and here in the homeland of President Gorbachev. I understand this invitation in his homeland as a very special gesture. ... Our talks were marked by the greatest openness and mutual understanding and personal sympathy. ... But what was special in the significance of this encounter lies in the results. We are in agreement that in central issues broad-ranging progress could be reached. This breakthrough was possible because both sides are aware that in Germany and in Europe and in the Soviet Union historical transformations are taking place that also places special responsibility on us. ... As for the results of the talks, I can note: President Gorbachev and I are clear that the German-Soviet relationship is of central importance for the future of our peoples and for the fate of Europe. ... We agreed to conclude, immediately after the unification of Germany, a comprehensive and fundamental bilateral treaty that regulates our relationship on a long-term and good-neighborly basis. Such a treaty should include all areas: political relationships as well as the security of both sides; economy, culture, science and technology, visitor exchanges as well as many other things. The goal of this is to bring our relationship on the basis of stability, verifiability, trust for the future. Our talks served to clarify basic questions that are being negotiated in the framework of the two-plus-four talks. We have stressed the agreement that was reached at the meeting of the six foreign ministers at the two-plus-four talks in June in Berlin, namely, that the two-plus-four talks should be concluded in a time frame so that the results can be presented to the CSCE summit in November in Paris. I can today with satisfaction and agreement with President Gorbachev state: 1. The unification of Germany comprises the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic and Berlin. 2. When unification is accomplished the rights of the four powers and responsibilities will be completely removed so that a unified Germany at the time of its unification receives its full and unrestricted sovereignty. Thirdly, a unified Germany in exercising its unrestricted sovereignty freely and by itself decide if and which alliances it wants to belong to. That conforms with the CSCE final act. I have explained the view of the government of the Federal Republic of Germany that the unified Germany would like to be a member of the NATO alliance and I am sure that this is in accordance with the view of the German Democratic Republic. 4. The unified Germany concludes with the Soviet Union a bilateral treaty to carry out the withdrawal of Soviet troops from the German Democratic Republic that should be concluded within three to four years. At the same time we should conclude a transitional treaty with the Soviet Union that would cover the consequences of the introduction of the deutsche mark in the German Democratic Republic within this time period from three to four years. 5. As long as the Soviet troops remain stationed on the former territory, the German Democratic Republic, the NATO structures will not be extended to this part of Germany. The immediate application of Article 5 and 6 of the NATO treaty remains from the beginning undisturbed. Unintegrated units of the Bundeswehr (the West German army), that means units of the territorial defense, can be stationed immediately after unification on the territory of the German Democratic Republic and Berlin. For the period of the presence of Soviet troops on the former territory of the German Democratic Republic, troops from the three Western powers should stay in Berlin after unity, according to our concept. The federal (West German) government will ask the three Western powers about this and will seek to conclude agreements with respective governments to regulate the stationing (of the troops in Berlin). 7. The federal republic of Germany declares itself ready during the period of the Vienna negotiations to give a declaration of its commitment to reduce the level of the armed forces of a unified Germany from a period of three to four years to 370,000 men. The reduction should come into force the day the first Vienna agreement takes effect. 8. A unified Germany will renounce the production, storage and use of ABC (chemical) weapons and remain member of the (nuclear) non-proliferation treaty. Ladies and gentlemen, this joint agreement is a very good starting point now to be able to conclude successfully and in time the external aspects of German unity within the framework of the two-plus-four talks.''

DOC.HEAD: Humpback Whale Freed from Fishing Net
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with whale freed. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `One swoop...
DOC.TEXT: A whale that got tangled in a fishing net was freed Monday by scientists who rushed to its aid aboard a flotilla of research boats and private craft. ``It's swimming free into the sunset,'' said Tom Hill, captain of the Yankee Captains out of Gloucester, as the 25-ton mammal spouted and splashed out into the open sea. The five-year-old, 40-foot-long humpback had been tangled for most of the day in a fishing net. The humpback, nicknamed Mallard by whale watchers, was discovered thrashing in the water 17 miles off Massachusetts. Rescuers could clearly hear ``trumpeting'' through the breathing hole atop its head as it fought the net and rope running through its mouth and around its body. ``It's a sign of antagonism or anxiety,'' scientist Steven Frohock said of the sound as he waited with others for the whale to tire so it could be approached. Rescue workers attached buoys to the trailing ends of the net wrapped around Mallard, hoping the additional drag would tire the whale, forcing it to rest on the surface. Thirty to 40 other whales, humpbacks and finbacks, circled and fed in the area, keeping a safe distance from the boats. But one whale, apparently hearing Mallard's cries, came up along side the entangled mammal and rubbed its head. Leading a crew of four rescuers late in the afternoon, Charles ``Stormy'' Mayo, head of the Center for Coastal Studies in Provincetown, Mass., approached the whales in two inflatable motorboats. A few minutes before 5 p.m., after more than an hour of effort, they managed to free Mallard from the plastic net. At one point, Mayo's boat nearly overturned when Mallard reared its head. Mayo, clad in a wetsuit, got into the water at one point, a risky move. Hill a 10-year veteran of whale-watching trips, said the rescuers would only in the most extreme circumstances get into the water to help the whale. ``One swoop of a flipper and they could be dead,'' he said. The whale was caught in a gill net set along the seafloor on the Stellwagen Bank to catch tuna and other fish. The area is frequented by whale-watching boats of by Massachusetts companies that earn their keep by taking humans to watch their animal cousins feed and frolic, rather than harpooning them as in the old days. The mission set off Monday from Gloucester and across Cape Cod Bay from Provincetown, Mass., after a fisherman radioed that he was awakened in the morning by a whale thrashing next to his boat. The whale, first recorded by whale watchers in 1986, was identified by scars and coloring on its tail and flukes, or flippers. Mallard was the second tangled whale sighted in a week. Last week, a whale known as Quixote was spotted trailing net, which the whales hit when diving to the bottom in search of the same fish the nets are designed to ensnare. Quixote hadn't been seen since Thursday. ``It's a very precarious situation. These whales aren't very happy to have a boat on top of them,'' said Frohock, chief scientist of Yankee Fleet, one of the whale-watching companies. ``When they start thrashing around, it can be a life-and-death situation, not only for the whale, but also for the people trying to save him.'' The whale _ sex unknown _ was tangled in one of the quarter-mile-long gill nets set on the Stellwagen Bank, which is about 17 miles off Gloucester and 25 miles from Provincetown. The bank is 25 miles long, five miles wide has an average depth of 84 feet. The area is a prime fishing ground this time of year for tuna, but it is also where fishermen catch haddock, pollock, codfish and some of the smaller species of whiting and red fish. Whales, too, come there for about half the year to feed. Lt. Glenn Miller, the U.S. Coast Guard's fisheries coordination officer in Boston, described gill nets as similar to free-standing chain-link fence about eight feet height and sitting on the ocean floor. The bottom edge is weighted with lead and the upper edge has plastic floats to keep the net upright.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Hails Foster Grandparents
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush choked back tears Monday as she told a group of foster grandparents that more volunteers are needed because so many babies are born with AIDS or addicted to drugs. ``We're running out of you,'' Mrs. Bush told the 26 volunteers who came to Washington on an expense-paid trip to mark the 25th anniversary of ACTION's Foster Grandparent program. ``We've got to get more help because, unfortunately, the boarder babies and the babies that need you are multiplying,'' the first lady said, sounding a somber note during the otherwise festive ceremony. ``So we've got to work on both ends. We've got to stop them from being abandoned and born with AIDS and coke-related problems,'' she said, her voice faltering. She caught herself and added: ``I see here I'm supposed to end with a very high, happy note, so having told you that, get out and recruit some more. And meanwhile, happy anniversary and God bless you all!'' The Foster Grandparent program matches low-income men and women age 60 or older with mentally or physically handicapped children, youths in juvenile detention facilities, abandoned babies and others with special needs. The 26 volunteers, the oldest 93 years old, represented the current 27,000 foster grandparents and the more than 400,000 who ``shared themselves with our children over the past 25 years,'' as Mrs. Bush put it. The program assigns foster grandparents to children on a one-to-one basis after 40 hours of pre-service training. ACTION says the typical volunteer devotes two hours daily to each of two children. Mrs. Bush has visited hospitals and other facilities caring for infants with AIDS and ``boarder'' babies abandoned by crack-addicted mothers. She received a peach smock from a San Antonio foster grandparent, as well as one for her husband. On a lighter note, she said: ``We Bushes ... love being grandparents. We've been through it 12 times so far and it's gotten to be a wonderful habit.'' Mrs. Bush recalled how much her children enjoyed spending time with the president's mother, Dorothy Walker Bush, now 89. ``They're really better people because they had the pleasure of her company,'' she said. ``All people need that special relationship. ``I'm sure you have that same wonderful effect that George's mother had on the children whose lives you touch,'' said Mrs. Bush, who was joined at the ceremony by William Bennett, the drug policy coordinator. It was Bennett who told Mrs. Bush of the growing need for foster grandparents. ``We're going to need more foster parents and grandparents before the drug wars are over,'' he told reporters. ``And when the drug war's over, we're still going to need them because the babies will still be the casualties.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Will Pay $25,000 to Ex-Official Charged With Spying
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department will pay $25,000 to a former official cleared of espionage allegations to head off a lawsuit over an erroneous report about the inquiry, a lawyer said Monday. Matthew L. Myers, who represents former Justice Department official Roger Pilon, said the government issued a private letter of apology last week and agreed to pay $25,000 to settle the dispute. Pilon, former director of the Justice Department's Asylum Policy and Review Unit, was placed on administrative leave in 1988 when he and his wife, Juliana, were investigated to determine whether they had passed a classified document to South African diplomats. The investigation did not result in criminal charges and Pilon was reinstated in his job and his top-secret security clearance was restored. But the 1988 annual report of the department's internal watchdog unit described a different outcome when it was issued last fall. The report by the Office of Professional Responsibility, which did not identify Pilon by name, said that the investigation found ``sufficient cause to terminate'' the officials's appointment. ``The employee resigned prior to the initiation of removal proceedings,'' said the report. Pilon acknowledged to reporters who had learned his name that he was the person referred to in the report but denied any wrongdoing. He demanded an apology from the Justice Department, which conducted a further inquiry into the matter. In its July 12 letter, the Justice Department acknowledged that there was ``confusion created'' by the publication of the OPR report last fall. Assistant Attorney General Stuart M. Gerson said in the letter that the Pilons were entitled to an apology because ``the 1988 investigation of Mr. Pilon did not produce any evidence sufficient to warrant his dismissal from the department.'' Gerson noted that Pilon was ``restored unconditionally'' to his agency position and ``his subsequent resignation was self-initiated and was not made in the face of removal proceedings (which in fact never had been contemplated or ordered).'' As part of the settlement, Gerson's letter will be placed in Justice Department files, along with those at the State Department, the FBI and the National Security Agency. Pilon said he suspects that the investigation may have begun after the NSA intercepted a conversation between his wife and a South African diplomat in New York. At the time, Mrs. Pilon was analyzing U.N. policies for the Heritage Foundation. Pilon says he suspects his wife's conversation with the diplomat was misinterpreted by eavesdroppers. According to a chronology of the case released by Pilon's lawyer, the couple were interrogated separately but simultaneously on Jan. 6, 1988 by the FBI. The Pilons have maintained that the probe cost Mrs. Pilon a presidential nomination to be an assistant secretary of interior. The Pilons have denied that they gave a classified State Department report on the influence of communism in South Africa to a South African diplomat in New York. The FBI told the Pilons they had both showed ``problems'' when they took polygraph tests, according to the chronology. But the couple both passed polygraph tests administered by private investigators. During the investigation, the chronology said, the FBI agents told the Pilons they had ``a high degree of confidence that the Pilons transmitted the document'' and that they had ``other evidence.'' But on Sept. 9, 1988, Associate Deputy Attorney General Dee V. Benson reinstated Pilon and said in a letter that ``no implication adverse to you should be taken from the investigations.'' Myers said the Pilons ``had threatened to file suit unless the department acted decisively to correct the record and to compensate the Pilons.'' ``In many respects, the admission of error is too little too late. There is no reason this should have taken eight months to resolve when the facts are as clear as they are,'' Myers said.

DOC.HEAD: President of Ecuador to Meet with Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf to add Argentina
DOC.TEXT: President Rodrigo Borja of Ecuador will meet here with President Bush on July 23, the White House announced Monday. Borja will be the first Latin American chief of state to meet with Bush since he announced a plan last month to forgive billions of dollars in debt owed by Latin countries, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Bush's ``Enterprise for the Americas'' initiative would include forgiving part of the $12 billion owed the United States by Latin and Caribbean countries. The initiative also would create a hemisphere-wide free-trade zone. In September, Bush plans to visit the South American countries of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Admits Having Sheltered Abu Daoud
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's deposed communist leadership sheltered Palestinian terrorists, including the man believed responsible for killing 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games, the Interior Ministry confirmed Monday. Wolfgang Elstner, the ministry's director of police, said factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization teamed up with other terrorist groups during the late 1970s, and sought to set up a logistical base in East Germany. He said records of the former secret police force _ known as the Stasi _ showed a man known as Abu Daoud gained entry to East Germany in 1978 and traveled to the country several times since then. Elstner said Abu Daoud tried to establish contact in East Germany with the Venezuelan terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. Abu Daoud is believed to be the PLO terrorist who planned the attack on the Olympic Village in Munich, which led to deaths of 11 Israeli athletes during a terrorist shootout with police at Munich airport. The Berliner Morgenpost newspaper in West Berlin reported over the weekend that Abu Daoud was sighted several times at the Palast Hotel in East Berlin, and was still believed to be living in East Germany now. On Monday, East Germany's ADN news agency published an interview with the hotel's protocol manager, Reinhard Hellmann, who confirmed that Abu Daoud was a regular guest there. Daoud used the name Tarek. ``We had known this Mr. Tarek for years. ... But no one knew who this modest and utterly polite guest was,'' Hellmann was quoted as saying. According to ADN, Hellmann said Abu Daoud made a ``very cultivated'' impression and often discussed Mideast problems with hotel staff. ``He said he was very unhappy about the discord within the PLO.'' Although PLO chief Yasser Arafat also stayed at the Palast during official visits to East Berlin, he and Abu Daoud never were guests at the same time, Hellmann was quoted as saying. Abu Daoud, or Mahmoud Daoud, is a senior officer of the PLO branch Fatah. Many Fatah people were believed to have had a hand in the Black September terrorist group that carried out some of the most notorious attacks of the 1970s, including the one at the Munich Olympics. Terrorist Carlos, whose real name is Illich Ramirez-Sanchez, is thought responsible for the deaths of two French secret agents and for the Dec. 21, 1975, attack on Arab oil ministers in Vienna that killed three of the officials. Abu Daoud also sought to get in touch with ``anarcho-terrorist groups from Western nations,'' said Elstner, who gave no specifics. Elstner said East German ports and airports were on the lookout for Abu Daoud, but no arrest warrant was issued. East German's communist rulers, ousted last fall, have also been accused of hiding Red Army Faction terrorists from West Germany. West German news media claimed the rulers had ties with Libyan, Basque and Irish terrorists as well.

DOC.HEAD: Crime-Fighting Turtle Jailed in Virginia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sharn is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: One of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, on tour to promote the crime-fighting band, spent the weekend behind bars. Leon M. Blake, who portrays the turtle Michaelangelo in shopping mall appearances, was charged with drunken driving and driving without a license in his possession. Blake, who didn't appear in the Ninja Turtles' movie, was released Monday on $500 bail. Blake, whose arrest report listed ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle'' for occupation and ``Michaelangelo'' under aliases, was arrested early Saturday. Albemarle County Police Sgt. Sharn Perry said Blake had pulled over to relieve himself when an officer saw him and stopped. Authorities said Blake jumped into his van and drove off but was stopped about 100 yards away. Blake, 31, of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., was in town to help another acter play the Michaelangelo role, and the show went on as scheduled, promoters said. Said Perry: ``I guess it just goes to show that at 2:36 in the morning, Ninja turtles should be home in bed.''

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Drugs Helped D.C. Criminal Justice Bills Soar
DOC.TEXT: The drug epidemic in part forced the District of Columbia to spend more on police, jails and courts than any state, but so did footing the bill for programs states usually pay for, city officials said Monday. A Justice Department report issued Sunday showed the district had spent almost four times the national average on criminal and civil justice in 1988, the year a crack cocaine epidemic hit the city. ``Certainly, if you are comparing the states, you have to compare apples with apples,'' said Robert Pohlman, the city's deputy mayor for finance. ``If you are comparing the cost of our local police force ... with a state police force, you're comparing apples with oranges.'' The study revealed the nation's capital, which functions as a local and a state government, spent about $859 per resident in 1988 for police protection, courts and correctional facilities. The national per capita average spending on justice activities by state and local governments that year was $218. ``That figure is so high because we have to pay for the city jail, plus the equivalent of a state correctional institution, and halfway houses,'' said corrections department spokeswoman Pat Wheeler. ``No state has to pay for all of that.'' Wheeler said the explosion of drug use has helped drive up the cost of corrections in Washington, but mandatory sentencing laws have added to the price tag. ``We have a high incarceration rate, both because the police are doing a good job arresting drug dealers and because we are seeing an increase in the number of drug offenses that require the person serve time,'' Wheeler said. ``We didn't ask for all these people _ we just lock them up.'' But there is little question the city's budget reflects an increasing concern about stopping crime. In fiscal 1980, the district spent $56.6 million to house the 4,707 inmates that spent time behind bars. In the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30, the city is budgeting $237 million to house prisoners. On Monday, 11,487 people were behind bars. Indeed, to avoid exceeding court-ordered population limits at the city's prisons, inmates now are serving sentences in state and federal penitentiaries as far away as Washington state.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Gorbachev for NATO Statement
With AM-Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds new 14th and 15th grafs to UPDATE with Baker comment.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday praised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a statesman for withdrawing objections to a united Germany's membership in NATO. Bush said Gorbachev's action ``strengthens efforts to build enduring relationships based on cooperation.'' A senior White House official called Gorbachev's statement ``a big step. It seems quite significant that they have said for the first time that they are willing to see Germany unified in NATO.'' Another administration official said Gorbachev's successes at the recent Soviet Communist Party congress, where he strengthened himself politically, had put him in a stronger position to allow full German membership in NATO. ``It looks like he's coming around,'' the official said. Both officials, insisting on anonymity, noted there still are other problems facing German unity. Gorbachev announced his position in a joint statement with visiting West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Moscow's opposition to a united Germany in NATO had posed one of the biggest obstacles to German unification. Gorbachev had insisted that a unified Germany be neutral or a member of both the Western NATO alliance and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. However, the joint statement read by Kohl said, ``A unified Germany, in exercising its unrestricted sovereignty freely and by itself, decides if and which alliances to which it wants to belong.'' Kohl said he had told Gorbachev that a united Germany wants to be part of NATO, and that he was sure East Germany agreed. ``Unified Germany receives complete sovereignty,'' Gorbachev said. Bush, in his statement, said he welcomed Gorbachev's remarks. ``This comment demonstrates statesmanship and strengthens efforts to build enduring relationships based on cooperation,'' Bush said. The president said Gorbachev's action ``can be seen as a response, perhaps in part, to the outcome of the NATO summit in London where the alliance displayed its readiness to adapt to the new realities in Europe and reach out to former adversaries in the East.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in Paris for talks on Germany, said, ``We have to make sure that we see exactly what was agreed to.'' Otherwise, Baker was extremely enthusiastic. ``This is the right development for all of Europe,'' he said. In recognition of reduced East-West tensions, NATO agreed to tailor its nuclear and conventional forces to the rapidly shrinking military threat from Moscow. NATO also proposed a non-aggression declaration with members of the Warsaw Pact and declared that nuclear weapons would be used only as a last resort. Bush said the Helsinki Final Act, which ratified the post-war boundaries of Europe, guaranteed Germany's right to choose membership in the Western alliance. ``We think this solution is in the best interests of all the countries of Europe, including the Soviet Union,'' Bush said. At their summit last month, Gorbachev had told Bush that he was opposed to a united Germany belonging to the Western alliance. However, Gorbachev did not challenge Bush when the president said, ``we are in full agreement that the matter of alliance membership is, in accordance with the Helsinki Final Act, a matter for the Germans to decide.'' Based on that, administration officials began saying that Gorbachev was leaning toward acceptance of a united Germany in NATO. Baker said Gorbachev's move had been anticipated, but not until later in the summer. ``I think we should be optimistic that it would give significant impetus to the overall process'' of German unification, he said. Baker and Soviet Foreign Minster Eduard Shevardnadze will meet Tuesday in the third in a series of talks on German unification. The session will focus on Germany's border with Poland amid Polish concerns that a reunified Germany might try to recover territory it lost at the end of World War II. Prior to that, he will meet Tuesday with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Flooding In Texas And Nevada
LaserPhoto SA6
DOC.TEXT: San Antonio shopkeepers mopped mud out of their businesses Monday after storms dumped up to 14 inches of rain, stranding people in stalled cars and forcing evacuations elsewhere in south-central Texas. In the Nevada desert, flash flooding at Las Vegas killed one person, swept away 30 cars and forced evacuation of an apartment complex. Rain continued to fall Monday in San Antonio after the night of downpours. ``All over town in the low-lying areas they are evacuating people,'' said Jenny Garcia, a Dimmit County Sheriff's Department dispatcher in Carrizo Springs. ``All morning long it's been somebody stuck here, somebody stuck there.'' Evacuation shelters were set up in Zavala and Dimmit counties, where water closed several roads, authorities said. The National Weather Service said up to 14 inches of rain hit Alamo Plaza in San Antonio and 11.8 inches fell in the Harlandale section. Despite the downpours, San Antonio and other communities intended to enforce mandatory water rationing that took effect Sunday after weeks without rain. The rationing covers a three-county area served by the Edwards Aquifer, an underground water source for 1.3 million people. Downtown San Antonio shopkeepers arrived Monday to find merchandise swept away and water soaking what was left. ``It looks like a wall of water came down here, not just rising water,'' said Jim Ory, owner of a dress shop near San Pedro Creek. Ory and his employees rushed damaged wedding gowns to dry cleaners. At the Operation Friendship thrift store, workers threw out clothes. ``It's sewer water _ it smells something terrible,'' assistant manager Iris Dominguez said. ``Dozens and dozens'' of people around San Antonio were rescued from cars stalled during the night by deep water, said police assistant Sylvia Sneary. One mobile home washed into the San Saba River near Menard where authorities evacuated half a dozen people. In Kerrville and Leming, residents cleaned up from tornadoes that touched down Sunday in south-central Texas. Six people were slightly injured. South of San Antonio in Atascosa County, people in a mobile home park cleaned up Monday from a twister or twisters that demolished five mobile homes. No injuries were reported, said sheriff's department spokeswoman Ann Gates. The rain at Las Vegas was much less severe _ 2 inches in some parts of the Las Vegas Valley early Monday, the National Weather Service said. But rapid runoff on the sunbaked soil meant water ran up to 8 feet deep in some of the washes or shallow gulleys etched across the sloping city from west to east. Residents were evacuated from at least one apartment complex near the glitzy Strip of major casinos, and most major north-south roads were closed by water overflowing the washes before dawn. Bob Leinbach of the Clark County Fire Department said 30 cars swept away in washes were checked and there were no victims trapped inside. A woman's body was found in one wash, about a mile from her car, police said. There was heavy flooding behind the Imperial Palace, where water carried off cars and forced the evacuation of an apartment complex, said police Lt. Randy Oaks. ``This is the worst one we've had this year,'' said weather service spokesman Jim Smith. The storm did not faze gamblers. ``There were no gambling interruptions here _ none,'' said Debbie Munch, a spokeswoman for Caesar's Palace, across the street from the Imperial Palace. There was water and mud in the driveway, ``but that didn't even stop traffic,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Orders NASA Review
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 6th graf pvs `Adm. Truly ...' to UPDATE with comment from Truly. INSERTS 2 grafS after after 18th graf pvs `NASA needs ... to UPDATE with comment from Texas lawmaker. Picks up 19th graf pvs `Quayle discussed ...'
DOC.TEXT: Andrews' comment..

After a spate of recent NASA embarrassments, the Bush administration Monday ordered a review by outside experts of the nation's long-term space goals. ``Space continues to be a top priority for the administration,'' said a statement released by the office of Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads the National Space Council. ``We all want the best ideas on how we can move into the next century maintaining our leadership in space.'' The review by an outside task force was not as drastic a measure as the complete restructuring of the space agency, which had been forecast by some news media over the weekend. ``Contrary to some published reports, there is no White House investigation of NASA,'' the statement said. Quayle met for an hour Monday with NASA Administrator Richard H. Truly, their third meeting in a week. ``Adm. Truly and the task force will report their recommendations to the vice president,'' the statement said, but it was not clear whether Truly would head the panel or merely appoint it. Truly said in a statment that he was pleased that Quayle ``has expressed his confidence in NASA.'' The space agency's most recent embarrassments _ the myopic Hubble Space Telescope and a grounded space shuttle fleet _ have focused both public and congressional attention on NASA. Not since the Challenger accident of 1986, which claimed the lives of seven crew members, has the space agency been so under siege. Investigations so far have shown that the mistake in grinding the lenses of the $1.5 billion telescope would have been caught with proper testing. After Challenger, NASA appointed an internal investigating board. But President Reagan also appointed a 13-member commission of experts, headed by former Secretary of State William P. Rogers, which held hearings and published its voluminous findings. The commission called the Challenger explosion ``an accident rooted in history,'' and was highly critical of NASA for lax oversight, poor internal communications and pressures to launch. Nearly all the officials who ran NASA at the time of Challenger are gone from the agency. There were a number of outside investigations by Congress and by a panel of the National Research Council, which also oversaw the redesign of the shuttles' faulty booster rockets. Congress has been upset by the Hubble fiasco and by the concurrent hydrogen leaks that caused NASA to halt all shuttle flights. Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., chairwoman of the Senate appropriations subcommittee that has oversight responsibility for NASA, summoned Truly and former administrator James Beggs to a hearing Wednesday. Beggs had charge of the space agency a decade ago when the telescope was built. The problems come at a particularly bad time for NASA, which has had 10 successful shuttle missions since the Challenger explosion and a spate of spectacular successes with probes to the planets. ``Their plate is quite full, and it's a very stressful time for NASA,'' said Rep. Bob Traxler, D-Mich., chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the space and science budget. NASA needs congressional support to continue the $32 billion space station scheduled for a critical design review this year, a planned earth study called ``Mission to Planet Earth,'' and the president's announced goal of a permanent manned base on the moon and an expedition to Mars. Rep. Michael Andrews, D-Texas, was critical of the decision to name a blue-ribbon panel. ``What is needed is a definition of where we are going in space,'' said Andrews, whose district includes the Johnson Space Center. ``We don't need another commission to start defining those goals once again.'' Quayle discussed the problems with Truly twice last week, once aboard Air Force Two as he returned from the economic summit in Houston. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu took part in the airborne talks. Space News, a weekly industry newspaper, forecast in Monday's edition that a restructuring of NASA was in the works because of ``concern that a lack of public support for space and federal budget pressures make it difficult for NASA to carry out its missions'' and that the White House was concerned the problems are institutional rather than technical.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Acquits Clyburn of City Contractor on Bribery, Conspiracy Charges
With AM-Barry Trial
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Monday acquitted prominent District of Columbia contractor John B. Clyburn of four wide-ranging bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from his involvement in city contracting. Clyburn, a close friend of Mayor Marion Barry, had been accused of working to steer city contracts to his company and to the businesses of friends and then skimming money off the top. On Thursday, the same jury acquitted former top city official David Rivers of similar charges. Clyburn still faces two separate trials on related matters. Prosecutors portrayed Clyburn as a middleman between a company headed by an undercover FBI agent and Rivers. In court, the prosecutors said that Clyburn had worked with Rivers and other city officials to broker contract awards and influence jobs in the city's human services department, which Rivers headed, and other city agencies. Barry, who is on trial for drug and perjury charges, expressed delight at the verdict in Clyburn's case. ``The U.S. attorney's office has waged a long and underhanded campaign to discredit the minority business community in Washington,'' Barry said in a statement. ``They have failed.'' If he had been convicted of all the charges against him, Clyburn would have faced a maximum penalty of 50 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Dodge City Man Wins $35 Million from Lotto America
DOC.TEXT: Dodge City, that onetime rowdy cow town, has a modern resident with cause to go wild: the winner of the $35 million Lotto America jackpot, the largest single prize so far in the multistate lottery. Dave Wagner, vice president of a cabinetry concern, bought the $3 lottery ticket, worth six chances in the lottery, at a convenience store where he had stopped Thursday for a cup of coffee to go. Wagner, 48, was all smiles when he appeared at a crowded news conference at Kansas Lottery headquarters. He was accompanied by his wife, Carol, and two daughters, Jennifer, 17, and Courtney, 15, each holding a bouquet of long-stemmed roses. ``It still hasn't set in,'' said Wagner, a lifelong Kansan. He said travel, expanded educational opportunities for his two daughters and a new car or two are part of the plans he has for the money. His fondness for drawing could send him on a trip to Paris to try to become an artist, Wagner said. But for the time being, he intends to keep his job. Lottery Director Gerald Simpson said Wagner will receive his $35 million in 20 annual installments, minus income taxes. Wagner will receive his first check in the mail in about 15 days, he said, for $1.3 million. The largest U.S. lottery jackpot ever was given away in the Pennsylvania lottery on April 26, 1989, when $115 million was split by 14 winning tickets. Numerous other states have given out prizes upwards of $50 million. The Lotto America drawing was Saturday night, and on Sunday morning, while brewing coffee, Wagner picked up the newspaper and read the winning numbers, comparing them with those on his ticket. ``I just couldn't believe it,'' he said. ``I just kept looking over and over and over. I went to the bedroom where my wife was and said, `Come here, you're not going to believe this.' My hands were shaking.'' ``When he said, `I think we won,' I said, `No,''' Mrs. Wagner said. ``We just sat there and looked at each other and hugged,'' Wagner said. About four hours later, Wagner was hit on the head with a golf ball while playing in the Dodge City Golf Invitational, a wound that required five stitches. ``It made me wonder what was I doing out there,'' Wagner said. ``I was just nervous as all get-out.'' He said after going to a nearby hospital, he returned to finish the tournament. One of his fellow golfers commented to him how unusual the day had been, Wagner recalled. ``I thought, boy, you don't know the half of it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Allowed 13-Year-Old Girl to Drive Dies
DOC.TEXT: A man who let his 13-year-old niece drive a crowded station wagon died Monday, the fifth passenger to die after the car plunged into a rain-swollen creek. Four children were trapped in the submerged station wagon Saturday night and drowned. Donald Duncan, 27, who was pulled from the creek after about 20 minutes under water, died at Lancaster General Hospital, a spokeswoman said. The niece, Heather Cunrod, was driving and Duncan was in the passenger seat helping steer when the car overshot a parking lot and plunged into Pequea Creek, police said. The niece swam to shore. She was released Monday from the hospital, where officials refused to release information about her injuries. Duncan's sister, Shirley Leonard, said she had no idea why Duncan let the girl drive. ``Especially with all the kids in the car. He loved them,'' Mrs. Leonard said. Killed were Heather's 7-year-old sister, Jennifer, and 3-year-old brother, Timothy, and Duncan's 3-year-old son, Donald, and 6-year-old daughter, Jessica. Conestoga Township Police Chief Samuel Goss said the girl told him her uncle offered to let her drive, and everything was fine for several miles. ``Heather said she had never driven a car before, that this was her first experience behind the wheel,'' said Goss, adding that she wouldn't be charged with a crime. Duncan had apparently taken the children out for a treat, Goss said. A bucket from a McDonald's Happy Meal was found in the back of the station wagon. The girl was trying to park by a boat launching spot so the children could watch ducks, Goss said. The car entered the parking area at up to 45 mph and went into the creek, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding In Texas And Nevada
DOC.TEXT: Storms caused flooding early Monday in south-central Texas and in Las Vegas, Nev., and rain also was widely scattered over much of the rest of the nation. Ten inches of rain fell overnight near downtown San Antonio and across the southern section of the city, flooding highways and downtown businesses. Runoff caused flooding along the San Saba River. Water flowed up to 8 feet deep in the natural washes or shallow gulleys that run across Las Vegas, after up to 2 inches of rain fell on the sunbaked desert surface. At least 30 cars were washed away and one woman was killed. Showers and thunderstorms continued into the afternoon from central and eastern Texas across Louisiana and western Mississippi, over Florida, the Georgia coast, eastern South Carolina and eastern North Carolina. Showers and occasional thunderstorms were scattered over southern Maine, north-central and northwestern New York state, northern Indiana and northern Illinois, northern Wisconsin and south-central Upper Michigan, southeastern South Dakota, northern New Mexico, south-central through north-central Colorado, southeastern Wyoming, southeastern Arizona, central Nevada and California. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.62 inches at Palacios, Texas; 1.51 inches at Victoria, Texas; and 0.98 inch at Galveston, Texas. Relatively cool air washed across parts of the southern Plains. Record lows were posted at Abilene, Texas, at 64; Fort Smith, Ark., at 57, and San Antonio, Texas, at 64. Fort Myers, Fla., tied its record of 72. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 43 at Butte and West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 57 at Crescent City, Calif., to 98 at Palm Springs and Thermal, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Andrew Young Predicts Endorsement From Opponent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `Some black...,' to UPDATE with ruling on challenge to runoff rule not expected until Tuesday at the earliest.
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young predicted Monday he will pick up the endorsement of one of his chief white rivals if Tuesday's Democratic gubernatorial primary leaves him in a runoff with Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. Young, a former Atlanta mayor, United Nations ambassador and congressman who is bidding to become Georgia's first black governor, barnstormed the state Monday, as did Miller and state Sen. Roy Barnes. Barnes' campaign manager, Bobby Kahn, called Young's comment ``the height of arrogance.'' The candidates were wrapping up a gentlemanly campaign, free of negative advertising and racial appeals. Even former Gov. Lester Maddox, a longtime segregationist running a longshot campaign, de-emphasized race as an issue. Young insisted he doesn't put much trust in polls, which have shown Miller and Young in a close race well ahead of Barnes. But when asked who Barnes might support in a runoff, he was willing to answer. ``I think he'll endorse me,'' Young said. Barnes, who portrays Miller and Young as too liberal for Georgia, stoked endorsement speculation when he bumped into Young at a black church Sunday. ``I like Andy Young,'' Barnes told the congregation. ``I'm glad to be here with him today. I'm not too hot on Zell Miller.'' But Barnes said Monday he had not decided to endorse anyone and was not conceding defeat. ``Andy and I have deep philosophical differences,'' he said. He joked: ``I'm glad Andy's endorsing me.'' In a speech at Augusta, Miller raised the endorsement issue. ``Already, you've got candidates wanting to make deals like it's already over with,'' he said. ``Well it's not already over with. The people have not spoken.'' Georgia law provides for the top two finishers to meet in an Aug. 7 runoff unless someone wins a majority of Tuesday's votes. Some black leaders, acting without Young's support, have filed a lawsuit arguing the runoff system is unfair to blacks, who make up about 22 percent of the state's registered voters. They asked U.S. District Judge Richard Freeman to declare Tuesday's leader the Democratic nominee. Freeman's staff said he wouldn't issue a decision until Tuesday at the earliest. In speeches to supporters in Macon and Columbus, Young portrayed himself as the candidate who can pull Georgians together and Miller as a combative politician who ``doesn't get along with anybody.'' ``I don't get along with people?'' Miller replied later. ``On May 8 in Rome, Georgia, Andy Young said that if he were not running he would be for me for governor.'' Miller apparently was referring to a May 17 appearance by Young in Rome. The Rome News-Tribune reported at the time that Young said he'd vote for Miller if he wasn't running himself, and added: ``I would say that I'd make a better governor, but he's a great guy.'' Miller, meanwhile, reminded voters that he was the first major politician to endorse a state lottery, and that he engineered a sales tax exemption for some groceries. He repeated his promises to lift the sales tax from all groceries, to open more boot camps for first-time drug offenders and to cut auto insurance rates 10 percent. ``I've talked about things the people of Georgia can identify with,'' he told supporters in Albany. Barnes continued to portray himself as the conservative alternative to ``tax-and-spend liberals.'' Barnes, who has promised a tax cut, also is the only major candidate who supports new restrictions on abortion. As L. Douglas Wilder did in Virginia last year when he became the nation's first elected black governor, Young championed abortion rights. The most recent poll, released last week by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, found 36 percent of likely Democratic voters favoring Miller, 30 percent for Young and 16 percent for Barnes. State Rep. Lauren ``Bubba'' McDonald and Maddox trailed badly in the poll, which had a margin of error of 3 points. In Tuesday's Republican primary, polls have shown state Rep. Johnny Isakson with a commanding lead. The current governor, Democrat Joe Frank Harris, is completing his second term and cannot seek re-election. Three seats in the U.S. House also are being contested, but only one incumbent, Rep. Doug Barnard, has opposition in the primary. Barnard, a Democrat from Augusta, is a member of the House Banking Committee and has been accused by opponents of being too cozy with savings and loan officials. He faces journalism student Scott A. Starling of Athens. J.B. Stoner, a white supremacist who served time for the bombing of a black church in Alabama, is running for lieutenant governor, but is considered the longest shot of nine candidates in the Democratic primary.

DOC.HEAD: Western Nations Praise Gorbachev Acceptance of Germany in NATO
With AM-Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western nations on Monday praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's agreement to a united Germany belonging to NATO as being a turning point in European history and as helping stabilize the continent. In Britain, the Foreign Office said the decision was ``an extremely positive development in Soviet thinking.'' ``We have throughout argued that a united Germany in NATO would be in the best interests of all those concerned,'' the Foreign Office said in a statement. It added that Gorbachev was evidently swayed by a NATO summit meeting in London July 5-6 at which the 16 leaders of Western alliance committed themselves to limiting the size of the German army _ a prime Soviet concern. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization leaders also offered a non-aggression pact to the Soviet Union and other East European countries, and relegated nuclear arms to weapons of ``last resort.'' France, a major West European power that belongs to NATO but keeps its military forces outside the NATO command, made no immediate comment. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said he was waiting to hear the news personally from West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. In Rome, an Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman praised Gorbachev's position. ``At first glance we look on it with extreme favor,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Portugal's Defense Minister Fernando Nogueira said ``Portugal, as a founder member of NATO, is very happy with the announcement.'' Austria, which is not a member of NATO, said the agreement announced during a visit by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to Moscow was ``a historic hour for Europe and for the world.'' ``The long journey of European history in this century has reached a very positive station,'' said Austrian Chancellor Franz Vranitzky. ``(It is) the foundation for building a peaceful Europe.'' Sweden, another non-NATO member, said the agreement should also calm Soviet fears about German military might. The Soviet Union endured the heaviest casualties of any nation in World War II _ about 20 million people killed. ``We should not forget that for Gorbachev it means security that Germany is in NATO,'' Swedish Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson told the Swedish news agency TT. ``The Soviet Union paid a high price in the struggle against Nazi Germany and it has probably been regarded positive that Germany is with NATO, with the wider responsibility which the United States and other NATO countries have.''
