NATO, in a statement from its Brussels headquarters, said Gorbachev's acceptance of a unified Germany in the western alliance ``will increase stability for all ... including the Soviet Union.'' ``NATO has always strongly supported Germany's desire for unification, since unification means that the division of Europe is also being overcome,'' the statement said. ``Germany's membership in our alliance will increase stability for all. It is as much in the interests of the Germans as their neighbors in East and West, including the Soviet Union.'' In Bonn, the leader of Kohl's governing party said the decision marked a ``new high point'' in German-Soviet relations. ``There is nothing more standing in the way of the reunification of Germany in full sovereignty by the end of the year. The new Europe has taken on a concrete form,'' said Volker Ruehe, general-secretary of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, said: East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told West German television the most important outcome of the talks was that ``the question ... of full sovereignty for a united Germany has been secured.'' In the German view, this includes an end to all remaining rights over the now-divided nation by the four World War II victors, the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain. In Britain, the news from Moscow pushed another main story from the top of national newscasts _ the weekend resignation of Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley for saying Germany was trying to dominate Europe. He said yielding sovereignty to the European Community as tantamount to giving it to Hitler.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Hires Khashoggi Lawyer for Future Legal Affairs
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos, facing a welter of legal problems despite her acquittal on federal fraud charges, hired her former co-defendant's attorney Monday to represent her in future court proceedings. James P. Linn, who successfully defended Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi in the case that ended July 2, said he agreed to take over ``all legal affairs'' of the former Philippine first lady. In a telephone interview, Mrs. Marcos said she was urged to hire Linn by Gerry Spence, the Wyoming attorney who represented her in the fraud trial, earning a $5 million fee. The Justice Department has ordered Mrs. Marcos to testify Sept. 25 before a federal grand jury in Pittsburgh investigating a nuclear power plant built in the Philippines by the Westinghouse Electric Co. The plant was built in the early 1980s when Mrs. Marcos' late husband, Ferdinand Marcos, was president, but was never operated because of alleged safety concerns. It is also the subject of a civil suit against Westinghouse by the present Philippine government, which claims the Marcoses accepted kickbacks in exchange for allowing construction of the plant. Mrs. Marcos said over the weekend that she had no knowledge of the case and no papers concerning the plant. Linn said Mrs. Marcos would testify unless the government advised her that she is a target of the criminal investigation. Mrs. Marcos also is involved in a number of civil cases in which the government of President Corazon Aquino seeks to recover millions of dollars allegedly stolen by Marcos during his 20 years in power. In the fraud case, the federal court jury rejected the prosecution's claim that Mrs. Marcos participated in her husband's financial dealings, or that Khashoggi had falsified documents to help the Marcoses conceal their holdings in New York real estate and artworks. Linn, a former West Texas prosecutor who now lives in Oklahoma City, led Khashoggi's defense team and will command a multimillion-dollar fee for representing Mrs. Marcos. Like Spence's fee, the costs will be paid by tobacco heiress Doris Duke, a friend of Mrs. Marcos, Linn said. Neither Linn nor Mrs. Marcos would divulge the amount. She said the change in lawyers had nothing to do with the controversy that swirled around Spence, who triggered numerous rebukes from U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan during the trial. ``Mr. Spence had to go back to Wyoming where he has three criminal cases, and he suggested Mr. Linn to take over all our cases,'' Mrs. Marcos said. ``Mr. Spence was a good lawyer, and it takes a lawyer to know another good one.'' In another development, the Aquino goverment, which has barred Mrs. Marcos' return, apparently wants to keep her half-sister, a Roman Catholic nun, out of the country as well. In a cable filed July 11, the Philippine foreign ministry asked the Philippine mission to the United Nations to add Dulce Romualdez, known in her religious order as Sister Bellarmine, to a ``hold-order list.'' If carried out, the instruction would mean that Sister Bellarmine could not obtain a visa to return to the Philippines. Spokesmen for the Philippine consulate here said they hadn't seen the order. Sister Bellarmine was among the coterie of 50 or so Marcos supporters who attended the 10-week trial. She has lived with Mrs. Marcos since shortly before Ferdinand Marcos died last September.

DOC.HEAD: Disbarment Sought of Former Gov. Arch Moore
DOC.TEXT: The State Bar's Committee on Legal Ethics on Monday filed a petition seeking to disbar former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. because of his conviction on political corruption charges. Moore pleaded guilty May 8 to felony charges of extortion, tax fraud, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. A federal judge refused Moore's request to withdraw his guilty plea and sentenced him July 10 to 5 years, 10 months in federal prison and fined him $170,000. The three-term Republican governor is scheduled to enter the Petersburg (Va.) Federal Correctional Institution July 31. State Supreme Court Clerk Ancil Ramey said a hearing probably would be set on the petition in September. Moore signed an agreement to plead guilty to a five-count federal indictment April 12, the same day the grand jury charged him with one count each of extortion, mail fraud and obstruction of justice, and two counts of tax fraud. The indictment said Moore extorted $573,000 from coal operator H. Paul Kizer. In return, the governor helped Kizer's coal companies obtain a $2.1 million refund from the state's black lung fund, which pays benefits to miners with the respiratory disease.

DOC.HEAD: Man Describes Dismemberment of Teen-ager
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `His 15-year-old ...' to UPDATE with cousin charged as adult for the killing. Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A young man accused of killing and dismembering a 15-year-old runaway said he didn't realize the implications of what he'd done until he showed a friend a gruesome souvenir, a newspaper reported. The souvenir was the severed and skinned head of Stephanie Dubay. ``I went to the freezer and got it. It was still warm,'' Jaime Rodriguez Jr. told The Detroit News in a telephone interview from the suburban Macomb County Jail. The female friend took the head to police headquarters in Warren. ``When I finally realized what I had done was when she left with the head,'' he told the newspaper. Rodriguez, 21, was being held without bond on charges of first-degree murder, conspiracy to commit first-degree murder and mutilation of a human body in Wednesday's slaying. His A 15-year-old cousin, Augustine Pena, was arraigned as an adult Monday in 37th District Court on one count each of first-degree murder, conspiracy to commit murder and mutilation of a human body. Dubay, 15, of Clinton Township, was reported missing June 26. She had briefly shared a Warren home with Rodriguez, the cousin and the cousin's mother after running away from home. Rodriguez told The News that he has been involved in satanism for about six years. But he said Dubay was slain on a whim, not as part of any ritual, the newspaper reported Sunday. ``Me and my cousin were sitting at the table Wednesday morning,'' Rodriguez said, according to the newspaper. ``He said, `Let's kill Steph.' I said, `You serious?' He said, `Yeah.''' Rodriguez said he and his cousin went to the basement and placed newspapers on the floor ``in case there was a mess.'' He said his cousin went upstairs, woke Dubay and brought her to the basement, where he held her by the neck while the cousin stabbed her, the newspaper reported. Rodriguez said neither he nor his cousin verbally suggested the dismemberment. ``We just read each other's minds and went for it,'' Rodriguez said. Dubay was decapitated, her head skinned and placed in the freezer. The index finger was severed from her right hand, which also had been removed. ``I wanted a finger for a charm, to wear around my neck. It has something to do with my beliefs, but not really. ... It's something else, really, that I don't want to talk about.'' But Rodriguez spoke in general terms about his involvement with satanism: ``I guess I needed a new god. God gave up on me, so I gave up on Him and went out and found a new god, one that would love me.'' Records show that on Aug. 30, 1987, Rodriguez's mother fatally shot herself at their Saginaw home. Conviction on both the murder and conspiracy charges is punishable by life in prison; mutilation carries up to 10 years' imprisonment. Rodriguez said he expected to spend the rest of his life in prison, but he expressed no remorse over the slaying. ``I've come close to this feeling,'' he told The News. ``It's not a feeling of pity or remorse or anything like that. It's not like I'm feeling bad inside for it. I'm not happy for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Frees British Nurse Held in Spy Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with nurse's arrival in Zambia, quotes, details, background. CORRECTS Zambia southern African, not central African country. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraq freed British nurse Daphne Parish from a Baghdad prison in a surprise move Monday after she served four months of a 15-year sentence for helping a journalist who was hanged as a spy. Britain hailed the release and said it hoped this was a turning point in the two countries' checkered relations. Mrs. Parish, 53, freed after pleas from President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, flew in a private jet to Lusaka, capital of that southern African nation. Zambian officials and Iraqi diplomats presented the smiling nurse with a bouquet of red and yellow roses; she was driven from the airport in a luxury car to spend the night at Kaunda's official residence. In Baghdad, Deputy Foreign Minister Nizar Hamdoun said President Saddam Hussein decided to release Mrs. Parish ``in response to an overture from President Kaunda and for purely humanitarian reasons.'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expressed delight at Monday's development, and was grateful to presidents Saddam and Kaunda, a Thatcher spokesman said. Mrs. Parish was arrested in September after driving Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian-born reporter for the London newspaper The Observer to the Al-Iskandaria military installation outside Baghdad. The Observer said Bazoft, who lived in Britain and traveled on British documents, was trying to check out reports of an explosion. But Iraq said he was a spy and hanged him on March 15. Iraq later confirmed 19 people died in an explosion at a military installation on Aug. 17. Mrs. Parish worked at Baghdad's Ibn al-Bitar hospital on a contract. Bazoft befriended her on a previous visit to Iraq. The Foreign Office said Mrs. Parish made a brief statement before leaving Iraq, saying her treatment in prison was good and she was grateful to Saddam and Kaunda. Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said he hoped the release was a diplomatic ``turning point.'' ``I hope our relations, which are always liable to be a bit bumpy with Iraq for historical reasons, are aimed in the right direction again,'' he said. In April, British authorities seized huge steel tubes that were bound for Baghdad. Officials said the parts, ordered from British companies, could be used to make a ``super gun'' capable of hurling shells as far as Israel. Iraq said the tubes were for an oil pipeline. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd appealed to Iraq on Monday to follow up Mrs. Parish's release by freeing British businessman Ian Richter, who is serving a life sentence in Iraq after being convicted of bribery three years ago. News of her release stunned Mrs. Parish's family. ``It was just incredible,'' said her daughter, Michelle de Vries, 22, who returned this week from visiting her mother in Baghdad's Rashid Abu Ghraib prison. ``We had no idea. Mummy had resigned herself to the fact she was going to be there for a long time.'' Miss de Vries spoke in a radio interview. Britain recalled its ambassador, expelled six Iraqi military cadets, froze official visits and canceled a trade mission in protest after Bazoft's execution. British-Iraq relations took another dive when customs officers seized 40 components that could be used as nuclear bomb triggers at Heathrow airport, before they could be put aboard an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad. Zambian officials were expected to welcome positive publicity from Kaunda's mediating role. Food riots and a bungled coup attempt by mutinous soldiers on June 30, which came during calls for a return to multiparty democracy last month, left 26 people dead in one of Africa's most debt-ridden nations. Most of the dead were hit by police and army gunfire.

DOC.HEAD: Former Senator Tower Heads Revamped Intelligence Board
DOC.TEXT: President Bush named former Sen. John Tower of Texas as chairman of his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board on Monday and replaced all other Reagan-era members of the panel. In a major overhaul, Bush also cut the size of the presidential board from its current size of 15 members to six. Tower, who was unsuccessfully nominated by Bush as secretary of defense last year, was the only holdover member of the board. He now works as a consultant in Dallas. Among those removed were chairman Anne L. Armstrong, the former ambassador to Britain; former Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger; former Attorney General William French Smith; Zbigniew Brezinski, who was national security adviser for President Carter; former United Nations Ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick and former Tennessee senator and White House chief of staff Howard Baker. The new board, composed entirely of defense and foreign policy experts, consists of: Lew Allen Jr., former chief of staff of the Air Force and now vice president of the California Institute of Technology; John M. Deutch, provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and onetime undersecretary of energy; William G. Hyland, editor of Foreign Affairs, the quarterly publication of the Council on Foreign Relations. Also, Bobby Ray Inman, onetime deputy director of the CIA and now a consultant in Austin, Texas; William J. Perry, former Pentagon research chief and now chairman and chief executive officer of Technology Strategies and Alliances in Menlo Park, Calif., and Tower. Since taking office 18 months ago, Bush had not altered the board makeup from the members appointed by former President Reagan. The changes were announced in a routine personnel announcement that did not offer any comments by Bush. The board is charged with assessing the quality, quantity and adequacy of intelligence collection, analysis and estimates. It also evaluates counter-intelligence work. Members of the board serve without pay and are required to report at least semi-annually.

DOC.HEAD: Company Bids to Build Vegas To Los Angeles Train
DOC.TEXT: A partnership made a formal bid Monday on a $5 billion high-speed train system that would whisk riders from Southern California to the casinos of the Strip in little more than an hour. The partnership headed by Bechtel International Inc. of San Francisco proposed the first commercial use of magnetically levitated trains that would run up to 300 mph on an about 270-mile line between Las Vegas and Anaheim. The bid for exclusive franchise rights was hailed as a milestone for the project, which was first proposed in 1979. ``We feel we are about to revolutionize ground transportation in the United States,'' said Arnie Adamsen, chairman of the California-Nevada Super Speed Train Commission. ``We believe we have overcome the last true hurdle in bringing this system into being.'' Bechtel officials gave the commission a $500,000 deposit along with a three-inch-thick proposal that calls for a two-way train that would glide atop an elevated guideway running alongside existing highways between the two metropolitan areas. The train could have commuter stops in Southern California, and Bechtel proposed possible spurs that could also eventually link the system to Palmdale, Palm Springs, Riverside and Santa Ana. If Bechtel gets financing and overcomes other obstacles, construction would begin in 1993, with the system up and running four years later. ``We see this as a pilot system that will be the first part of a network that will eventually encompass the Southwest and the nation,'' said Erv Koenig, a Bechtel vice president. The train would follow Interstate 15 from Las Vegas to Southern California, where it would run alongside the Santa Ana River Channel into a final destination at Anaheim Stadium south of Los Angeles. But the project faces enormous hurdles, including its huge price tag and uncertainty over whether it would attract enough riders to be profitable. Since the mid-1980s, the estimated cost of the project has risen from $2.5 billion to $5.1 billion. Bechtel is gambling not only that it can raise the huge amount of money needed to privately finance the system, but also on the use of maglev technology. The maglev system, which uses a magnetic field to propel the train and to elevate it one to four inches above the guideway, is being tested in West Germany but has not entered commercial use. Before deciding whether to actually build the train, Bechtel plans to spend about 16 months on ridership studies. A ridership survey done for the commission said an Anaheim to Las Vegas run would get a 6.5 million round trip passengers a year paying $110 a ticket. The idea of a speedy train linking Las Vegas with the Southern California market that provides most of it 18 million tourists each year was first raised in 1979 by then-Mayor Bill Briare. The train commission was established in 1988, after a study showed the project was feasible.

DOC.HEAD: New Footage Uncovered from Uncompleted Monroe Film
DOC.TEXT: Footage from Marilyn Monroe's last film shows the star never missed a cue, contradicting reports that she was in a drug-induced stupor during the last weeks of her life, according to TV Guide. Fox Entertainment News is scrambling to prepare footage from ``Something's Got to Give,'' for a prime-time special tentatively scheduled to air Aug. 4, the 28th anniversary of Monroe's death, the magazine reported in its July 21 edition. Those who have seen the footage say Monroe never missed a cue, the magazine reported. But others interviewed for the special said Monroe, who died of a drug overdose before the movie was finished, was losing control of her private life during filming. The film was never completed.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fake Gang Member's Death In Murder-For-Hire Sting
DOC.TEXT: Police faked the murder of a gang member, using makeup to create a gunshot wound and photographing the ``death'' scene in order to arrest a man accused in a murder-for-hire plot, authorities said. The 24-year-old gang member, identified only as David, underwent a two-hour makeup job to create a fake bullet wound on his left temple and was photographed lying in the trunk of a car during the sting operation Thursday, police said. The gang member had approached police after he learned he was marked for death for allegedly stealing drug profits, said Sgt. Don Korte. Warren Krugman, 47, was arrested early Friday after paying an undercover agent who showed him a photo of the ``dead'' gang member, police said. Krugman paid an eighth of an ounce of cocaine to the agent hired as the gunman, police said. ``Murder for about $500 worth of cocaine. Who said life isn't cheap?'' said Mark Shaffer, a U.S. Treasury's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agent who posed as the hitman. The arrest capped a month-long investigation by Chicago police and Treasury agents, police said. Krugman was charged with transfer of a firearm to commit a violent crime and with using firearms in connection with a drug transfer, Korte said. If convicted on all charges, Krugman could face 25 years in prison. He was ordered held without bond at Chicago's Metropolitan Correctional Center until his next hearing Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Drop Objection to German Membership in NATO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 15 `The rights' to explain allied rights. Picks up 16th pvs, `Kohl had...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOS24
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Monday dropped its objection to a united Germany's membership in NATO, clearing one of the most difficult remaining hurdles to German unification. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced the agreement in a televised news conference from Gorbachev's home region, Stavropol in southern Russia. The area was one of the deepest points of German penetration during World War II. The announcement capped several months of intense diplomatic maneuvering, during which Germany backed a $3 billion bank loan to Moscow and pushed its allies for a comprehensive plan to bail out the crumbling Soviet economy. The agreement, reached in just two days of talks in Moscow and at a country home in Arkhyz in the Caucasus Mountains, made it likely the two German states could complete unification by December. ``A unified Germany, in exercising its unrestricted sovereignty freely and by itself, decides if and which alliances to which it wants to belong,'' Kohl said, reading a joint statement. He said he had told Gorbachev a united Germany wants to be part of NATO, and that he was sure East Germany agreed. ``Unified Germany receives complete sovereignty,'' Gorbachev told the news conference. ``It has the right to use this sovereignty to make its choice ... meaning its variant of social development, and meaning what it would like to be a part of, what blocs to support.'' In Washington, President Bush praised Gorbachev's remarks. ``This comment demonstrates statesmanship and strengthens efforts to build enduring relationships based on cooperation,'' Bush said in a written statement. The British Foreign Office called the Soviet change ``an extremely positive development in Soviet thinking.'' Kohl and Gorbachev also reached agreement on other contentious issues: _They agreed to begin negotiations on the complete withdrawal of Soviet soldiers from what is now East German territory. The approximately 380,000 soldiers should be withdrawn in three to four years, they said. _The army of a united Germany, during the same period, will be reduced to 370,000 soldiers. Currently, the two Germanys have about 600,000 men under arms, 480,000 in the West. _No NATO forces will be stationed on the territory of what is now East Germany while Soviet forces still are there. But German soldiers not integrated into the NATO command may be stationed there as soon as unification is completed. _The rights of the four victorious World War II powers _ France, the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union _ will cease immediately upon unification. Such rights include military patrols and control of air traffic in Berlin. But Western forces may remain in Berlin as long as Soviet soldiers stay in any part of the country. Kohl had been expected to make some progress on the NATO issue in his talks with Gorbachev, but had not been expected to be able to wrap up the entire agreement during this visit, the second to Moscow since February. Although there are no such guarantees in the agreement, Gorbachev said the Soviet Union hopes that after it withdraws from East German territory ``nuclear weapons will not appear, foreign soldiers will not appear, so that the budding trust, the responsibility we have toward each other and toward Europeans, can be preserved.'' The Soviet Union says that more than 20 million of its citizens died as a result of the German invasion in World War II, and for years afterwards worries about a new German threat were cultivated in the Soviet media. As the two German states raced toward reunification after the collapse last fall of the hard-line East German government led by Erich Honnecker, Soviet objections to NATO membership had remained one of the main obstacles. East Germany had been one of the linchpins of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, and one of Moscow's main trading partners. The Soviet Union first demanded that a unified Germany be neutral, then recently approved the idea of an unspecified associate membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. That position was rejected by West Germany and its allies. They had insisted that Germany be a full NATO member. The United States argued that a united Germany would present less of a threat to the Soviet Union if it was anchored in the Western alliance. Recently, the Warsaw Pact has announced its intention to transform itself from a military to a political organization. NATO responded at its London summit by reducing its reliance on nuclear weapons, reviewing the size of its forces and its military strategy. Kohl said the two governments would work out an agreement on the details of the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers from East Germany, and on the introduction of the West German mark into what is now East Germany during the withdrawal. The Soviet Union is concerned about the financial status of its army on German soil. It has had agreements with East German concerning the convertibility of its currency, but has none with West Germany. East Germany began using the West German mark earlier this month, and theoretically this could leave Soviet soldiers in East Germany without money.

DOC.HEAD: Abul Abbas Torpedoes Move to Resume PLO-US Dialogue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th pvs `(Arafat's) in' to ADD State Department statement. Picks up 6th pvs, `President Bush ...'
DOC.TEXT: Radical Palestinian leader Abul Abbas has torpedoed a PLO plan aimed at reviving its dialogue with Washington, suspended last month after an attack on Israel by his guerrillas, senior PLO sources said Monday. The officials, speaking by telephone from Tunis on condition of anonymity, said that under a compromise proposed by Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid, Abbas, whose real name is Mohammed Abbas, would resign from the Palestine Liberation Organization's ruling Executive Committee. Washington would then resume the dialogue with the PLO through Ambassador Robert Pelletreau Jr. in Tunis, and within a few weeks elevate the level of contacts, the sources said. But Abbas, leader of the Palestine Liberation Front, one of nine guerrilla factions in the PLO under Chairman Yasser Arafat, rejected the proposal, the sources said. ``(Arafat's) in a corner,'' a senior PLO official said by telephone. ``If he acts against Abul Abbas he'll appear to be bowing to America and incense the radicals in the movement even further. If he doesn't, the dialogue will remain severed.'' In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said, ``We have stated very clearly what we think has to happen before we can resume the dialogue. Those things have not changed.'' President Bush suspended the 18-month-old dialogue June 20 after Arafat made no apparent move to punish Abbas as Washington demanded. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said June 28 that his government was trying to mediate a resumption of the dialogue. Egyptian Foreign Ministry sources confirmed that the effort is still under way. The United States agreed to talk to the PLO after Arafat publicly renounced terrorism and recognized Israel in December 1988. The Americans had refused any contacts with the PLO until Arafat met those conditions. The dialogue was at the time seen as a major breakthrough in the tortuous Middle East peace process. But Israel opposed it, as did many Palestinian radicals inside and outside the PLO. In the May 30 attack, Libyan-based PLF guerrillas in rubber boats tried to land at a beach near Tel Aviv. Israeli forces intercepted them, killing four guerrillas and capturing 12. There were no Israeli casualties. Arafat's renunciation of terrorism involved halting attacks on civilians, but not necessarily on military targets. Abbas said the guerrillas were aiming for a military target in Israel even though they landed on a civilian beach. The sources said Abbas was to have submitted his resignation at a meeting of the PLO's Central Council scheduled for July 18 in Baghdad, capital of Iraq. When he refused to do so during the weekend, the PLO postponed the meeting. The PLF's chief spokesman in Baghdad, where Abbas has his main offices, said when asked if his leader planned to resign: ``This is a baseless report. ``It's a fabricated story by the United States and its cronies,'' Hussein el-Abid said. The Central Council is an 80-seat mini-legislature. Its members are drawn from the 450-seat Palestine National Council, the PLO's parliament-in-exile. The Central Council oversees implementation of resolutions passed by the PNC, which usually meets once a year to map out PLO strategy and elect the Executive Committee. The Central Council has no power to dismiss any of the 15 members of the Executive Committee members. If one tenders his resignation, the council can accept it, but cannot appoint a replacement.

DOC.HEAD: Two Wounded by Dominican Police in Anti-Government Protests
DOC.TEXT: Protesters exploded homemade bombs and battled riot police Monday in demonstrations over President Joaquin Balaguer's disputed re-election. Two protesters suffered gunshot wounds in separate clashes with police in provincial cities, according to radio and newspaper reports. In the capital Santo Domingo, police in riot gear fired tear gas to disperse students who burned tires near the state university. No injuries were reported in the riot that reportedly involved students hurling garbage at police. The demonstrations were part of a 48-hour period of ``national mourning'' organized by Juan Bosch's opposition Dominican Liberation Party to protest Balaguer's victory over Bosch in the May 16 general election. Gen. Jose Ramon Mota Paulino, chief of the national police, said the Caribbean island-nation of 7 million people had returned to normal by midday, but soldiers were placed on alert. In Azua, 62 miles west of the capital, one youth was shot during clashes with police, dozens of demonstrators were arrested and some allegedly beaten, the newspaper Ultima Hora said. Radio Popular, an independent station, said a second man was wounded by shotgun bellets fired by police at rock-throwing protesters in San Francisco de Macoris, 75 miles northwest of the capital. Bosch, 81, a former leftist president ousted in a military coup in 1963, has accused Balaguer's Social Christian Reformist Party of widespread voter fraud and has refused to acknowledge the incumbent's victory. After a review of tally sheets, the Central Electoral Board announced Friday that Balaguer defeated Bosch by less than 2 percent: 678,268 to 653,434, making it the closest presidential race in Dominican history. The conservative Balaguer, 83 and blind, has served five previous terms as president.

DOC.HEAD: President-Elect Gaviria Promises to Fight Medellin Poverty
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Cesar Gaviria promised Monday to fight poverty in Medellin slums where drug traffickers are hiring teen-agers as assasins. Colombia must find social solutions to the wave of terror sweeping Medellin, Gaviria said at a news conference. It was his first public appearance since returning Sunday from Europe, the United States and Venezuela. He met with President Bush during his trip to Washington last week. ``The country's gravest problem now is violence in Medellin, and this will require special treatment from my government, a treatment that transcends just military, police and public order measures,'' he said. An estimated 3,000 people have been murdered in the city this year. With 2 million people, Medellin is Colombia's second-largest city after the capital of Bogota and is home to the Medellin drug cartel. Officials say drug terrorists are responsible for the murders of about 150 policemen in metropolitan Medellin this year. Gaviria, who becomes Colombia's next president on Aug. 7, said the government will have to attack the city's poverty if it hopes to make a dent in drug-related violence. Drug barons often hire teen-agers _ known here as sicarios _ from Medellin's poor neighborhoods to carry out their campaigns of bombings and assassinations. ``We must establish programs to rehabilitate not only young sicarios, but also all the young people who form part of the subculture of violence,'' Gaviria said. However, the president-elect said eliminating drug trafficking was a longterm problem requiring international cooperation to reduce drug consumption and help cocaine-producing countries find alternative livelihoods, he said. He added that the drug raids now taking place in northeastern Colombia have not been a failure, as suggested in many news reports. Last week about 2,000 policemen and soldiers began combing the area in search of Pablo Escobar, reputed head of the Medellin cocaine cartel. Police said they had Escobar surrounded, but the fugitive billionaire drug lord managed to slip away for the third time in a year.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Checked for Chest Pains, Released from Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Singer Harry Belafonte was admitted to a hospital Monday after complaining of chest pains, but tests showed the pains weren't caused by heart problems and he was released, a hospital spokeswoman said. ``They checked his heart and it was very strong and very healthy,'' said Pat Story, spokeswoman for the 61-year-old singer. ``They think it must have been a muscular spasm from stress or he may have sprained the muscle.'' The entertainer went to the emergency room at Los Gatos Community Hospital south of San Francisco after waking up with chest pains early Monday, and transferred to Good Samaritan Hospital here. Belafonte underwent a test that showed he was free of heart problems, Blanche Gibberson, spokeswoman for Good Samaritan. Belafonte performed during the weekend at the Paul Masson winery in Saratoga south of San Francisco. The singer canceled a Friday show due to a throat ailment, but gave his scheduled performance on Sunday, a winery spokeswoman said. Story said the entertainer planned to return to New York on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: 10,000 LA Commuters Take a Ride on the Blue Line
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with ridership figures, quote from commuter. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `The $877 million...
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in nearly three decades, Los Angeles area residents Monday rode a commuter train to their downtown offices. On the system's first business day, the Long Beach-to-Los Angeles trains carried at least 10,000 riders, who used tickets given away free. The 22-mile system started Saturday with a gala attracting thousands. ``They had their little briefcases and were reading their papers on the way in,'' said sheriff's Lt. Jim Holts with transit security. ``It is an unusual sight in Los Angeles.'' Among the commuters was Ken Mattfeld of Long Beach, who normally takes the bus to work. ``The train is a lot more civilized than the bus,'' said Mattfeld. ``I think I'll stick with this.'' Throughout the day, there were no mechanical problems and only one security problem, an apparently drunken man who couldn't figure out how to get off the tracks, said Holts. The $877 million Blue Line marks the first stage of a 150-mile rail system planned over the next century in Los Angeles, an ambitious effort to pry Southern Californians from their beloved, exhaust-belching cars. The $10 billion system includes the $1.3 billion Metro Rail subway, where a fire erupted Friday in a maintenance tunnel under construction and closed part of the busy Hollywood Freeway overhead. Only two lanes were open on the artery through the city's heart, but traffic was light throughout the morning rush hour, said Margie Tiritilli, a spokeswoman for the state transportation Department. The Blue Line is the first light-rail service from Long Beach to Los Angeles since the Pacific Electric Red Cars stopped operating in 1961, but the technologically advanced Blue Line bears little resemblance to its noisy ancestor. The Blue Line's sleek, Japanese-built overhead-powered cars move quietly. Each 87-foot-long, air-conditioned car can hold 230 people. The large percentage of Blue Line commuters Monday pleased officials with the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, which built the line. But officials noted the true test comes Aug. 1, when tickets go on sale for $1.10, and in the next six months to a year, when the system's novelty wears off. ``It's going to be a very long slow process to convince the Los Angeles motorist to give up his automobile and gridlocked freeways and give these trains a chance,'' said transportation commission spokeswoman Stephanie Brady.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Two in Jordan's First Bank Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday arrested two Spanish men and seized $15,000 from their apartment in what police said was Jordan's first bank robbery. Amman police chief, Brig. Ghaleb Zoubi, said the holdup took place at the British Grindleys Bank in Marka, near Amman. The robbery was ``a unique case since it is the first in the history of the Kingdom,'' Zoubi said. The independent Kingdom of Jordan was established in 1946. One of the alleged robbers is Spanish by birth and the other is a Spaniard of Jordanian origin, Zoubi told reporters. He declined to identify them. He said the bank raid occurred at midday Sunday _ banks are open Sunday in Jordan _ and noted both men were arrested ``less than 24 hours later.'' In Jordan banks close on Friday, the Moslem holy day. The suspects ``were followed all day Monday and we finally decided to raid their homes, where we found the stolen money,'' Zoubi said in a news conference. He said police seized almost $15,000, which was stolen from the bank when one ``English-speaking and bad-tempered man pointed the gun at the bank's clerk and asked him to fill his black bag with all the money in the cash register.'' According to Jordanian law, non-Jordanians are usually deported from the country after serving their sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Somali Rulers Announce Referendum on Elections
DOC.TEXT: Somalia's government said Monday multiparty elections will be held in seven months and that it also has ordered a referendum on a new constitution. An announcement over the state radio, broadcast from the Somali capital, Mogadishu, and monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp., said the government also sought reconciliation with opposition groups. It said the referendum will be Oct. 31 and the long-pledged parliamentary and local elections Feb. 1. Somalia on the Horn of Africa is one of the world's poorest countries with a largely nomadic population of 5.8 million. The radio said the Cabinet on Thursday endorsed ``implementation of the democratization of the country's political system'' but did not explain why the announcement was delayed. ``The government ... will as a matter of urgency appoint a committee to seek peace and reconciliation with opposition groups,'' the radio said. Membership of the committee and its powers had still to be determined, the report added. It said two ministerial committees were being set up to make a ``serious study of the country's internal and external policies and the economy'' and make recommendations to the government. The radio said the government appointed a committee to prepare a law covering parties and elections for presentation to the People's Assembly. After army Maj. Gen. Mohamed Siad Barre seized power in a 1969 coup, the country was racked by a long territorial conflict with neighboring Ethiopia. From May 1988, fighting raged in the north between the government and the opposition Somali National Movement, with 400,000 people fleeing to Ethiopia to escape the combat. Thousands more refugees fled to Kenya after fighting in the south between government forces and the Somali Patriotic Movement. The government said last August that political parties other than the governing Somali Revolutionary Socialist Party would be permitted to contest the next parliamentary elections. Amnesty International, the human rights organization based in London, reported last week that despite the release of hundreds of political prisoners, hundreds more remained in jail. It accused Somlai authorities of extrajudicial executions, torture and other ill-treatment of prisoners. It said more than 200 people were shot in Mogadishu during anti-government demonstrations last July.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Thrift To Repay $18 Million To Federal Government
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Monday a Florida savings and loan association had agreed to pay more than $18 million to settle charges that it falsely billed the Department of Education for student loans. The settlement calls for Florida Federal Savings Bank of St. Petersburg to pay $17.89 million in restitution. In addition, the thrift must pay $150,000 to release most bank officers and employees from liability, the Justice Department said. Florida Federal and one of its former officers were convicted May 2 of 43 counts of mail fraud, conspiracy and filing false claims. The thrift was fined $2.15 million, which is separate from the sum agreed to in Monday's civil settlement. The department said in a statement that Florida Federal had falsely claimed it had attempted to collect delinquent student loans. ``Because Florida Federal made little or no attempt to collect the loans it issued, thousands of students were unfairly tagged as delinquent borrowers. Part of this settlement insures that they will be vindicated,'' said Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general in charge of the department's Civil Division, said in a statement. As part of the settlement, Florida Federal agreed to correct the credit records of students against whom it had reported adverse information. In addition to sending letters to credit bureaus, the institution must advertise in local newspapers its willingness to correct credit ratings, the agency said. The department said the areas covered by the newspaper advertising will be St. Petersburg, Tampa, Orlando, Tallahassee, Gainesville and Pensacola. Florida Federal will pay a majority of the $17.89 million by agreeing not to accept legitimate reimbursements from the Education Department. That process, which began several months ago, is nearly complete, the agency said. In the May criminal case, Robert Harmas, former vice president of the institution's student loan division, received a two-year prison sentence. Another Florida Federal official, James LaMantia, was convicted on 30 counts of fraud and sentenced to three years probation. A third former official, Jeffrey Flatten, has been indicted on 25 counts and is awaiting trial. Florida Federal has been under the supervision of the Office of Thrift Supervision for the last several months, although federal regulators have not formally assumed control.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Willing to Talk to Gorbachev Foes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 7-8: ``Polish Foreign,'' to CORRECT name from Skubiszeski to Skubiszewski
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is prepared to open a dialogue with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's sharpest critics if they form a legitimate non-communist opposition, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Monday. Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federated Republic, led the Gorbachev foes who quit the Communist Party during the 28th party congress in Moscow last week and began forming a national opposition coalition. Baker said it wasn't clear whether Yeltsin and the others who quit the party ``are going to develop any kind of multiparty democracy.'' ``We don't know yet if that is going to happen,'' Baker said. ``If it does happen, we ought to approach it as we have in other countries.'' Baker expects to get a report on the congress during a meeting Wednesday in Paris with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. On Tuesday, Baker and Shevardnadze will participate in the third in a series of talks on German unification. The session will focus on Germany's border with Poland amid Polish concerns that a reunified Germany might try to recover territory it lost at the end of World War II. Polish Foreign Minister Krystof Skubiszewski said in Paris on Monday that his government agrees that German unification must precede a treaty dealing with the German-Polish border. Skubiszewski said Poland would not insist that such a treaty be in place before the four World War II victors _ the United States, Great Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ relinquish control over Germany. Earlier, Poland had demanded the four occupying powers retain their rights over Germany until the treaty is completed. Baker said the Bush administration would like to see German unification move quickly, but that the United States has ``floated the idea'' of not giving up control of the border until Germany concludes a treaty with Poland. ``Given European history, I think it is understandable that there is a lot of attention focused on this issue,'' Baker said before a refueling stop here en route to Paris. Control over Berlin and the Polish border are the main powers the four World War II allies have retained from the 1945 victory agreement. Leaders of West and East Germany have assured Poland the border would be guaranteed in a treaty after unification. Baker's offer to open a dialogue with the Soviet radical reformers who quit the Communist Party could enhance their stance. The radicals, who include Gavril K. Popov, head of the Moscow government, and Anatoly A. Sobchak, the Leningrad City Council leader, challenged Gorbachev to move faster on free-market reforms. They say they doubt the party is able to lead the country to democracy and prosperity. Baker said the ``good news'' for Gorbachev at the party congress was that he strengthened himself politically by fending off conservatives who tried to slow down his liberalization programs. The ``bad news'' for Gorbachev is that the party split, which tells the Soviet people that the party has failed, Baker said. As Central and East European states have broken away from Moscow, Baker said, the Bush administration has established a dialogue with opposition groups that showed democratic traits. Citing Bulgaria as an example, he said: ``We have taken care to touch base with the opposition, to make sure that we understand where the opposition is coming from, that they understand where we are coming from. And I don't think that's inappropriate just because it's the Soviet Union.''

DOC.HEAD: Fires Continue in West, Pacific Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Dry, erratic winds and high temperatures fueled a brush and grass fire in northern California's rural Santa Clara County that jumped fire lines and doubled in size to more than 2,000 acres by Monday. Fires also burned in Yellowstone National Park, Idaho and Oregon and Washington, but none posed immediate threats to life or property. California fire officials said they expected to have full containment of the blaze northeast of Mount Hamilton, by late Tuesday. The mountain is 15 miles southeast of San Jose. ``Right now we've got a low-pressure system causing erratic winds and fire behavior on all areas of the fire line, so that's going to be another problem for us,'' said state forestry spokesman Chris Morgan. Temperatures were in the mid-90s with 10-12 mph winds, and efforts to contain the blaze were further hampered by rugged terrain and dry brush, he said. The blaze was 65 percent contained on Monday, but Morgan said gusty winds pushed the flames over the fire line. ``It doubled fairly quickly,'' he said. The cause of the fire, which began shortly after 5 p.m. Saturday, still was under investigation. Only one building, an uninhabited log cabin, was burned. Although there are ranches in the area, no homes were in danger. Outbuildings were threatened if the blaze continued to spread, Morgan said. Firefighters also controlled a 650-acre brush fire near Santa Clarita in northern Los Angeles County Monday. No one was seriously injured and no structures were burned by the blaze that erupted Saturday afternoon at a campground, said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Robert Brady. Firefighters in Yellowstone National Park hoped to contain one lightning-caused fire Monday as officials watched for new fires. Park spokeswoman Marsha Karle said 13 firefighters remained at the scene of the 15-acre fire Monday to finish a containment line around the blaze. The fire was 95 percent contained, Karle said. Firefighters had hoped to fully contain the fire Sunday, but several flare-ups within the containment line delayed work, Karle said. In Idaho, fire bosses called in more reinforcements Monday in their battle against a wildfire racing out of control across 120 acres east of Cascade in the Boise National Forest. Cascade is about 80 miles north of Boise. ``It's expanding quite rapidly, fanned by hot temperatures and gusting winds,'' spokeswoman Ann Finkelstein said. More than 100 firefighters were digging a line in the area about 17 miles east of Cascade, and another 200 men were being moved in to bolster the attack. The fire erupted Sunday evening from smoldering embers left from a lightning strike during a storm that passed through the area last week. Fires triggered by lightning last week had consumed more than 4,000 acres of forests in central and eastern Oregon by Monday, authorities said. One fire grew to 935 acres Monday while smoldering brush on the Warm Springs Indian Reservation re-ignited and consumed 146 acres. A blaze near John Day had destroyed 880 acres, according to state and federal fire managers. As many as 500 fires were started by lightning strikes Wednesday night and about 75 fires _ most of them small _ are burning in Oregon and Washington, said Ralph Satterberg, spokesman at the Northwest Interagency Coordination Center in Portland.
Eds: There has been a delay in getting the data from the National Weather Service for the evening temperature tables. We now expect to move the tables in about 45 minutes.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Serbian Communists Try To Reshape Hard-line Profile
DOC.TEXT: Communists ruling the Serbian republic tried to shed their hard-line image Monday, merging with a sister group and renaming themselves the Socialist Party. Serbia, largest of the six Yugoslav republics, had moved more slowly than the others toward democratic reform. The new party's platform includes commitments to a market economy and multiparty democracy. However, it retains Communist-style calls for broad state ownership of businesses and makes no provision for freedom of the press. The Socialists also kept the Communist Red Star as official party symbol. The new union with the Socialist Alliance, a Communist-run mass movement originally designed to give non-Communists a forum, was proclaimed Monday at a hastily convened joint session of delegates from both groups. The fusing of the two movements was first announced last month by Serbia's Communist president Slobodan Milosevic. An official statement then said the merger was motivated by a desire ``to unite all left-leaning forces in Serbia in the face of an onslaught of extreme rightist, anti-Communist forces.'' ``We will not be afraid of anti-Communism; we will fight it,'' Bogdan Trifunovic, former chief of the disbanded Serbian Communist Party, told the party's final congress Monday. The congress was held just before the new organization was formed, with Milosevic elected its president. Croatia and Slovenia, Yugoslavia's two Westward-leaning states, this year held the first free elections here for local parliaments in 45 years. Center-right parties won both elections. The states of Bosnia, Montenegro and Macedonia are due to hold multiparty elections this fall. Milosevic has gained great popularity in Serbia for tightening control over the republic's province of Kosovo, where majority ethnic Albanians have resisted his efforts. Kosovo has been shaken by unrest for months. Leaders of Serbia's illegal opposition parties have denounced the merger as a sham intended to give Communists control over the assets of the sister group. Serbia's leadership has said it will adopt a new constitution before allowing the legalization of dozens of new independent parties and holding free elections. Also on Monday, a leading ethnic Albanian dissident in Kosovo said the region is seeking the status of a full Yugoslav republic. ``We are demanding independence within Yugoslavia,'' Ibrahim Rugova, chief of the Democratic Union, told journalists in Pristina, the province's capital. His group claims more than 500,000 ethnic Albanian members. Serbia all but abolished the autonomy of the province this month. It considers Kosovo as ancient Serbian territory. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of the population in the province, which borders Albania.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Broke into Sharon Gless' House Sentenced to 6 Years
DOC.TEXT: A woman who broke into actress Sharon Gless' home armed with a rifle in March was sentenced Monday to six years in prison. After Joni Leigh Penn, 30, pleaded no contest to two felony burglary charges in San Fernando Superior Court, Judge John Major handed down the term. He had reviewed Ms. Penn's psychiatric records and testimony including an apology from Ms. Penn to Miss Gless. Deputy District Attorney Lori Dery, who pushed for the maximum 10-year term, said: ``I think the judge did what he thought was right. ... Hopefully, she can get the help she needs while she's in state prison. Otherwise, she is still a danger to Miss Gless.'' Ms. Dery said Ms. Penn, who has no prior record and no history of violence, could be eligible for parole after 40 months in prison. Miss Gless, an Emmy Award winner for her role in the TV detective series ``Cagney and Lacy,'' did not attend Monday's court proceedings. But her brother and lawyer, Michael Gless, said he was glad Ms. Penn would be locked up. During the break-in, police said Ms. Penn told them she was in love with Miss Gless and planned to sexually assault her, then kill herself. Miss Gless was away from her Studio City home when the incident occurred March 30. Deputy Public Defender Mitch Bruckner could not be reached for comment. He has said previously that Ms. Penn never intended to harm Miss Gless, but only wanted to talk to her. At the time of the incident, she was under a restraining order instructing her to stay away from the actress. Her psychiatrist had notified Miss Gless more than two years ago that the woman planned to shoot herself in front of her. Police responding to a home security alarm discovered a person inside with a rifle. Ms. Penn surrendered peacefully to authorities after seven hours of negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Activist Sentenced to 32 Months, Probation
DOC.TEXT: An animal-rights activist was sentenced Monday to 32 months in prison for trying to blow up an executive of a company that uses live dogs to demostrate surgical equipment. Fran Trutt, 35, pleaded no contest in April to charges of attempted murder, possession of explosives and bomb manufacturing. Trutt, of the New York City bureau of Queens, was accused of planting a sophisticated pipe bomb near the parking space of Leon C. Hirsch, chairman and chief executive of Norwalk-based U.S. Surgical Corp. in November 1988. The bomb didn't explode. The company uses anesthetized live dogs to show surgeons how to use its surgical staplers, instruments which some doctors use instead of sutures. Superior Court Judge Joette Katz sentenced her to 10 years in prison for each charge. The judge suspended all but 32 months of the sentence, and Trutt is due to be released March 31 because she has already served time while awaiting the conclusion of court proceedings. Katz said she felt there was no question that Trutt ``had some sort of evil in her mind,'' but said Trutt's intentions as well as accusations that the company set her up to hurt the animal rights movement ``will never be known in light of the plea.'' Trutt had said in interviews that she wanted to scare Hirsch rather than kill him. Animal protection groups at first disavowed any connection to Trutt, saying they deplored violence. But activists, who have long disliked U.S. Surgical, rallied after hearing allegations that the company had set up Trutt by taping conversations she had with Mary Lou Sapone. According to Trutt's attorney, John R. Williams, Sapone was hired by U.S. Surgical to befriend Trutt and spy on her, then later encouraged her to proceed with the bombing despite Trutt's reservations. U.S. Surgical acknowledged hiring Sapone, of Ridgefield, to spy on Trutt after hearing of her plans against Hirsch. Prosecutor Bruce Hudock said during the sentencing that he had no doubt Trutt wanted to kill Hirsch. ``This is punishment for someone who places human life below that of animals and the law simply does not allow that,'' Hudock said. Trutttold Katz that she feels she is a scapegoat. ``Here I am taking the brunt for it. This is unbelievable,'' Trutt said in a loud, angry voice. In a telephone interview after the sentencing, Hirsch called Trutt a ``very disturbed woman'' and defended his company's use of animals to develop medical tools. ``I think all of America has to wake up to the threat of animal rights activists,'' he said. ``If they're successful, you can forget about improvements in medicine or any cure for Alzheimer's or cancer or any other disease that's still with us.'' Trutt was also sentenced Jan. 8 in federal court in New York for possession of two bombs found in her apartment. She received time served and three year's probation. The sentence in the Stamford case includes three years' probation following her release from the Niantic prison for women. The judge said that during probation Trutt must undergo psychotherapy, and must refrain from contacting Hirsch or any employee of U.S. Surgical.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Held for Quebec Policeman Slain in Mohawk Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `The officer' to fix typo `is' to `as.' Picks up 3rd, `Cpl. Marcel ...'
DOC.TEXT: L'ANCIENNE-LORETTE, Quebec (AP) _ A provincial police official, speaking Monday at the funeral of an officer killed in a shootout with Mohawk Indians, pleaded with his colleagues not to seek revenge. The officer died Wednesday in a confrontation with Mohawks opposing a golf course addition on lands they claim as ancestral territory. The standoff continued Monday, with armed Indians of nearby Kanesatake reserve manning barricades in Oka, a town 18 miles west of Montreal. Cpl. Marcel Lemay, 31, died Wednesday when police tried to storm an Indian barricade in Oka with gunfire and tear gas. At his funeral Monday, the director-general of the Quebec provincial police told his fellow officers nothing would be accomplished by seeking retribution for Lemay's death. ``We won't find an answer to our questions in vengeance, retaliation or rebellion,'' Robert Lavigne said. He called for ``the calm, the lucidity and the rational approach'' that he said had so far guided authorities in the dispute. Quebec's Public Security minister, Sam Elkas, has said Lavigne ordered Wednesday's raid. Lavigne spoke to nearly 1,500 people, including local residents, politicians, and police officers from as far away as New York City. They crammed into the ornate L'Ancienne-Lorette church in the Quebec City suburb. Lemay's widow, Lorraine, sat in the front row and occasionally wiped tears with a tissue.Lemay is also survived by a 3-year-old daughter. Even behind the Mohawk barricades in Oka, a flag was lowered to half-staff Monday to mark Lemay's funeral. However, a Mohawk spokeswoman, Ellen Gabriel, said a settlement is still not near. She is helping to represent the Mohawks in talks with Quebec provincial officials. Other Mohawks have blocked a bridge connecting Montreal to its southern suburbs in sympathy with the Oka Indians. Ms. Gabriel said the Mercier Bridge will remain barricaded ``as long as our demands aren't being met.'' Attorney William Kunstler, a lawyer who has represented many U.S. activists, was to fly to Montreal on Tuesday to serve as a negotiator for the Indians, the lawyer's New York office said. At the blocked bridge across the St. Lawrence River, about 100 provincial officers marched in formation Monday to honor Lemay. They stopped in front of the police barricades and faced the Mohawk barricades for a minute of silence. There were ugly scenes in that area Saturday and Sunday when local residents gathered to protest the blockage. On Saturday evening, about 2,000 residents gathered at the boundary of the nearby Kahnawake reserve and shouted racist slurs at Mohawks. At one point, they burned a dummy bearing the words ``Non aux Warriors,'' or ``no to the Warriors.'' They also chanted and waved Quebec flags.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Says it Will File Lawsuit Against Noriega
DOC.TEXT: Panamanian officials said Monday they will file a lawsuit in a U.S. court seeking $5 billion in damages from former dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Attorney General Rogelio Cruz told reporters he would travel to Washington next week to file the suit, assisted by the U.S. law firm of Williams and Connolly. Cruz said the country seeks to recover damages caused by Noriega during his six years as head of the armed forces. ``The Panamanian authorities would be absolutely irresponsible if they did not try to recover for Panama the funds which were obtained illegally by Noriega,'' he said. U.S. officials took Noriega to Florida to face trial on drug trafficking charges after he was overthrown by a U.S. invasion last December. Cruz said ``Noriega is the main theme'' of his scheduled meeting with U.S. attorneys. ``Everything turns around Noriega,'' he said. Cruz said the meeting with U.S. attorneys would be aimed at permitting both American and Panamanian justice systems to work ``more effectively in the Noreiga case.'' Panama does not expect to recover the full amount, said Panamanian Ambassador to the United States Eduardo Vallarino. ``What is being said is not that Panama hopes to be able to collect this money,'' he said. ``Simply, what is being said to the United States court is that this is the damage that (Noriega) has caused to the Panamanian economy and to the country in general.''

DOC.HEAD: Praise for Soviet-German Summit in Moscow
With AM-Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's governing party Monday praised the Soviet Union's acceptance of Germany's right to join NATO and said the decision marked a ``new high point'' in German-Soviet relations. Ending two days of talks in Moscow, Kohl and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev agreed a united Germany was free to make its own choice on joining a military alliance. The end of Soviet objections to NATO membership for Germany clears away one of the major obstacles to German unification and made it all the more certain the two Germanys will end their 40-year Cold War division in December. Volker Ruehe, general-secretary of West Germany's Christian Democratic Union, said, ``There is nothing more standing in the way of the reunification of Germany in full sovereignty by the end of the year. The new Europe has taken on a concrete form.'' In the German view, full sovereignty includes an end to all remaining rights over the now-divided nation by the four World War II allies that defeated the Nazis. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told West German television the most important outcome of the talks was that ``the question ... of full sovereignty for a united Germany has been secured.'' The four allies _ Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States _ meet Tuesday in Paris for another round of talks on the international implications of German unity. Ruehe said the Moscow talks were ``a new high point in the German-Soviet relationship'' that would have ``historic consequences.'' ``Chancellor Kohl's visit has opened new perspectives for the European peace order,'' Ruehe said, adding that the decision to limit a united German military to 370,000 troops would advance the Vienna talks on reducing conventional arms in Europe. The two Germanys merged their monetary, economic and social welfare systems on July 1 and have proposed all German elections on Dec. 2 for a joint parliament in the final step to unification.

DOC.HEAD: Education Problems Threaten Emerging Hispanic Power, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: The bleak condition of Hispanic education threatens the emerging power of the minority group, expected to be the nation's largest in 10 years, leaders of a Hispanic rights organization said Monday. A study by the National Council of La Raza says Hispanics are the most undereducated segment of the U.S. population. They continue to drop out of the nation's schools at a faster rate than other students. And those who do stay in school have a harder time than non-Hispanics. They achieve lower scores on standardized tests and get less financial aid from private schools and colleges. Worse, some officials say, is the council's finding that education reforms designed to help poorly performing Hispanics have hurt them instead. ``The problem is getting worse rather than better,'' said Raul Yzaguirre, director of the council. He and others warned 4,000 Hispanic leaders attending the council's annual conference that poor education could wipe out gains Hispanics have made in business and government. ``It's painful to know that with all the potentials and all the dreams ... all of it will be undercut if we cannot deal with the question of education for our people,'' said Henry Cisneros, former mayor of San Antonio. Hispanics, compared with blacks and non-Hispanic whites, enter school later and leave it earlier. They are also less likely to complete high school, enter or complete college, the report said. In 1988, the dropout rate for Hispanics at age 19 was about 31 percent, compared with 18 percent for blacks and 14 percent for non-Hispanic whites. Yzaguirre said the council is worried that education reform efforts that have swept parts of the country have forgotten Hispanics, failing them behind just as a track coach would fail his team if he raised the bar of the high jump and failed to train the athletes to jump higher. ``Those who have had the training, the preparation, the nutrition will jump higher than those who have not,'' Yzaguirre said. ``That's exactly what we fear will happen to the Hispanic community.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Asylum-Seekers Seize Hostages in Havana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13 grafs for 8-19 bgng `In its...' to UPDATE with Cuba refusing to negotiate, bomb deadline passing without incident, minor editing. Pickup graf 20 pvs, `Czechoslovak state...'
DOC.TEXT: Seven Cuban asylum-seekers seized several diplomats as hostages Monday at the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana and then threatened to blow up the building, official news reports here and in Mexico said. Czechoslavak television reported later that all six diplomats were released unharmed by the kidnappers. The official CTK news agency reported earlier that four diplomats had been taken hostage. Mexico's Notimex news agency said the captors demanded a plane to the United States. It said five other refugees were also seized. It was the second such incident the past week in Havana, capital of Communist Cuba. On Thursday, five Cubans occupied the apartment of the Czechoslovak charge d'affaires and held him hostage a few hours. A total of 15 Cubans seeking asylum had taken refuge at the Czechoslovak and Spanish embassies in Havana. The affair has soured Cuban relations with Czechoslovakia, which was a close ally before last fall's democratic upheaval toppled Prague's hard-line Communist leaders. The refugee crisis has also put Cuba at odds with Spain. Madrid lodged a protest after Cuban authorities chased an asylum-seeker onto the grounds of the Spanish Embassy and hauled him away Sunday. Three refugees remain there. In his first official statement on the crisis, Cuba's President Fidel Castro called the Cuban refugees ``anti-social elements encouraged by Czechoslovak diplomats,'' the Czech newspaper Lidova Demokracie said Monday. In its report, Czechoslovakia's official news agency said the Czechoslovak diplomats were taken hostage when the Cubans broke into a meeting. It said the Cubans acted ``very violently,'' but it was not clear if they had weapons. The news agency said no one was hurt. The Mexican news agency said the seven Cuban hostage-takers had been in the embassy six days. It said also they took five fellow refugees captive. A total of 12 refugees had reportedly been holed up at the embassy. The first Cubans arrived there July 9. The Czechoslovak news agency said the hostages had included Jan Doemoek, the charge d'affaires who was held hostage at his apartment. He escaped from the apartment, which is not in the embassy compound. CTK, quoting its correspondent in Havana, also said the hostage-takers had been holding a Foreign Ministry official who came to Havana to try to negotiate the departure of the Cubans in the embassy. Notimex, reporting from Havana, quoted unidentified journalistic sources in saying the seven Cubans demanded a plane to the United States. It said the hostages had been held in the offices of the ambassador. It said they later shouted out a window they would blow up the embassy if their demand for a plane was not met. They set a deadline of 8 p.m. (8 p.m. EDT) but it passed without any explosion reported. Czechoslovak TV's reporter in the Cuban capital said the seven had barricaded themselves inside the embassy and demanded everyone leave the embassy grounds after releasing the hostages. The correspondent described the seven barricaded inside as ``hysterical.'' There was no mention in that report of other refugees being held hostage. Associated Press phone calls to the Foreign Ministry in Prague went unanswered. In a statement Monday night, the Cuban Foreign Ministry said it will negotiate the refugees' demands for diplomatic safe-conduct passes to go abroad, according to Notimex. The statement said the Cuban government insisted the refugees holed up in the embassy ``must leave unconditionally.'' Czechoslovak state television quoted Foreign Ministry spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky as saying a deputy foreign minister would leave for Havana immediately because ``it is necessary to protect the safety of Czechoslovak citizens.'' Dependents of some Czechoslovak diplomats have already left Havana. About 30 Czechoslovaks left Sunday on a regular flight, the daily Lidova Demokracie in Czechoslovakia reported Monday. Foreign Ministry official Jindrich Opava said they included some families of diplomats. The official, however, said left at their own request _ not under evacuation orders. The Cubans who broke into the charge d'affaire's apartment remained there Monday. They have been denied asylum by Czechoslovakia because of their actions. In his remarks quoted by the Czech newspaper, Castro was also quoted as saying Cuba has no agreement on diplomatic asylum with European countries, so their embassies have no right to grant asylum. ``Czechoslovak diplomats in Havana try to interpret the situation in a way that indicates that Cuban government should solve the situation. ... The affair should be solved by the Czechoslovak side,'' the daily quoted Castro as saying. The refugee problem poses an embarrassment for Castro, who has resisted the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Instead, he has continued to espouse orthodox Marxist policies.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Declares Tie in Republican Primary
DOC.TEXT: A Cook County Circuit judge declared a Republican primary for a state representative's seat a tie Monday after a daylong hearing on last week's vote recount. The decision by Judge Francis Barth means the state Board of Elections will hold a lottery to determine the winner, though it's unclear what form the lottery would take. Election officials could not be reached at their home or office phone numbers Monday night. Both sides plan to appeal, depending on the lottery's outcome. Both candidates _ Rep. Penny Pullen and challenger Rosemary Mulligan _ are proceeding with campaign plans on the assumption that they will be declared the winner. ``I'm very pleased,'' said Pullen, a seven-term representative from the northwest suburb of Park Ridge and the leader of anti-abortion forces in the Illinois House. ``We live to fight another day.'' Mulligan, a paralegal who favor abortion rights, said: ``I think we have a lot of issues that are appealable in our favor if it (the lottery) shouldn't go the right way.'' The results, based on results of last week's recount, stand at 7,387 votes for each candidate.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Threat Not Considered Credible
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration informed airlines of a threat against Pan Am in Europe but did not consider the threat credible, an FAA spokesman said Monday. ``The FAA routinely issues information to U.S. carriers to put into perspective rumors, news reports and other information that may be based on erroneous information or speculation,'' said spokesman Fred Farrar. Such a circular was issued July 12, he said, without describing its contents. A London newspaper, the Sunday Correspondent, reported Sunday that U.S. authorities had warned airlines of a threat to blow up a Pan Am jet on a flight from West Germany in the next 10 days. The supposed threat involved a female student with a Canadian passport who was to be duped into carrying a suitcase containing a bomb on a Pan Am flight from either Frankfurt or Berlin. Farrar said information about the threat had been circulating for several months among news organizations in Europe. The FAA cautioned that doubts existed about the information and advised airlines that the agency did not consider it a credible threat, he said. A Pan Am plane was blown up by a bomb in December 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland with the loss of 20 lives. Many authorities believe the bombing was carried out by a terrorist group working on behalf of Iran in retaliation for the accidental shooting down of an Iranian airliner over the Persian Gulf by a U.S. warship.

DOC.HEAD: School Survivor Sobs for Mother _ `My Friends Are Dead Inside'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE casualty figures, Mrs. Aquino arrives, more rescue accounts. Picks up 7th graf, `Lt. Benbol.. .'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Philippines-Quake, Bjt
LaserPhotos CAB1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: ``Mommy, mommy, come here!'' screamed Loida Gabwat, 14, after she was pulled from the rubble of a school Monday. ``I can't go through this alone! My friends are dead inside!'' She was among hundreds of students and teachers inside the Christian College of the Philippines when an earthquake struck at about 4:30 p.m. on Monday, toppling the six-story building in this city of 80,000 residents. The school included first grade through the senior year of college. The quake measured 7.7 on the Richter scale and was centered near Cabanatuan City, 60 miles north of Manila. It was the strongest earthquake to hit the Philippines in 14 years, and seismological officials said Cabanatuan had not had a major quake since 1645. Early Tuesday, hospitals said 35 people had been killed in the Cabanatuan area and 154 injured. Most casualties were from the school but officials had no accurate breakdown. Officials admitted they had no idea how many were in the building when it collapsed. Mayor Honorato Perez said Tuesday about 50 people remained buried in the rubble but fewer than half were believed still alive. Rescue efforts were undertaken largely by townspeople who flocked to the site and volunteered their services. There was little sign of experienced supervision. President Corazon Aquino flew to Cabanatuan from Manila early Tuesday to console families and visit survivors. Gov. Bren Guiao of Pampanga province said Mrs. Aquino gave the families money and told them ``It's already happened. Leave it to God.'' As she met, a rescuer crawled from the rubble and told reporters he found four boys, all alive. But he said one was pinned under the ruins, in such pain he amputated his own leg with a jagged piece of concrete. Poorly equipped local hospitals overflowed with victims. Patients were placed on cots in yards in front of clinics. Lt. Benbol Moralde, part of an army contingent sent from nearby Fort Magsaysay, said he believed few remained alive beneath the debris. Moralde said victims' cries grew fainter and fainter and that he could see bodies and parts of bodies when he surveyed the destruction. Hours after the temblor, hundreds of family members and friends watched and prayed as rescuers dug through the school rubble. Each time someone was brought out alive, relatives crowded around the survivor, begging for news of those still missing. ``They told me she's still alive,'' said Rosa de los Reyes, who was waiting word of her daughter, Maria Lisa, 14. ``I'm very happy but if it turns out she has died, I think I'm going to die too.'' Throughout the night, boys as young as seven scrambled between slabs of concrete carrying water to victims still trapped. Sixteen-year-old Florencio Alano crawled through the wreckage looking for his 13-year-old brother, Cesario _ only to find out he was dead. Florencio, who eventually led three survivors to safety, said: ``At first I couldn't believe that he was already dead. So I crawled through the passageway. I saw his face and felt him. What else can one feel but just accept it.'' Rescuers could hear the anguished screams during the night of those buried under tons of debris. Most begged for water. One girl shrieked for rescuers to ``cut off my legs'' to free her. Miss Gabwat, a high school sophomore, said her class had just finished a math examination when the quake struck. ``We were kidding each other, we were saying the test was so easy,'' Miss Gabwat said as she rode in an ambulance to the provincial hospital. ``Then suddenly, the walls trembled, the ceiling collapsed and there was total darkness. We embraced each other. We were very scared.'' She said survivors groped for one another in the darkened rubble and prayed aloud. ``We were calling out our classmates' names but they did not respond any more,'' she said. ``Then we groped for their hands but felt that they were cold. Each time, we wept. ``We were scared and some were screaming. But then later on, they said they wanted to sleep already and rest. Then there was silence.'' Cenando Memping, whose 14th birthday was on Monday, said he had just invited his three best friends to join him after class at a restaurant when the quake hit. Cenando and his friends were trapped beneath tons of rubble. He said there were 54 students in his class. More than 10 hours after the quake, he was the only one of them who had been rescued. ``I prayed to God that if I survive, I'll hear Mass every day,'' he said from his hospital bed. He said his friend Michael Nuevo joked that he would never go to a ``high'' school again. Moments later, Michael died, Cenando said. ``We were kidding each other, comforting each other,'' Cenando said softly. ``Then suddenly, he stopped breathing. He said, `Praise the Lord. Our Father, Our Father, Our Father.' Then he was silent.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire In Empire State Building Injures 38
