DOC.TEXT: Adjusting the spray upward also gets rid of insects. ``Bugs are smart. They lay their eggs on the underside of the leaf out of the rain. So we got smarter and spray from the bottom, washing off the eggs. This reduces use of pesticide to a sixteenth of what the bag label recommends.'' Another sermon in Robbins's ministry is low-tillage farming: LISA, low input sustainable agriculture. Leaving corn stubble in the field retains snow melt, impedes rain runoff, cuts herbicide use by two-thirds, means only five tractor trips across a field a year instead of eight or 10 _ and saves water. Bruce Unruh farms 2,000 acres of wheat, corn and sunflowers and is a prize pupil of Robbins. ``I used to pump 90 to 120 days a season. Last year I ran the pivot 39 days.'' He uses gypsum blocks _ only 2 percent of Ogallala farmers do _ which measure soil moisture ``like a fuel gauge and tell me when to irrigate.'' LEPA and LISA farming are more management intensive. ``But instead of five operations with the tractor before planting at 10 acres an hour, now I have one.'' Another of Robbins's proteges is growing corn over in Nebraska on 6 to 8 inches of irrigation instead of 2 feet. ``You got guys running pumps all summer. That's what everybody told them to do.'' Much of the hope for the future of the aquifer, in Robbins' view, lies in a change of farmer mentalilty. ``Farmers think in terms of yield, not profit. The whole purpose of farming is to make enough to support your family. If you can reduce the cost, you do it better.'' ``In the coffee shop, farmers are always talking about how many bushels they got per acre,'' Unruh says. ``But it's how much money you net that makes you sucessful or not.'' ``Farmers have a tilling addiction,'' Robbins says. ``They get the shakes if the tractor isn't running. Sun's up, you gotta be driving. Sun's down, go to bed. It's a problem to program older farmers. They think it's a sin to sit down. But we know how to farm with less manpower, less water and more profit.'' ``We've been mining the aquifer, using it up, marketing water through a crop,'' says Lyle. ``We got 172 bushels of corn on our fields with 5.5 inches of irrigation, vs. 24 bushels dry farming. For an additional 12 inches of water we added 14 bushels, so in effect we gave away the 12 inches.'' But the most persuasive missionary for sensible water use is a farmer looking over his fence at a more prosperous neighbor. ``We had 16 LEPAs in this county last year,'' Robbins reports. ``By the end of this year there'll be 100.'' It costs up to $9,000 to convert a $50,000 pivot to LEPA. It is an investment in the future. ``If there were no pioneers in this country, we'd still all be sitting on Plymouth Rock,'' says Wes Robbins, visionary. ``We haven't begun to scratch the future out here.'' ``I seriously think we have the technology right here today to cut the amount of water we're using by half in Texas and parts of Nebraska,'' says Lyle. ``I believe the Ogallala could be self-sustaining if we cut back on water and concentrate on profitability instead of yield.'' He mentions technology: _ A new cotton plant that uses 20 percent less water. _ An improved pivot whose segments move uniformly in tandem, spreading water and chemicals more efficiently. _ Improved management by irrigating in alternate furrows with diking to retain water _ An improved nozzle that sprays in a sheet instead of more erosive droplets. In Imperial, Neb., district water manager Ron Milner foresees irrigation technology that will reduce water on crops by two-thirds. But in Greeley County in western Kansas, ``the horse has already left the barn,'' says Keith Lebbin, water manager in Scott City. ``A new proposal would limit 12-section areas to 641 acre feet of water. But permits are already in existence for 8,191 acre feet. What do you do: sue everyone to take away their property rights? What's the cost of that?'' The U.S. Geological Survey had predicted the water table in the corn and cow belt of the Upper Republican River in Nebraska would drop 90 feet by 2000. The actual decline has been only 1.5 feet annually, a projected 15 feet by century's end. ``With irrigating 8 to 10 inches a year, the Ogallala here could be self-sustaining with recharge from rain and surface water,'' Milner predicts. A 1982 study for the U.S. Department of Commerce forecast a 25 percent fall in water levels in the Ogallala by 2020 if no conservation steps were taken. Irrigated farming would decline sharply from Kansas to New Mexico and ``increase greatly'' in Nebraska. A more regulated use of the aquifer would reduce predicted declines by 5 percent to 25 percent, depending on the area. But, the report concluded, ``actions by individual states would have little effect'' on regional consequences. That crystal ball has proved to be cloudy. With new technology, better management, regulated pumping and normal rainfall, declines have been considerably below generalized predictions. Suppose they weren't. It should be remembered that the original sodbusters of the High Plains got by on dryland farming. About three-quarters of the farmers in northwestern Kansas do not irrigate. About half of the acreage of the Texas panhandle and south is dry farmed. For years farmers have grown summer fallow wheat, planting fields in alternate years. ``Eventually we'll have a mix of dryland and irrigated farming,'' says former Nebraska state hydrologist Vince Dreeszen. ``This will keep the Ogallala around. Absolutely.'' Even assuming a worst scenario, any changes in population and agriculture ``are going to take place over time,'' says Michael Jess, Nebraska director of water resources. This is evident across the High Plains where abandoned, swaybacked, weed-covered farmsteads of those who didn't make it gaze windowless over still-green fields of neighbors who did. The 1982 study, the most thorough the Ogallala has had, did not write the aquifer's epitaph in the dust. It will last ``well into the next century,'' the report said. Nebraskans talk about a 400-year supply for them. Seen through the eyes of a Wes Robbins or a Wayne Wyatt or a Bill Lyle, the Ogallala has been comprehended in time to save it. Should this be so, and the drinking spree of the ancient aquifer has taken the pledge, it would signal a commendable triumph of good sense over greed. At a water conference in Lincoln not long ago, David Sands of the Nebraska Audubon Society delivered a better epitaph for the Ogallala: ``We don't own our world. We merely borrow it for our children.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
With BC-APN--Water Trust, b0766-b0767
DOC.TEXT: Home on the range, the skies are not cloudy all day. That's the problem. Rain falls and rivers flow far more kindly elsewhere than in the High Plains. But this semi-arid swath from South Dakota to New Mexico has been an irrigated breadbasket producing some 25 percent of the nation's food and fiber since its huge underground sea, the Ogallala Aquifer, began being pumped in earnest 70 years ago. But what if the well should eventually run dry? There have been some earth-shaking proposals that challenge Genesis itself, such as pouring Canada's huge northern rivers south of the border. Meanwhile, rainmaking, once the province of tom-toms and flim-flam artists, has actually been working. Ten years ago in Texas, where wells have ``dewatered'' as hydrologists delicately put it, they were talking about importing water from Nebraska's mother lode of two-thirds of the aquifer's Great Lakes-size supply. The cost and realities of interstate politics have stilled such musings. In the 1960s, Texas was seriously considering capturing the Mississippi River below New Orleans and siphoning and pumping it 800 miles to the Panhandle to irrigate its huge cotton fields. Power to do it would have come from six or so new nuclear generating plants. The prohibitive price kept Ol' Man River where it was. In 1982 the ``Six-State High Plains Aquifer Regional Resources Study'' for the U.S. Department of Commerce went into megariver transfers in some detail. As outlined by the Army Corps of Engineers, various alternatives would divert water from the Missouri River, turn rivers backward, put reservoirs and pumping stations all over the map and cost anywhere from $13 billion to $22.6 billion in 1982 dollars. Stating it nicely, the Corps reported: ``NONE (their emphasis) of that water has been identified as surplus to the needs of the basin of origin.'' Michael Jess, Nebraska's director of water resources, puts it more bluntly: ``We wouldn't stand for it.'' Canada has expressed similar reluctance about a proposal by an American engineering firm in California to redirect the Yukon, Susitana and Tanana rivers from the Northwest Territories down to the States. The flow would be 125 percent that of the Mississippi at St. Louis. Cost: $200 billion in 1977 money. Another plan would cost $40 billion to tap the Mackenzie River, which pours 325 million acre feet largely unused into the Arctic Ocean every year, for 40 million acre feet delivered to the United States by way of the Rockies. The Corps estimates its plans would cost the farmer $226 to $434 an acre foot _ which would bankrupt most of them overnight. ``Maybe some day if we have starving multitudes and people are willing to work for a hell of a lot less than the minimum wage, we'll have transfers,'' says Wes Robbins, a U.S. water expert in Burlington, Colo. On a more realistic level is the 1982 decision by the U.S. Supreme Court that ground water is a commodity of interstate commerce and its export cannot be embargoed by the state where it is found. The cast involved a Colorado farmer, Joy Sporhase, who owned land in Nebraska and was pumping its well water onto his adjacent farm in Colorado. Nebraska tried to invoke its regulatory powers against Sporhase, but the court said it couldn't. This caused Nebraska state Sen. Loran Schmit to suggest that Nebraska begin selling its water out of state, since under Sporhase there wasn't anything stopping the city of Denver, say, from buying up Nebraska land and pumping its water back to the Mile High City. ``Schmit was damn near lynched,'' says Jess. ``We might as well get something for our water while we have it.'' Several small towns in Kansas and Colorado have dipped straws into Nebraska for domestic water, and dewatered Texans and Jayhawkers have been buying farms in liquid Cornhusker land, but the implications of Sporhase remain, so far, only a cloud on the horizon. In Kansas Water District No. 1, scientists have been experimenting with cloud seeding to produce rain since 1975. ``People thought it was hocus-pocus, but if it could take some of the stress off our aquifer, we thought it might be worth trying,'' says district manager Keith Lebbin. The results have been evaluated independently in 1978, '81 and '88. All confirmed a 9 percent increase over normal rainfall and, more importantly, a 35 percent reduction in hail. The rainfall is equivalent to an inch or inch and a half of precipitation. Hail insurance rates have dropped 11 percent, a saving of $75 million. Hail the size of grapefruit can ruin a crop in minutes. It caused Ed Gutentag, a federal geologist, to re-roof his house four times in the 15 years he lived in the area. ``Some people think it's the Lord's work and we shouldn't interfere,'' says Lebbin, who has four cloud-seeding planes on ready alert during growing season. ``But we're not pretending to make rain. We're just trying to maximize what the cloud is doing.'' North Dakota has had even better luck. Ray Pat Jones, meteorologist for the Upper Colorado River Municipal Water District in Texas, says seeding has increased rainfall there 20 percent. The Lubbock, Texas, water district is going to give it a try in three to five years. ``It takes people that long to get comfortable with it,'' says water manager Wayne Wyatt.

From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 5 b&w photos. ColorFoto subscribers get 4 35mm slides.)
DOC.TEXT: In September, more than three quarters of a century after construction began, the final stone will be put in place at the Washington National Cathedral. It was first conceived by the architect who designed the nation's capital, but only a few years ago some thought the cathedral would never be finished. Here's a look at the magnificent church and its history.

On the gray February day in 1924 when Woodrow Wilson was laid to rest at the Washington National Cathedral, the main sanctuary of the vast building was unfinished and open to the sky. When the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. mounted the cathedral's Canterbury Pulpit on Palm Sunday 1968, just three days before his death, the central tower was complete but the twin towers on the west portal had not yet begun to rise. When mourners were summoned for a memorial service for assassinated Egyptian President Anwar Sadat in 1981, the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral Foundation had fallen $10.7 million in debt and work at the cathedral was at a standstill. ``Only the most optimistic person would have bet on Washington Cathedral ever being finished,'' said Canon Richard T. Feller, clerk of the works since 1953. ``A review of the hard facts gave it almost zero chance.'' And yet at noon on Sept. 29, a gleaming blue crane will lift a 1,008-pound chunk of Indiana limestone, carved in the shape of a folded leaf, onto the south tower's southwestern pinnacle and one of the world's last great Gothic cathedrals will be completed. President Bush is expected to be on hand, just as President Theodore Roosevelt was there for the foundation stone ceremony on the same date in 1907. ``Godspeed in the work begun this noon,'' Roosevelt told a crowd estimated at 10,000 as a stone quarried in Bethlehem was sunk in the rocky soil of Washington's Mount St. Alban. A national worshiping place was first conceived by Pierre L'Enfant, the Parisian-born American architect commissioned by George Washington to plan the national capital. His blueprints for the city included a church ``intended for national purposes, such as public prayer, thanksgiving, funeral orations, etc., and assigned to the special use of no particular Sect or denomination, but equally open to all.'' Partly because of concern over the constitutional separation of church and state, it was not until Dec. 9, 1891, that the first meeting to plan the cathedral was held at the home of banker Charles C. Glover. Construction would not begin until 16 years later. Building the cathedral has cost $65 million to date, not taking inflation into account. The figure includes more than 200 stained-glass windows and a wealth of statuary, mosaics and other art works. According to the Federal Highway Administration, it can cost up to $63 million in 1990 money to build a one-mile stretch of urban interstate highway. The cost of a B-2 stealth bomber has been set at from $530 million to $815 million, depending on how many are purchased. Even in today's dollars, the cost of the cathedral is small compared to such sums. Yet some have questioned whether the foundation, which operates the cathedral under a charter granted by Congress in 1893, should have pumped money into such a project in a capital facing mounting homelessness and poverty. The provost of the cathedral, the Very Rev. Howard A. Perry, says the decision in 1983 to finish the building on a pay-as-you-go basis while retiring its debt was coupled with a commitment to expand outreach to the city. At the time, 20 percent of the cathedral's budget went into worship and outreach. It is now 40 percent. ``We don't see ourselves being so caught up in this building and all its glory that we don't also have a very strong involvement in the metropolitan area,'' says the Rev. Kwasi Thornell, who came from a mission church in a poor St. Louis neighborhood to be canon missioner of the cathedral. The cathedral does not double as a parish church, as do most Episcopal cathedrals in the United States, so there is no built-in congregation. Yet several services are held every day. There are usually five services on Sunday. Perry says only about 15 percent to 20 percent of the people attending the services come to the cathedral regularly. One of the regulars is Ruth Goodchild, daughter of an Episcopal clergyman and wife of a retired Foreign Service officer. She and her husband come in every Sunday from suburban McLean, Va. But her involvement with the cathedral doesn't end there. On Monday afternoons, from 12:30 to 3, Mrs. Goodchild, a former schoolteacher, goes to a school in a poverty-stricken area of Washington and tutors two Hispanic fifth-graders.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
WASHN: Hispanic fifth-graders.
DOC.TEXT: As chairman of the cathedral's literacy program, Mrs. Goodchild also arranges and attends three-hour training sessions for volunteers the first Saturday of each month. There are more than 90 volunteers in the program, some visiting schools once or twice a week and some working in the evening with adults at a former public school now run by the city government as a tutoring center. The cathedral is built in the style of the English cathedrals of the 14th century, with some variations, including mostly French-style windows. It is put together in the same stone-on-stone method used by medieval masons. Although there are steel reinforcing rods in the concrete floors and in the cores of the pillars, there is no structural steel in the bearing walls. Flying buttresses, countering the outward thrust of the Gothic arches, hold them up. ``This thing is built to stay here a couple of thousand years,'' says Joseph Alonso, the mason foreman. At 83,012 square feet, the Washington cathedral is the sixth largest in the world, exceeded by St. Peter's in Rome at 227,069, Seville at 128,570, the unfinished Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York at 121,000, Liverpool at 101,000 and Milan at 92,600. The building is 518 feet long. Its central tower rises 301 feet and the west tower reaches 234 feet. The work proceeded from east to west, starting in 1907 with the Bethlehem chapel, where Wilson was laid to rest, then continuing to the Chapel of St. Joseph of Arimathea, with a mural of Christ's entombment, and the Resurrection Chapel, with the cathedral's only mosaics. A visitors' center and museum shop complete the crypt, or lower level. The main altar, directly above Bethlehem Chapel, was built next. Then came the choir, with its richly carved wood, and the south and north transepts, which intersect the nave at right angles to form the shape of a cross. Construction stopped in 1977 due to the shortage of money. Work resumed in 1980 after a new bishop and dean, the Right Rev. John Thomas Walker, started a fund-raising drive and ordered stringent economies _ cutting back on heat, reducing staff and turning the lights off except during services. The final phase of construction began on April 5, 1983, with the setting of the first stone for the west towers. Walker died after heart surgery on Sept. 30, 1989, the day that a ceremony was held marking the beginning of the final year of construction. Like five other bishops who served as the building rose, he is interred in the cathedral. His successor, the Right Rev. Ronald H. Haines, will be installed a few weeks after the cathedral's ceremonious completion. A few months before his death, Walker challenged the cathedral to become ``a servant church.'' ``The alternative is to become an anachronism, a museum piece, a stop on a tour of the capital city,'' he wrote. ``I don't believe that we will be reduced to be a museum piece.'' The building will need more work even after the final stone is set. ``We've got a 70-year-old building at one end and a brand-new building at the other end, and the 70-year-old portion of the building and the intermediate areas have got to have some preservation,'' Feller says. One problem is that during the stop-and-start construction, the building was often protected only by temporary roofs. Walking a visitor through the nave, Alonso said: ``You notice these black stains here. That's from water infiltrating. It seeps into the limestone and then darkens.'' ``A building like this is always moving, expanding, settling,'' he added. Unlike New York's St. John the Divine, which is on the edge of Harlem, the Washington cathedral is on a leafy hilltop in a fashionable residential area far from the troubled inner city. From the south tower, you can see across the Potomac River to the Pentagon, off into Maryland to the Mormon Temple and beyond to Sugar Loaf Mountain, up Pennsylvania Avenue to the Capitol and the Library of Congress. The White House, four miles away, is hidden behind trees. ``You can be any place in that building and you can find delight,'' says James P. Cramer, executive vice president of the American Institute of Architects.

DOC.TEXT: From Coventry to Philadelphia, from the edge of Harlem to the Golden Gate, cathedral building in the 20th century has often been accompanied by controversy. A cathedral serves as the official seat, or chair, of the bishop of a diocese in churches that are governed by bishops, such as the Roman Catholic, Eastern Orthodox, Anglican or Episcopal and, in Sweden, the Lutheran denominations. The question of whether and how to build cathedrals has been revived with the scheduled completion in September of the Gothic-style Washington National Cathedral, begun in 1907. The question is not a new one. When the 14th century St. Michael's Cathedral in Coventry, England, was gutted by German bombing during World War II, the cathedral chapter decided to rebuild in a controversial modern style. ``I think they were right,'' said Stanford Lehmberg, a historian of cathedrals who teaches at the University of Minnesota, arguing that England already has a wealth of real medieval churches, and doesn't need to build copies. ``Here, where we don't genuinely have any medieval buildings, I think it is appropriate for us to have one.'' San Francisco Roman Catholics, however, built a modern cathedral after their 75-year-old red brick Gothic one was destroyed by fire in 1962. ``The community at large ... expected the new cathedral to be a building of the future, not a clever replica of a traditional style,'' Monsignor James P. Gaffey said in a lecture in 1983. Some didn't want it to be built at all. Twenty-seven priests wrote to Archbishop Joseph T. McGucken in 1967 that human inequities ``must take precedence over parish and diocesan building programs.'' The archbishop argued there was no contradiction between building a cathedral and helping the poor. The new St. Mary's Cathedral was dedicated in 1971. In 1967, Episcopal Bishop Horace W. Donegan of New York halted fund-raising to complete the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, begun in 1892. He said the structure, located on the border of Harlem, would remain unfinished as a witness to the ``despair and anguish'' of the nearby slums. This decision was reversed by Bishop Paul Moore in the 1970s. Work has resumed and a fund-raising drive is under way aimed at completing the cathedral early in the 21st century. The diocese has launched a program to train young people from Harlem and the South Bronx in stone cutting and stone carving. Although it is a myth that cathedrals are never finished, there are a number that have been unfinished for some time. In Philadelphia, Episcopalians broke ground in the 1920s for what was planned as the largest Gothic cathedral in the world. Then the Depression came along and there was ``a series of bishops who were concerned about the edifice complex,'' said the Rev. Tom McClellan, rector of St. Mary's at the Cathedral, the parish church on the site. All that was completed was the apse, the front part of the church that includes the altar. It is now part of St. Mary's. The diocese decided in 1975 to leave the cathedral unfinished and use the 100-acre plot as a life care community for retired people. In Seattle, ground was broken in 1930 for St. Mark's Episcopal Cathedral. There, too, the Depression intervened. The building has a wooden roof that was intended to be temporary, and there has been rain damage in the sanctuary. The exterior walls are a rough surface that was intended to be faced. Lisette Trombley, publications coordinator for the cathedral, said a pledge campaign has been started to get the building finished, starting with the roof.

DOC.TEXT: Washington National Cathedral is only one of several names by which the building on Washington's Mount St. Alban has been known. Officially, it is the Cathedral Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, the name chosen by the cathedral chapter after the Episcopal Diocese of Washington was carved out of the Maryland diocese in the 1890s. As the building slowly rose, and became the site of national observances, people took to calling it National Cathedral. The late Bishop William Creighton, who took office in 1969, is said to have thought this presumptuous, so the name used on cathedral stationery and publicity was ``Washington Cathedral.'' One of the three schools on the 57-acre cathedral grounds is called the National Cathedral School for Girls. A few months before his death in 1989, Bishop John Thomas Walker approved the use of the name ``Washington National Cathedral.'' The Rev. Canon John Frizell objected to the change in a guest editorial in the diocesan newspaper, saying, ``It does not do honor to other faith communities in this pluralistic country when we arrogate to ourselves a title which is illusory, misleading and potentially divisive.'' The Rev. Canon Leonard Freeman, director of communications for the cathedral, however, described the new name as a compromise. National Cathedral ``has long been kind of the other name of the place,'' Freeman said, noting that the Washington Metro System uses it on bus schedules. He said he always called the building National Cathedral himself before he came to Washington. By any name, the cathedral receives no financial support from the U.S. government or the national Episcopal Church. It is the official seat of the presiding bishop of the church, but his office is in New York. Over the years many Washington churches have come to call themselves national. There are National Presbyterian Church, National City Christian Church, National Baptist Memorial Church and the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception, among others.

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: From the start, there was debate over whether Washington National Cathedral should be built in the medieval Gothic style. In the 1890s, as the cathedral was being planned, a committee voted 12 to 3 to approve a domed, Renaissance-style design of white marble with a long colonnade, submitted by noted American architect Ernest Flagg. Others favored the Greek Revival style of many of the capital's government buildings. The cathedral chapter, or board of trustees, voted unanimously on May 21, 1906, to build a Gothic cathedral instead. ``This is probably the last one,'' says Stanford Lehmberg, professor of history at the University of Minnesota and an authority on English cathedrals. Some have questioned the appropriateness of using a 14th century style for a cathedral that will be serving 21st century worshipers. ``It's Christianity, as it were, in a period costume,'' says David L. Holmes Jr., professor of religion at the College of William and Mary. ``You have to ask what an unbeliever thinks. He or she may be awed, or may relegate the Christian message to an irrelevant position because the building is so anachronistic and almost Disneyland in character.'' ``I don't think that it will ever happen again,'' says E.A. Sovik, a leading church architect who works in the more modern style of the liturgical movement. ``I think that it was a valiant gesture, but it was started during a period when architecture and architects were looking back and not forward. ``I think the whole Gothic revival was a mistake. But within that mistake, things were done well and done badly, and this one was done well.''

DOC.TEXT: Here are some milestones in the history of Washington National Cathedral: _ Construction, which began in 1907, was halted during the two world wars. _ Work on the choir began in 1921, the year the Lincoln Memorial was completed. _ The chancel was opened for public worship on Easter Sunday in 1932. _ The Wilson Bay, to which the President Woodrow Wilson's remains were moved from Bethlehem Chapel, was dedicated in 1956. _ Beginning in March 1979, prayers for the American hostages in Iran were said in the cathedral daily for the 444 days of their incarceration. _ For three days in November 1982, when the Vietnam memorial was dedicated, the 57,939 names listed on it were read in the War Memorial Chapel during the day and in Bethlehem Chapel at night.

DOC.TEXT: When it comes to writing screenplays, two cooks often come up with a better broth. Some of Hollywood's biggest hits have been the result of collaboration between two or more writers. And in today's electronic age, sometimes the collaborators rarely see each other in person.

Rarely has a long-distance relationship been so blissful. Jim Cash and Jack Epps Jr. haven't seen one another in more than a year and have met just five times in the last 14 years. They live 2,000 miles apart. Yet they are one of this town's hottest screenwriting teams, authors of the summer hit ``Dick Tracy'' and the 1986 blockbuster ``Top Gun,'' as well as ``Legal Eagles'' and ``The Secret of My Success.'' In an industry where collaboration often is considered a necessary evil, a disruption of one's personal vision, Cash and Epps and several other screenwriting partnerships are finding that two cooks don't spoil the broth. Indeed, as in a good marriage, a writing team's sum frequently exceeds its parts. Cash works in East Lansing, Mich., where he teaches in the film program at Michigan State University. Epps writes in Culver City, Calif., handling much of the team's Hollywood business. The former is good at dialogue, while the latter specializes in story. The two bridge the Continental Divide with an electronic meeting of the minds, linked by speakerphone and dual computer screens flashing text simultaneously in two cities. ``It's words and music _ we're good at different things,'' Epps says. ``And I happen to like the distance. It's kept us together. It's taken ego out of the equation.'' At a time when such actors as Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger command salaries well in excess of $5 million, the entertainment industry suddenly has rediscovered the value of scripts. In recent weeks, several screenplays have sold for $1 million and more in frantic bidding wars. Many of these deals were prompted by team-written projects. Brian Helgeland and Manny Coto reportedly received $1 million for their script ``Ticking Man.'' Doug Richardson and Rick Jaffa collected the same amount for ``Hell Bent ... And Back.'' ``The Ultimatum,'' written by Laurence Dworet and Robert Roy Pool, brought them $1 million. Pen Densham and John Watson earned $1.2 million for the script ``Prince of Thieves.'' The ultimate test of a screenwriting team is not the price of a single script. Rather, it's whether the team can remain together, consistently creating stories that please film critics and studio accountants. These writers _ known simply by the names Cash & Epps, Gale & Zemeckis, Gideon & Evans and Ganz & Mandel _ can split $500,000 and more per script. The money's good, and so's the symbiotic link that makes the productivity pleasant. Writers feel that given the key role they play in filmmaking they don't draw enough credit. When a picture flops, they take the blame. When it's a smash, someone else collects the credit. What's more, just about everybody from the electrician to the gaffer believes he or she can make a scene better than the most experienced writer. Since so much of the movie business hinges on compromise, writers working in teams are prepared better for that give-and-take. ``It's a wonderful thing in life to be heard and understood, and your partner is always there to hear and understand,'' says Lowell Ganz. His nine-year association with Babaloo Mandel has yielded scripts for ``Parenthood,'' the Academy Award-nominated ``Splash'' (co-written with Bruce Jay Friedman), ``Gung Ho'' and ``Night Shift.'' ``Babaloo could go to Mars and I'd wait for him to come back,'' Ganz says. Other teams joke that they have suicide pacts _ they can't face a blank page of paper alone. Writer's block in a team is a rarity; when one writer hits a wall, the other should be able to take the lead. Rick Natkin and partner David Fuller wrote the scripts for last year's HBO film ``The Heist'' and next spring's feature ``The Taking of Beverly Hills,'' starring Ken Wahl. ``We entertain each other, which makes the lonely task of writing so much easier,'' Natkin says. ``We always write faster than an individual does.'' A good writing team should spot a bomb even before the fuse is lit. Dialogue is read aloud, plot points are debated and character development is argued. Among the more successful teams, there's an unbreakable rule: If one half of the team doesn't like what the other half suggests, the idea goes to the Dumpster.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
HOLLYWOOD: the Dumpster.
DOC.TEXT: ``Writing teams tend to write less personal pieces but highly plotted pieces,'' says producer Lynda Obst, who co-wrote the new Hollywood novel ``Dirty Dreams'' with Carol Wolper. ``Their scripts have less internal logic, less of an internal voice. They're not literary. But they have an external logic that works in this business.'' Obst, now making ``The Fisher King'' with , internal films are written by people who sit up late at night by themselves. Jim and I are pop writers, writing for the masses.'' Some writing teams say differences of opinion rarely spark fights; others say a bloodletting occasionally brings new life to the creative process. Billy Wilder's battles with Charles Brackett were legendary and golden. The combative duo wrote Oscar-winning scripts for 1945's ``The Lost Weekend'' and 1950's ``Sunset Boulevard'' (written with D.M. Marshman Jr.), and the nominated script for 1948's ``A Foreign Affair'' (written with Richard Breen). ``We've had a lot of screaming,'' says Bruce Evans, whose 12-year association with Raynold Gideon has given birth to screenplays for ``Stand By Me,'' an Academy Award nominee, ``Starman,'' ``Made in Heaven,'' ``A Man, a Woman and a Bank'' and the upcoming ``The Day Before Midnight.'' ``It's very valuable having a partner disagree with you because if one partner can convince the other he can probably convince the audience, too. ... The end product outweighs the pain you have getting it, like a good marriage,'' Evans says. With most writing teams, the screenwriting credit is shared evenly, and some alternate the order in which their names appear. The work, however, sometimes is not split justly. Michael Beckner and Jim Gorman's script for ``Texas Lead and Gold'' recently sold in a deal valued at $1 million. Beckner is considered the writer of the team and Gorman the producing partner, writing little of the script. Novelist Roger Simon and director-writer Paul Mazursky are listed as the writers for both ``Enemies: A Love Story'' and ``Scenes From a Mall,'' a December release directed by Mazursky. Starring Woody Allen and Bette Midler, ``Scenes From a Mall'' is the first film Allen has acted in but not directed since 1976's ``The Front.'' When Mazursky works with a partner, be it Simon or Leonidas Capetanos, he confers with his colleague, outlining the story. Mazursky's partner then writes a first draft. Mazursky makes revisions to that draft, and the process begins again with both writers sharing the keyboard. ``It's sort of like tag-team wrestling,'' says Simon. ``I'm slightly more cerebral and he's slightly more theatrical.'' Although Cash and Epps work best many miles apart, most writing teams find proximity improves the product. Ganz and Mandel, for instance, who just finished a script for Billy Crystal titled ``City Slickers,'' sit across from each other in a small office. Before they begin writing their scripts in longhand, they outline the story on a series of index cards. The day's work is typed up overnight, which is reviewed the next morning and revised. ``When we read what we've just written, sometimes we weep, sometimes we say, `We're out of the business,''' Ganz said. ``Sometimes we dance together in the room.''

DOC.TEXT: It was where millions of people were introduced to America, a cavernous building on Ellis Island in New York Harbor, perhaps the largest building many of them had ever seen. Out of use and neglected for nearly 30 years, it has undergone a $156 million refurbishing and will reopen in September as the National Museum of Immigration.

The noble, soaring spaces are radiantly clean and dry again. Light streams in on a summer day. On one or two patches of wall restorers have left poignant graffiti, scribbled names and drawings of outstretched hands. The graffiti was the artwork of immigrants, some of the 12 million people seeking a new life who passed through this main building of the Ellis Island immigration station. They were the forebears of perhaps 140 million present-day Americans. ``Nowhere else can you say `almost half the population of the country can trace their ancestry back through this building,''' says architect John Belle, director of a $156 million Ellis Island restoration project. The architects in charge of the renovations were Belle's firm, Beyer Blinder Belle, and Notter Finegold & Alexander. They began work in 1983 to rescue the 220,000-square-foot building, neglected for more than a quarter of a century and left in a state of near-ruin. It will reopen to the public on Sept. 10 as the National Museum of Immigration and is expected to draw 2{ million visitors a year. ``We began by getting to know everything about the building, by documenting it to the umpteenth degree, every nook and cranny,'' says Belle, leading a tour of the beaux-arts structure. The familiar, warmly handsome, horizontal building in limestone and brick, with four copper-domed towers, dominates its island in the harbor alongside Liberty Island. The present building opened in 1900, replacing an earlier wooden structure destroyed by fire in 1897, along with all the records. The present building continued in use until 1954, when it was inherited, already in deteriorated condition, by the National Park Service. ``The original design of the building with its east and west wings was a very classical plan, and it was also a very efficient plan for moving people through,'' Belle says. ``Now, starting in September we're going to have numbers of people moving through again.'' In addition to describing the history and experiences of those Ellis Island immigrants, the museum will reflect the whole history of immigration into this country from all entry points. It also will present some of the achievements of those immigrants. Visitors will be able to follow the immigrants' route through the building. From the dock where the ferry from Manhattan will leave them _ as the steamship-company ferries used to leave their ancestors _ they'll walk to the main entrance under an airy new canopy, described by Belle as ``a contemporary interpretation of the original.'' Belle, a native of Wales who came to this country in 1959, specializes in historic preservation. In addition to the Ellis Island project, he directed the restoration of New York City's Grand Central Terminal and the South Street Seaport Museum, the Boston Customs House and the Delaware Aqueduct. ``The Park Service is very strict about never faking history,'' Belle says. ``That's a philosophy we share. We don't want to fool anybody with our project. This is a very, very careful restoration. ``When we came in the plaster was on the floor. All that has gone back in place. Where elements no longer existed we tried to design the modern equivalents. History will be the judge _ you will be the judge. ``This is an attempt to interpret the building, sometimes with elements that are not compatible in the design sense, but that try to tell the story.'' Most immigrants spent most of their time on Ellis Island in the second floor registry room. In its heyday it routinely handled 5,000 to 7,000 people a day. April 17, 1907, is believed to have been the peak day, when 11,747 came through. ``To many it must have seemed huge, and intimidating, the largest building they'd ever seen in their lives, filled with noise, a babel of languages,'' Belle says. And the lamps glittering along the balconies and shining down from the chandeliers would have been the first time many of them, coming from small villages and simple ways of life, ever saw electric light. At the far end of the great chamber is a memorable staircase: the one by which immigrants left after negotiating the nervous passage through desks and register books and questioning officers. The exit was to one of three destinations, down one of the three lanes separated by the staircase's two rails. On the left, you were off to catch a ferry into Manhattan; on the right, to buy your ticket for a train heading out West. But the center lane was the ``stair of separation'' down which immigrants were detoured for further formalities, entry to the promised land heartsinkingly postponed. They may have found themselves pleading their cases in the special inquiry room, a kind of court of last appeal. This is one of the few rooms that will be left as a ``period room,'' with its carved wooden railings directing anxious steps toward the judge's table. Many other interiors have been designed to accommodate exhibits, not to simulate the rooms' early appearance. In addition to the major exhibition areas, there are a library and reading room, an oral history center with a recording studio where immigrants and former employees may chronicle their memories, and a listening center where others may hear these recordings. Other public amenities include orientation areas, museum shops, two 146-seat movie theaters, meeting rooms and a restaurant with a terrace overlooking the harbor. A curatorial complex contains offices, research facilities and conservation labs.

DOC.TEXT: It pains lawyer-novelist Scott F. Turow that some big city critics have dismissed his work as unimportant. It hurts a lot, until he looks at his bank balance. The author of ``Presumed Innocent'' has learned to spin best sellers from his experiences as both a prosecutor and a defense attorney.

As a prosecutor who turned defense attorney, novelist Scott F. Turow knows how to mine the shadowy regions of the legal profession. In Turow's fiction, prosecutors are violated. And when the defense rests, it may be in the bed of the client's mistress. In Turow's real life, judges have been jailed and yesterday's prosecutorial target may be today's client. At age 41, Turow, now a partner in a major Chicago law firm, is two-for-two on the fiction best-seller lists, reaping considerable national publicity and fat paychecks. ``All I can say is they won't be holding any tag days for Scott Turow,'' he said in a telephone interview while on tour promoting his second published novel, ``Burden of Proof.'' In 1986, Turow stepped down after eight years as an assistant U.S. attorney in Chicago. He got a record $200,000 advance for his first published novel, ``Presumed Innocent,'' and watched it climb to the top of the hardbound best-seller lists. That was followed by 4.3 million paperback sales and a $1 million movie rights deal. The $20 million movie, starring Harrison Ford and directed by Alan Pakula, recently opened. The publicity surrounding ``Presumed Innocent'' made much of the fact that a high-profile prosecutor had written a thriller about a prosecutor being tried for murder. It was not noted widely that Turow's only job since graduating from Harvard Law School had been with the U.S. attorney's office, which does not handle murder cases. Perhaps coincidentally, the prosecutor-as-defendant theme had appeared in one of Turow's own real-life cases _ that of then-Illinois Attorney Gen. William J. Scott. Turow was one of the federal attorneys who obtained a tax fraud conviction against the state's chief prosecutor in 1980. ``I realize now _ and I think my wife, Annette, understood before I did _ that writing about the prosecution of a prosecutor was part of my preparation to do defense work,'' Turow said. Defense attorney Phillip Kurland argued in his unsuccessful appeal of Scott's conviction that Turow and his federal colleagues had turned the trial into a ``Roman circus.'' The phrase found a possibly subconscious echo in ``Presumed Innocent,'' when hero Rusty Sabich likens his murder trial to ``Christians and lions back in Rome.'' Before leaving his federal post, Turow also saw more legal ambiguities through his involvement in Operation Greylord, the federal probe that sent many Cook County Circuit Court judges to prison. The turn to defense work, which coincided with the publication of ``Presumed Innocent,'' brought Turow to Sonnenschein Nath & Rosenthal, a 300-attorney firm with offices in six cities. ``I suppose you could say I'm a specialist in white-collar criminal defense, mostly in the grand jury phase,'' he said. ``None of my clients are currently under indictment, although several are under investigation.'' ``I've walked both sides of the street now, and I really can see the system from both sides.'' Turow once got a slap on the wrist from the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. In 1987, a Miami cocaine trafficking defendant named Ronald Ofshe sought to have his indictment dismissed because his defense attorney, Marvin Glass, was serving as a federal drug informant. Glass himself was a defendant in the Chicago Greylord probe and was negotiating with Turow for leniency. With Turow's permission, Glass had secretly tape-recorded at least one of his conversations with Ofshe. Although the appellate court refused to dismiss Ofshe's indictment, it appended a footnote calling Turow's agreement with Glass ``reprehensible'' and recommending that Turow be investigated by attorney registration officials in Chicago. Turow's former superiors in the U.S. Justice Department later exonerated him, but the appeals court refused to strike the footnote from the record. Turow was asked if the incident may have been reflected in ``Burden of Proof,'' in which the lawyer-hero burglarizes his own client's house and also has a romantic scene in a hot tub with his prosecutorial adversary. ``There's no doubt that that contributed to my analysis of the attorney-client relationship,'' Turow said. ``Everything, after all, becomes fodder for the fictional mill. In retrospect, I'm just glad I could find something useful in something that was very painful and, I still feel, very unneccessary.'' Some critics have objected to the frequent sex scenes in ``Burden of Proof'' as unconvincing, but the author says that only the ultimately platonic hot-tub tryst caused him problems. ``I really had to work up my nerve to write it and submit it,'' he said. ``Presumed Innocent'' had its steamy scenes, too, but the critics found them more acceptable in what was, at heart, a traditional and gritty murder mystery. ``One of the exalted things about the mystery novel is its architecture,'' says Turow, who taught creative writing at Stanford University before going to law school. While at Stanford, Turow says he made ``three serious attempts'' to get a novel published and once cranked out a novel in three weeks to win a bet. ``I'm not sure I really won,'' he says in retrospect. Turow's first published book was ``One L,'' a non-fiction account of his first year at Harvard Law School, written on contract, but he says his early unpublished works may have helped him escape the ``second novel jinx.'' ``Maybe my good fortune with my second novel was that it ain't my second novel,'' he says. Reviews of ``Burden of Proof,'' although less enthusiastic than those for ``Presumed Innocent,'' tended to be favorable _ with several critics suggesting it was a more serious work than its predecessor. ``Of course the bad ones hurt,'' Turow said of the reviews. ``But they've been running about 8- or 9-to-1 favorably. I sometimes wonder if some of the negative reviewers aren't out to get me, but there's always that old lawyers' adage: `Reasonable minds can differ.''' And then again, no tag days.

DOC.TEXT: When Kevin Conway, the star of ``Other People's Money,'' left the play, Gallin replaced him with Stephen Keats, an experienced stage actor but not known to most theatergoers. ``We are kind of at the point in our run where we are a bit ambivalent,'' Gallin says of the play, which has been running in New York since February 1989. ``We don't think we need a name yet, but it would be nice to eventually have one.'' And most television actors welcome the prestige of appearing on Broadway. ``I can't let opportunities like this go by,'' Busfield says. ``I've been in the movie `Field of Dreams.' I've been in a hit television series. I needed a play. I needed to establish to myself and to the people in this business that I can be a lead in a play, and the play won't fall apart and close in one night.'' Perlman wasn't pursuing theater roles when he was offered the job in ``A Few Good Men'' to replace Stephen Lang and quickly took it. ``I use the same criteria for wanting to do this job as I use for any job,'' Perlman says. ``Is the role challenging? Is it allowing me to explore parts of humanity I haven't had the chance to tap into? Is it a role I can have respect and enthusiasm for?'' Television stars coming to the New York theater are nothing new. Lucille Ball tried it in 1960 with the musical ``Wildcat.'' It ran only six months, closing when Ball became ill and left the show. Mary Tyler Moore has played Broadway several times with varying degrees of success. Her first attempt, right after ``The Dick Van Dyke Show'' in 1963, was ``Breakfast at Tiffany's,'' a huge flop that closed in previews and never officially opened. Her co-star was Richard Chamberlain of ``Dr. Kildare'' fame. She had more luck replacing Tom Conti in ``Whose Life is It Anyway?'', in which the playwright changed the leading character from a man to a woman to accommodate the actress. Despite the powerful presence of Tyne Daly in ``Gypsy,'' its producer, Barry Weissler, discounts the attraction of television names to theater audiences. Movie stars like Kathleen Turner and Dustin Hoffman sell tickets, he says. ``TV stars do not sell tickets because the people who made them television stars don't go to the theater,'' he says. ``They watch television. ``With `Gypsy,' we were up and down on the road before coming to New York,'' Weissler said. ``It was an enormous risk, but we had two things going for us. We had a brilliant show, and a woman playing Rose who had the talent. Had she not been able to come up to the role, we would have been dead in the water. Because she surprised everyone, it helped us. That had nothing to do with star power. That had to do with people telling their friends, `You've got to see this.''' Still, Weissler cast Lavin as Daly's replacement. ``Linda is a very well-known Broadway stage actress,'' he says. ``So she's going to draw the theater public. But she also hit it big with `Alice.' So maybe tourists, coming in during the summer, might choose to see `Gypsy' because they remember the show. I might have a double punch going for me.'' Producer James Walsh toured ``I'm Not Rappaport,'' the comedy by Herb Gardner, with its original stars, Judd Hirsh, late of ``Taxi,'' and Cleavon Little, star of the Mel Brooks movie comedy ``Blazing Saddles.'' ``It probably was the most successful tour of a play anyone has done in the last decade,'' he said. ``We broke house records. ``Sometimes you can send a very good play out and because you want to satisfy the need for a star, you end up doing half the production you should be doing.'' When Walsh sends his current Broadway hit ``The Heidi Chronicles'' out on the road this fall, the star in Los Angeles and possibly other cities will be Amy Irving, an actress with theater and movie credits but without proven box-office appeal. ``I don't want to take someone from a television series, if they can't act on stage,'' Walsh says. ``So I think it's a better break for an audience, if you get somebody who is really good, who may or may not have a high profile, but will serve the play. So if I don't deliver them a big star, I can promise them a really good production.''

DOC.HEAD: Grieving Family Struggles To Make Sense of Tornado's Senseless Rage
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In the brief, ringing silence after the tornado passed, Donna Ray realized 15-month-old Benjamin was gone. The 250 mph wind had torn the Rays' only son from his mother's arms. Their trailer home had exploded. The family of six was suddenly five. ``I was the one who had hold of Benny. I was supposed to have held on to him and not let anything hurt him,'' Donna said. ``There's nothing worse than knowing you can't keep things from hurting your kids, that you've got no control.'' And no one to blame. ``It was nobody's fault,'' Donna's husband, Tim, said flatly. It is the tragedy's randomness that is hardest to take. ``I just want him back ... want to watch him grow up,'' Donna said. ``We tried so long to have a little boy and then we get him, and he's gone.'' Said Geneva Speer, the baby's great-aunt: ``They had three girls and wanted a boy so bad. They really couldn't afford to have all them kids, but they kept having them until they got them a boy.'' More than a month after Benjamin's death, the Rays still are revisiting the moments before everything stopped making sense. They retrace their steps but know there is no changing them. The June 2 storm, which killed eight people and injured 180, was the worst to hit Indiana in 16 years. It spun through town in four minutes, devouring the Rays' home at Riverview Trailer Park in seconds. Tim, Donna and their three young daughters were scattered in hospital emergency rooms, their lives uprooted like the grove of 20 poplar trees that used to shade the family's trailer on hot August afternoons. The two-acre trailer park now resembles a haunted battleground littered with the munitions of everyday life: Dad's ratchet, the dog's rubber ball, Mom's ironing board and the children's bright-colored toys. ``The thing that keeps us going are the three little girls. We can still pick them up and hold them,'' said Tim, 31, a wiry man with a freckled face. ``But my little boy ... I was not ready to give him up.'' The tornado struck without warning. ``We'd just come home from the store. I'd no more than got the water on to boiling for dinner,'' said Donna, 27, who first saw the green-tinted sky churning outside the kitchen window. ``They say tornados make a noise, but we didn't hear anything. We were already in the middle of it,'' she said. Donna screamed for her husband. ``Get in back,'' Tim shouted. The lights flickered, then went out. Each parent grabbed two children. Donna had her left arm wrapped around Benny. With her right, she dragged 6-year-old Abby by her blue-flowered summer dress. ``Get in back,'' Tim screamed again. Too late. The trailer's four walls blew out. Donna looked down. The ground was swirling beneath her. Hold on to Benny, hold on, she thought. Then Benny was gone. ``Oh my God,'' Donna cried and fell to the ground. The tornado had passed. When Tim opened his eyes, he saw Benny lying face-down a few feet from his unconscious mother. ``I picked him up and he was real limp,'' Tim said. ``It was quiet. Like in a desert, there was just silence all around.'' Then came tears. Abby, Ginny, 7, and 3-year-old Melissa were half-buried by debris, their pale skin gashed and wispy brown hair matted with blood. Tim groped toward them, pulling himself out of the mud each time his broken leg collapsed. Donna soon came around. But she still was in a daze. ``All I could think about was getting help,'' said Donna, whose forehead was slashed and collarbone broken when the wind's current dropped her. ``I wanted to get Benny in the car because it was raining and cold. I was telling myself: `I'm going to get help. I'm going to take him to the hospital.''' The Rays strapped the baby into his car seat. But they knew. Benny was motionless, silent, showed no sign of breathing. His soft skull had been crushed. ``I just didn't want to admit that it could be my baby that was taken,'' said Donna, her expression more blank than bitter. The funeral was a blur. Sad embraces, prayers led by a Pentecostal minister whom Tim met back when he first started working at a local fast-food restaurant 10 years ago. It took only two pallbearers to lift the blue metal casket into the hearse. Faith is the frequent counsel in this town of 14,000 people, 42 Christian churches and about 75 pastors. Friends and strangers tell the Rays that Benjamin is God's child now. It's of little comfort. ``Some would say it's an act of God ... but try telling that to the woman whose baby is jerked out of her arms,'' said the Rev. Max Toliver, a Methodist minister whose neighboring trailer also was destroyed in the storm. Tim and Donna, who don't attend church regularly, have gratefully accepted prayers, Bibles, pamphlets and other gestures meant to ease their despair. They know about counseling, the books on loss and talk shows on pain. But nothing works. Nothing can restore Benny or the domestic dream Tim and Donna nearly grasped before they were sucked into the vortex. ``When we got married I set some goals. I wanted to have little boys and I've always wanted to have a garden, fence off a place, get the kids a pony, maybe build them a big old playhouse,'' Tim said. That was eight years ago, when the couple set out to create the kind of large and close-knit family they knew as kids growing up in this rural area about 60 miles south of Indianapolis. The night the tornado hit, Tim and Donna were feeling good. They'd made a dent in their debts and set aside part of the $20,000-a-year salary Tim earns managing a local Hardee's restaurant. They were planning to buy a piece of land somewhere in the rolling, green country near here. Now they are living in a rental house stocked and paid for with thousands of dollars from strangers, family and friends, like Tim's co-workers at Hardee's restaurants. ``This community is a family,'' said Donna. ``I don't know how we're ever going to thank them, and that bothers us.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, July 22, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: BEDFORD, Ind.: bothers us.''
DOC.TEXT: Accepting the spontaneous charity has been painful for the Rays, who have always done for themselves. They are the kind of people who fix their own cars or sew their own clothes as much out of pride as practicality. They also took pride in their baby pictures and birth certificates, the girls' favorite dolls, Tim's comic book collection, Donna's half-sewn dress, even the red polka-dot cutouts for learning ABCs _ all of which the tornado spewed over miles of wooded and rain-soaked land. ``You can tell they loved their kids a lot. Just look at all these toys,'' said the Rev. Johnny Johnson of Dive Christian Church. He was among a band of family, neighbors and preachers who in the hot days following the storm showed up to save for the Rays what muddied belongings they could. They burned the rest. ``When I first saw this, I went home and cried,'' said Beth Cooper, a mother of two who showed up to help a couple she'd never met. ``I suddenly knew how close we are to dust.'' Now, in the wreckage of their lives, the Rays see the normalcy they once had, the sense of control they are struggling to regain. They are looking now for some small order amid the chaos. Donna wants a new blue mailbox with a red flag, like the one she used to visit each day for bills and the occasional card. When Cuddles, one of two family dogs, turned up alive miles from home it was as though the slightly terrorized, shaggy pup was a gift from God. ``You've got to have certainties,'' Johnson said, tossing a tattered garment into the bonfire. ``They give you hope, strength, goals _ and everybody needs those because, evidently, what you own is not for certain.'' Tim and Donna still are thinking about what they want on their son's headstone. Most likely, it will be something simple: Our little Benny. ``Mommy, did Benjamin die?'' Abby asked not long after the storm. ``He went to heaven, didn't he?'' ``Yes, he did,'' Donna told her. ``We're telling the kids that he went to heaven. I think it helps them,'' she said. ``But me, I just want him back.''

DOC.TEXT: An ill wind reached into Donna Ray's arms and wrested her 15-month-old son, thrusting Benjamin into the maelstrom. When the tornado passed, wreckage of the Rays' lives was everywhere to see _ a trailer home reduced to rubble, broken bones, belongings strewn for miles. And worst of all, the lifeless body of their only son, the boy they had wanted so much. ``My little boy ... I was not ready to give him up,'' says his father.

Star Watch: Private Actor Most at Home in Big Sky Country
DOC.TEXT: Just in from the Big Sky country, Harrison Ford faced a peril as hazardous as any encountered by Han Solo and Indiana Jones: the press tour. Ford is a private man, and he approaches an interview with the zest of Roseanne Barr facing a diet. His verbal fencing, especially on personal matters, is notorious with news types. Jim Brown of ``The Today Show'' recently tried to wheedle Ford into disclosing the sex of his unborn baby. Ford knew, but declined to say. The baby turned out to be a girl, born June 30. Unlike some major stars, Ford feels a responsibility to the studios who pay him huge salaries for his work (upwards of $7 million). Hence he came here for two grueling days of radio, TV and print interviews for ``Presumed Innocent,'' the Warner Bros. film based on Scott Turow's blockbuster book. Also taking part were co-stars Bonnie Bedelia, Brian Dennehy, Raul Julia and Paul Winfield and director Alan J. Pakula. His co-workers had revealing things to say about Ford. Bedelia: ``(The film) was the first time I had met him. He's a very interior type of person; he keeps his own counsel. I think he's a marvelous actor. In this picture he was very _ soulful. .. . He was very giving, generous, sensitive. A lovely man.'' Winfield: ``Harrison and I first met when we were both under contract to Columbia Pictures (in the mid-1960s). I was brought in after the Watts riots because the studios decided they needed angry young men, and I fit into that category. It was the end of the contract period, and the only friend I made was Harrison. ... He was the same as he is now. Except he's a lot richer.'' Pakula: ``I thought of Harrison from the beginning. I wanted someone who was like Everyman, who had an All-American kind of quality. ... I am interested in characters who are two-sided, who can be a collection of opposites. ``Harrison is very bright, he has a sense of storytelling, especially a complicated story like this one. It's great to have someone who says, `Have you told that?' `Does the audience understand that?' `Explain that to me.' I said to my wife, `Harrison asks simple questions that sometimes have very complicated answers.''' Pakula added that he had worked with three people who became Academy Award directors: James L. Brooks, Warren Beatty and Robert Redford. Ford could have equal success if he wanted to turn director, Pakula said. He doesn't. Acting is enough challenge for him. In ``Presumed Innocent,'' Ford portrays a married prosecutor accused of murdering a beautiful colleague (Greta Scacchi) with whom he had a flaming affair. The role calls for greater depth of feeling than Ford has displayed on the screen before. Nothing unusual, he said. ``It seems to me it's the same job every time: trying to figure out what the ideas are and to give them expression. The more of an idea there is, the easier it is to give it life. This was a character that was extremely well-written and had great complexity. And the complexity was well-knit to the plot. It was really an easy part to play.'' Ford had not read the Turow novel, and he held off until he could see the movie script, by Frank Pierson and Pakula. ``I didn't want to prejudice my impression of the screenplay,'' he said. ``I immediately read the book afterward. Then I worked with Alan for six or eight months before the films started.'' The role is far, far removed from Ford's portrayals in the ``Star Wars'' and ``Indiana Jones'' movies. Mixing drama and action has been part of his strategy: ``It has always been my intention that that might help to keep my career alive. I like doing different kinds of films, I like facing different kinds of challenges.'' Ford grew up in suburban Chicago, drifted into acting at Ripon College, mostly as a way to meet women. After a stint in summer stock, he drove to California in 1964 with his new wife, Mary Marquardt. The Columbia contract proved a dead end, and Harrison made more money from carpentry than from acting. Did he grow impatient in those years? ``Often,'' he said. ``Impatient and frustrated. But when I look back on it, I really did know from the very beginning that it was the kind of job that took a long time to get into. And that the really secret of it all was just outlasting the competition and not giving up. As well as taking that period of time to develop your craft and to mature.'' Between building houses, Ford appeared in TV serials and such films as ``The Conversation'' and ``American Graffiti.'' ``When I went away to do `Star Wars,' I had the feeling that I might be packing up my carpentry stuff for the last time,'' he recalled. ``After that, I was able to work when I wanted to work.'' Ford and his second wife, screenwriter Melissa Matheson (``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial''), make their home amid the Tetons of Wyoming, about as far from the Hollywood scene as is possible. When the actor goes filming, the entire family goes with him, including son Malcolm, 3{, and, when they're able, two college-age sons from the first marriage. Ford continues with drama in his next film, ``Regarding Henry,'' with Mike Nichols, his director in ``Working Girl.'' The role casts Ford as a successful New York lawyer who becomes an amnesiac after being shot in the head. Therapy allows him to reinvent his life and relationships. And if Harrison Ford could reinvent his life? A faint grin appeared on the handsome face. ``I'm quite happy with what I've got. I can't imagine doing much better.''

The Artists: Hitch-Hiking to Art
DOC.TEXT: Doc Tate Nevaquaya doesn't know what course his life might have taken if his cousins hadn't happened along while he was trying to hitch-hike. ``I was going to Oklahoma City to join the Marine Corps,'' recalls Nevaquaya. ``They bought me a ticket and put me on thece, Kansas, to enroll in a trade school. I had 35 cents in my pocket.'' Times have changed for Nevaquaya since then. He no bus for Lawrenw is an internationally acclaimed artist whose work includes designing a shield on the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery. He also sold a painting to England's Queen Elizabeth II for about $1,200. Nevaquaya paints in the traditional two-dimensional Indian style, which often has the main object or feature outlined. Some work is a flat dimension, resulting in a semi-abstract work. His canvas, ``Native American Church,'' depicts 16 figures involved in religious ceremonies. Nevaquaya's paintings range in price from $500 tp $7,000. Most of his work is done in watercolor. ``I feel that most closely depicts the effects of the earth pigments,'' Nevaquaya says. For some work, he mixes the watercd interest in the Indian flute. The citation hailed him for being ``one of the few remaining artists'' to link past generations with the future. ``People have asked me to play the flute for everything from banquets to weddings and church services,'' Nevaquaya says. ``Former U.S. Senator Fred Harris flew me to Washington to play at the wedding of his daughter.'' Nevaquaya also has been the subject of television documentaries, has appeared with country music star Roy Clark, has played at the Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in Washington, and appeared on British television while on a goodwill tour sponsored by the State Department and the Smithsonian Institution. He has appeared in concerts or lectures in Europe and the Far East. Nevaquaya has taken the Grand Award for his paintings at various art shows, including exhibitions in Chicago and Albuquerque, N.M. However, there was a time when the future didn't look all that bright. Nevaquaya, formally Joyce Lee Tate Nevaquaya, was orphaned when he was 13. He lived for a time with an older brother in the Apache-Fletcher area of rural southern Oklahoma. Both the nickname Doc and the Joyce are in honor of Dr. C.W. Joyce, a physician for whom many Indian children in the Fletcher area were named. It was while he was living with his brother that he started that fateful trip to Oklahoma City to enlist in the Marines. ``I had just started hitch-hiking when my cousins picked me up,'' Nevaquaya says. ``If they hadn't come by, within a few minutes my whole life might have been changed.'' Nevaquaya says his brother didn't know where he was or where he had gone until he wrote him a letter from the trade school, which now is Haskell Indian Junior College. Although Nevaquaya says he painted and sketched in the 1940s, he stayed away from the art classes while attending the Fort Sill Indian School because he did not like the policy that discouraged all painting except portrayals of traditional Indian culture. His interest in art was honed by the fact that an early neighbor had been Allan Houser, a painter who now is an acclaimed sculptor. He later met and became friends with artist Black Moon Riddles. Although he sold a few of his paintings in the early 1950s, he painted and sketched in his spare time while holding down a job. Then, in 1955, Doris Littrell of Oklahoma City sought him out after seeing some of his work at the Southern Plains Indian Museum in Anadarko. From that point on, Nevaquaya made art his vocation. Nevaquaya is in demand for his expertise with the Indian flute as are his paintings by collectors throughout the world. He frequently holds workshops at high schools and colleges and has taught his sons _ he has five, along with four daughters _ to play the flute. But although his fortune has changed for the better, Nevaquaya still lives in the rural town of Apache. And instead of a fancy northern-lighted studio, he still paints at home, on a table in his bedroom.

Music Makers: Chrissie Hynde Is Changing; Her Music Isn't
DOC.TEXT: Critics can be found in the strangest places. Try the back seat of Chrissie Hynde's car. One evening this spring, the Pretenders leader popped a working tape of her band's new album into the cassette deck of her car. She drove in circles around Regents Park in London, trying to decide if the running order of the songs made musical sense. Hynde's 5- and 7-year-old daughters were dozing in the back seat _ or so she thought. Suddenly, a small voice peeped up from behind. ``Mummy,'' her youngest daughter asked. ``Can we hear `Sense of Purpose' again?''' Smart kid. The longing-for-love ballad is probably the best of 12 songs on ``Packed,'' the first new Pretenders album since 1986. Since the early 1980 release of a debut Pretenders album that has aged into a classic, Hynde's life _ and band _ have changed considerably. Her music hasn't. Hynde is the only constant in the Pretenders' life. Over the years, she's seen two band members die drug-related deaths, fired a drummer and seen another guitarist quit to join Paul McCartney's band. She insists the Pretenders are still a band, although she and drummer Blair Cunningham are currently the only members. The search is on for a guitarist and bass player in time for a tour of the United States expected to start in late September. Hynde's two daughters are aware of what their mother does for a living, but the car ride was the first time she remembered them reacting to her work. They usually listen to their nanny's opera or classical recordings. ``I feel like I'm more humanitarian because of my relationship as a mother,'' she said during a recent interview. ``When I walk through Central Park, I want to be seen in the community as a mother. I don't want to be seen as a celebrity or a show business figure.'' Her children are the product of relationships with fellow musicians Ray Davies of the Kinks and Jim Kerr of Simple Minds. She married Kerr, but they're now separated. Motherhood hasn't necessarily softened the outspoken woman who wrote ``Tattooed Love Boys'' _ just ask her opinion about the nation's drug war. More about that later. But the differences in her life have obviously changed her approach to work. It's the chief reason why there was a four-year gap between Pretenders albums. ``Since I've been in the hotel the past week, I wake up at 6 o'clock in the morning and the first thing I do is reach for a guitar,'' said Hynde, who was over from London for a publicity tour. ``I haven't done that for years,'' she said. ``When I'm home, the first thing I do is go downstairs and turn the television off and get breakfast together for the kids.'' The new album, she said, is ``me going back down to my medium'' after recording her last disc while caring for an infant. ``Packed'' is a combination of hard-nosed rockers such as ``Hold a Candle to This'' and ``Downtown (Akron)'' and such ballads as ``Let's Make a Pact'' and ``When Will I See You.'' In spots, it sounds eerily like the first Pretenders album. Too much so, for some critics' tastes, who've pointed out the similarity of ``Packed'' to some of Hynde's past work. Most often cited is the mournful first single, ``Never Do That,'' a close cousin to ``Back on the Chain Gang.'' That's OK, Hynde said. Let them all talk. ``They're allowed to say whatever they want,'' she said. ``If that's how they see it, that's how they see it. Fine. I use the same five chords, rearrange them, talk about different things and have different melodies. I don't consciously think, `Oh no, this sounds too much like something else.''' ``Packed'' contains Hynde's second song about her hometown of Akron, Ohio. The first, ``My City Was Gone,'' bemoans the city's economic slump. ``Downtown'' is about how the 1980s mall culture affected the city. The critical eye she displays in the two songs doesn't lessen her feelings for her hometown _ she said she had a great time in her most recent visit. Hynde even toyed with the idea of buying a house where she used to live in the early 1970s, but was sidetracked when she got back to London. That visit also taught the 37-year-old Hynde, an art student at Kent State University at the time of Vietnam War demonstrations, how things have changed in the country she left in the mid-1970s. ``When I went to my high school reunion and tried to roll a joint, half the room turned into my parents,'' she said, and she's angry about the ``right-wing fervor'' that has lumped marijuana use with harder drugs as criminal behavior. ``As far as I'm concerned, I reserve the right to smoke an herb that grows in the ground,'' she said. ``I don't drink. I don't smoke cigarettes. I don't take any drugs. I'm completely vegetarian. I lead a nice, clean, easy life and don't cause any trouble. The fact that I'm automatically of a criminal status because I smoke pot ...'' Her voice trailed off. Hynde's musical career took shape in London's fertile punk scene during the late 1970s. These days, she's found planning a tour is a lot more complicated than piling everyone into a van; Hynde may be the first rocker whose work schedule may be partly governed by her nanny. ``My nanny's in school training to be a dance therapist for deaf children,'' she said. ``I am sort of planning my career around her schedule because I like her, she's part of the family and it's important to have a secure setup. It's give and take.''
