Books and Authors: A Thousand Restless Nights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Song writer'' is cq in 2nd graf; title ``An Old Fashioned Wedding'' is cq in 24th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Irving Berlin once insisted there were nine rules to writing popular songs. They must be original, easy to sing, easy to remember, ``sexless'' so that a man or woman could perform them and should have attention-getting titles. But most important, Berlin stated, ``The song writer must look upon his work as a business, that is, to make a success of it, he must work and work, and then WORK.'' And he meant it. American music, it seems, was created on a thousand restless nights by a shy little man with a high voice who insisted, ``I sweat blood between 3 and 6 many mornings, and when the drops that fall off my forehead hit the paper they're notes.'' He liked to write in the evening, sleep in the morning and pitch songs in the afternoon; sometimes he didn't bother sleeping. On a winter's night in 1941, Berlin began working on ``White Christmas.'' He finished it the next morning and raced over to his office, telling his stunned transcriber that ``not only is it the best song I ever wrote, it's the best song anybody ever wrote.'' Berlin always seemed to have a plan. In 1909, he set himself a goal of writing four to five songs a night, creating an enormous backlog of unused or ``trunk songs'' _ ``God Bless America'' among them. Nearly 80 years later, Steven Spielberg tried to negotiate for film rights to the great love song ``Always,'' but the director was curtly informed that Berlin wanted to use it for a project _ never started _ of his own. The movie, also called ``Always,'' was released in December 1989, three months after the songwriter's death at age 101. What kept him going? According to Laurence Bergreen, author of the comprehensive biography ``As Thousands Cheer: The Life of Irving Berlin'' ($24.95, Viking), it wasn't love or greed or even artistic ambition. The sound of applause, the need for the public's approval was the songwriter's greatest inspiration, the author said. ``He began by singing for pennies and nickels in the sidewalks of New York,'' explained Bergreen, also author of ``James Agee: A Life.'' ``If people liked what he sang they gave him money and if they didn't like it, they didn't give him money and he didn't eat. ``You wrote songs. They were performed, and the audience heard it. You would stay up all night and fix it to and try to make it better. That's how you developed, with the immediate feedback.'' Bergreen raises the same question again and again: How did Berlin remain so prolific for so long? How did he change with the times for nearly 40 years until another self-made man named Elvis Presley redefined popular music and pushed a frustrated Berlin into retirement? ``He was totally market driven,'' Bergreen said. ``I think what's remarkable is that every 10 years or so he tried to reinvent himself as a songwriter; popular songwriters then tended to come and go as quickly as they do now. ``He consciously adapted himself to changing styles. Ragtime in the 'teens (`Alexander's Ragtime Band') to sob songs in the '20s (`Always') to romantic ballads (`Cheek to Cheek') in the '30s. In the '40s, you notice a pronounced influence of swing music (`I Got the Sun in the Morning').'' Irving Berlin was born Israel Baline on May 11, 1888, the son of a Russian cantor and one of eight children. His family emigrated to the United States in 1893 and settled into the heavily populated Jewish community of Manhattan's Lower East Side. While his parents and siblings stuck to the ways of the old country, even speaking in Yiddish, Berlin raced into the new world, hustling to get out of his family's cramped, dirty tenement as quickly as possible and make it to the classy world that waited uptown. He hawked newspapers, spoke in colorful New York slang, earned coins as a singing waiter. Eventually, he changed his name and tried writing his own songs, reasoning, ``Once you start singing, you start thinking of writing songs, it's as simple as that.'' He wrote his first song, ``Marie From Sunny Italy,'' in 1908 and soon joined a music publishing house called Waterson & Snyder. In 1911, Berlin contributed four songs to the Ziegfield Follies, and hammered out ``Alexander's Ragtime Band,'' a lively update of the ``classic'' ragtime made popular by Scott Joplin in 1899. Like any quick-thinking kid, Berlin was looking for an angle, a gimmick _ some way to grab onto a trend _ and seized on ragtime as the answer. But he was also willing to take chances, play with the rules and invent the rules. ``Alexander's Ragtime Band,'' the name inspired by the derogatorially named ``coon'' songs that had ``Alexander'' in the title, combined popular black and white music, mixing ragtime and march. The chorus ran 32 bars, double the usual length, and the song changed key in mid-course, another innovation. ``I humbly began to study my own song, asking myself, `Why?' `Why?','' Berlin recalled in 1915, reflecting on its international success. ``And I got an answer. ... It's opening words, emphasized by immediate repitition _ `Come on and hear! Come on and hear!' _ were an invitation to `come' and join in, and `hear' the singer and his song.'' ``There were distinctive yard marks in his songs that you could see,'' Bergreen said. ```Puttin' on the Ritz' on the one hand and `God Bless America' as the other. You had anthems of basic American events: `White Christmas,' `Easter Parade'; ragtime songs like `Alexander's Ragtime Band.' ``And there was the counterpoint song, `Just in Love,' `Play a Simple Melody,' `An Old Fashioned Wedding.' There were two songs kind of going at the same time, two singers singing against each other.'' Berlin could neither read nor write music and his business skills were equally crude, equally effective. He had dropped out of school at age 14 to earn money and had to scramble around town, pitching his songs to publishers; until his death in 1989, his office never had a computer. But if Berlin sweated blood as a businessman, the drops that fell quickly turned to cash. He realized early on that publishing was where the most money could be made and held on stubbornly to the rights of his songs, boasting for years that he received the highest royalty payments in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: the nation.
DOC.TEXT: ``I think there are twin facts of the same painstaking approach,'' Bergreen said. ``He was just as careful at selling songs as he was writing them. He would make the rounds of the music stores to make sure the sheet music was stocked on the shelfs, and would get angry if it wasn't selling.'' Berlin's last major success came in 1950 with the musical ``Call Me Madam.'' Five years later, rock 'n' roll ended his career and those of many Tin Pan Alley writers. ``He came to a country where you could do anything you want,'' Bergreen said. ``His patriotism was incredible; it was his religion. That's what he believed in, `God Bless America,' a merging of patriotic and religious sentiments. ``With the rise of rock 'n' roll, everything he stood for, Tin Pan Alley and classical writing and the American values went out of favor.'' Berlin tried. In 1962, he broke a five-year silence and announced he was working on a musical satire on the Kennedys called ``Mr. President.'' There were 22 songs, including ``Washington Twist,'' a take on the latest dance craze. More than $1 million worth of tickets were sold before the cast was even announced. It was a disaster. Elliot Norton of the Record American in Boston labeled it ``Dreadful ... Anything milder would be misleading, not to say dishonest.'' When the show opened at the National Theatre in Washington, President Kennedy didn't show up until the second act and left soon after. Six months later, with advance tickets used up, the show quickly closed. ``You don't have to stop yourself (from writing songs),'' a shaken Berlin said in a radio interview. ``The people who have to listen to your songs tell you to stop.'' Berlin outlived his peers _ Harold Arlen, George Gershwin, Cole Porter, Jerome Kern. He outlived his siblings. He outlived his two favorite performers, Ethel Merman and Fred Astaire. He outlived his wife of more than 60 years, Ellin Mackey, who died on July 29, 1988. And he even outlived some of his songs. In 1986, ``Alexander's Ragtime Band'' turned 75, lost its protection under United States copyright law and became part of the public domain, an area Berlin himself had long occupied. He hoped that Hollywood would produce a musical retrospective of his work, ``Say It With Music,'' but the deal fell through. Berlin spent most of his remaining years in virtual seclusion, refusing interviews and making angry, profanity-laced phone calls to journalists and friends who talked about him publicly. ``He stayed at his house in Manhattan,'' Bergreen said. ``He watched a lot of television and rarely saw anyone except for the barber or his doctor or servants. ``He built up a small network of music historians and pundits in the field of popular music, and would endlessly talk shop with them. Also Harold Arlen; that was how he stayed in touch with the world.'' Berlin avoided tributes, including a lavish celebration of his 100th birthday at Carnegie Hall that featured Frank Sinatra, Leonard Bernstein and a chorus of Girl and Boy Scouts. He did, however, appear before an audience one last time. John Wallowitch, a composer and cabaret singer, had lived near the songwriter for years and the two occasionally chatted in the street. He soon began an annual tradition. On Christmas Eve, Wallowitch would stop in front of Berlin's building and softly sing ``White Christmas,'' his own private ceremony. Soon, others joined him, and they began to sing out loud. By 1983, there were 17 carolers. ``It was 4 degrees and the place was dark,'' Wallowitch recalled in a telephone interview. ``I never thought he was there; it was just symbolic. But one friend of mine said we should ring the droobell, he might be there. ``I finally rang the bell and the housekeeper answered. We said we were serenading Mr. Berlin and she said she was going to tell him. He came down in his bathrobe and slippers and invited us in. He said it was the nicest Christmas present he ever had. ``We told him we were coming back for the next 77 years to do that, and he said, `Good, good.' We were all in a state of shock. We floated out of there and went back to my house. We sang his songs for 2{ hours _ without repeating one of them.''

ashville Sound: Boots Randolph Is Still Challenged
DOC.TEXT: Boots Randolph says it's still a challenge to play the saxophone after 40 years. ``Every time I pick the horn up, it's more intriguing to me,'' the 63-year-old Randolph says. ``It satisfies my desire to do whatever I do.'' He's earned the nickname ``Mr. Sax'' for his 30 albums and background work on dozens of other songs such as Elvis Presley's rendition of ``Return to Sender.'' His new album, ``Boots,'' is his first in about seven years, and is being sold only on television. ``It has the potential to be a big album, a world album,'' Randolph said in an interview *#* *#* *#* 1335 +10 Jul *#* *#* *#* 1355 +10 Sep *#* *#* *#* 1375 +5 Dec *#* *#* *#* 1405 +8 Est. sales 2,878. DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: She may be the daughter of the king of rock 'n' roll, but how much does anyone know about the real Lisa Marie Presley? Authors David Adler and Ernest Andrews promise to ``tell all'' in their unauthorized biography, ``Elvis My Dad'' (St. Martin's Paperbacks; $3.95), to be published next month. The result of hundreds of meetings with never-before-interviewed friends and schoolmates as well as members of the Graceland staff, ``Elvis My Dad'' is full of Lisa's life with and without father. Now 22 years old, Lisa is married, with a daughter, Danielle. She's reconciled with her mother, Priscilla, and is about to inherit millions.

Kevin Costner will star in a film dealing with the life of Michael Collins, Ireland's legendary hero who led the fight for Irish independence in the early part of this century. The film, based on a screenplay by Eoghan Harris and Robert Dillon, will be produced by Costner and Jim Wilson. It will be filmed on location in Ireland, with principal photography scheduled to commence in September of this year.

More than 3,000 poets from the United States, Canada and 27 other countries will converge when the ``World of Poetry,'' the largest organization of poets in the world, holds its sixth annual international convention next month. In addition to its membership, Bob Hope, Joan Rivers, William Shatner, Pearl Bailey and Red Buttons will recite their works as well as entertain the attendees at the meeting that runs Aug. 26-28. Soviet poet Natasha Borovsky; Dr. Kenneth Fan, poet laureate of Taiwan; and former U.S. Sen. Eugene McCarthy are expected to attend. A highlight of the convention will include a ``Poets for Peace Balloonathon,'' in which each poet lofts a poem tied to a balloon into the air. Over the past 15 years, the Northern California-based ``World of Poetry'' has provided its members with poetic justice _ a chance not only to express oneself, but to be heard. The organization augments its annual convention by issuing a quarterly newsletter combining practical advice on publishing and poetry news. The group also regularly collects and publishes the poetic work of its members in anthologies.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: `Arachnophobia,' `The Adventures of Ford Fairlane'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Arachnophobia'' opens July 18; ``Ford Fairlane'' opened July 13.
DOC.TEXT: ``Arachnophobia'' Just when you thought it was safe to go play in the barn, along comes a spider who makes killer bees look like Bambi. Frank Marshall's ``Arachnophobia'' is the first release from the Walt Disney Co.'s new Hollywood Pictures and Steven Spielberg's Amblin Entertainment. Spielberg is also co-executive producer with Marshall. The movie has all the slick production values of a Spielberg venture, as well as the picture book Americana that seem to permeate his movies. It also is highly derivative of other scare movies, even down to the Norman Bates shower scene (in this case, the specter of death is a spider). But is ``Arachnophobia'' really, really scary? No. Is it unsettling? On occasion. Is it amusing? Sometimes. Is it entertaining? Yes. The movie opens in the plump rain forests of Venezuela where Dr. James Atherton (Julian Sands) is seeking new insects for tagging and study. His photographer, Jerry Manley, is bitten by a huge spider and dies. Only, no one really knows it was a spider bite that did him in. His body is shipped back to his hometown, Canaima, Calif. (named by the filmmakers after the Venezuelan town where the movie was filmed), with a stowaway _ the spider. Once in the Canaima mortuary (with the ancient gag of a sandwich-chomping undertaker), the spider escapes to the outside world, terrorizing a dog and cat. A hungry grackle plucks up the spider in its beak. The spider bites the bird and the feathered creature falls dead right in front of the barn of the Jennings family, who have just moved from the perils of San Francisco for the safety of the country. Oh happy day! New meat. Ross Jennings (Jeff Daniels) is a family doctor, about to take over the practice of a country quack, Sam Metcalf (Henry Jones), who at the last minute decides to stay on. With the first death from a spider bite _ Jennings' one and only patient _ the two doctors lock heads over cause of death and an autopsy. The next victim is also someone Jennings' examines, and he soons earns the nickname _ even from his own kids _ of Dr. Death. The victims multiply and so do the arachnids. There are the usual near-misses: Jennings' daughter, Shelley, is playing with the her friend, Bunny Beechwood. A spider nears her foot, ready to bite. She doesn't see him, but springs to her feet just as he's a lick away, drops a book on top and then nonchalantly steps on the book. There are also the usual mis-sightings: Jennings awakens in the middle of the night in a cold sweat, staring at the wall beyond the bed he shares with his wife, Molly (Harley Jane Kozak). There's a spot ... and ... it ... looks ... like ... A GIANT UGLY SPIDER. He eases from the bed to the wall, but even before his toe touches the floor, we know it's a coat hook, and the thrill that should come from his approach simply isn't there. But what ``Arachnophobia'' lacks in chills, it more than makes up for in humor, thanks especially to John Goodman as Delbert McClintock (Bugs Begone exterminating company), the Rambo of bug exterminators. Delbert reaches into his truck for his ``private stock'' bug killer, straps on the nozzles and outfits himself for bug war: ``Now let's rock 'n' roll.'' He makes our day. He also makes this movie because, by and large, ``Arachnobobia'' lacks bite. It doesn't have the mystical unknown of Alfred Hitchcock's ``The Birds,'' or the savage unknown of ``Jaws.'' All is just too predictable, too pat and too cute. Steven Kutcher's spider unit, the guys who handle the real live critters, does a good job of rounding up the arachnids. The well-trained little devils sure can make their marks. The specially created spider was designed by Chris Walas, and works with menace. Mikael Salomon's photography is lovely, especially the early vistas of Venezuela and the intricate lacework of the webbing in the barn. The movie is rated PG-13. The spider violence and deaths may be difficult for younger members of the audience or for the squeamish. _ By Dolores Barclay, AP Arts Editor.

``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane'' Joe Silver proves the ideal force to bring Andrew Dice Clay to the screen. The producer of the ``Die Hard,'' ``Lethal Weapon'' and ``Predator'' movies is, of course, the ``King of the Lowest Common Denominator.'' He has an absolute knack for spending megabucks on films that are full of flash, with no redeeming social values. ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane'' fits neatly into this Silver pattern. Expensive cars explode. A luxury beach house blown up. Point-blank killings. Fights atop a tall building. Heavy metal sound track. Language that would make a rap singer blush. All this plus the Diceman's brand of comedy. No, he doesn't parade his notorious gay and female putdowns. But the level of humor remains below the belt, with matching nomenclature. Lots of oral sex jokes, spoken and visual. Colorful asides to set the frat-house boys sniggering. There's a plot, sort of. Clay is Ford Fairlane, an L.A. private eye who specializes in rock music cases. A dull-witted Philip Marlowe, he bumbles his way through murders, drug deals and high-level deceptions (Is the music world really that venal?). Fairlane is assisted by his sleek secretary (Lauren Holly) and a ditzy groupie (Brandon Call) and beset by a host of opponents, including an oily executive (Wayne Newton), his slinky ex-wife (Priscilla Presley) and a cockney crazy (Robert Englund, a.k.a. Freddy Krueger of the ``Nightmare on Elm Street'' pictures). The taste of the film is sometimes astonishing. A college sorority is portrayed as some kind of sex academy. A long sequence takes place in a cemetery, where a limo and a hearse stage a murderous chase, scattering mourners and toppling gravestones. And what about Andrew Dice Clay in his starring debut (he has had smaller film roles)? He seems to have studied the Howard Cossell school of elocution, pausing ... between ... each ... word. His expressions range from distaste to smirk. There may be more Fords in his future, but his versatility remains unanswered. Finnish director Renny Harlin, who also directed ``Die Hard 2,'' knows how to maintain a frenzied pace. Daniel Waters, James Cappe and David Arnott labored on the mindless script, apparently working from the Joel Silver handbook. Steve Perry co-produced. ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane'' is a 20th Century Fox release rated R for all the above reasons and more. Running time: 96 minutes. _ By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer.

Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``All Dogs Go the Heaven'' (MGM-UA Home Video. Rated G)
Charlie, a hoodlum mutt, is in the slammer. But not for long. His faithful pal, Itchy, is about to liberate him. And where's the first place Charlie the escaped con-dog goes? Carface's honky-tonk. Carface, a cigar-chewing bulldog with a heart of nails, runs the type of gin joint where people, er, dogs drink cheap booze and fight at the drop of a bone. Carface is also the dog who framed Charlie. And Carface clearly does not want Charlie around anymore, so Carface kills him with his car, and Charlie is quickly dispatched to ... heaven. Years ago, this easily could have been the set-up and plot for a James Cagney or John Garfield gangster flick. But would you believe an animated feature for children? Don Bluth's ``All Dogs Go to Heaven'' is the second major animated feature to come out this fall, going up against Walt Disney's ``The Little Mermaid.'' But where Disney's has very little to frighten or rattle a 5-year-old except a mean sea witch, Bluth's effort dallies in the hereafter with haunting visions of hell and death. Charlie decides he really doesn't want to stay in heaven. It's soooooo boring! He turns back his ``life watch'' and returns to Earth, with a warning from the Whippet Angel that he can't come back. Once back to his old haunts, he discovers that Carface has a little girl named Anne-Marie who can talk to animals _ like race horses. With Anne-Marie as hostage, Carface never loses at the track! Charlie lures the little girl away with promises of helping her find a mommy and daddy. Anne-Marie is an orphan but we never know how or when her parents died or how she's managed to make it on her own. Charlie uses Anne-Marie, abusing her love and loyalty, but in the end, saves her life by giving up his own. His reward is heaven. Along the way, we meet a lady dog, Charlie's good friend, and her several puppies. There is a strong suggestion here that Charlie might be the dad. There's also the overblown and ferocious King Gator, who leads a pack of cannibalistic rats in an underground kingdom. King Gator is a questionable character, an almost racist concept. He has large lips and speaks in a distinctive black ghetto lingo (Ken Page does the voice). Though a hero of sorts in the story, he is nevertheless offensive and presents the kind of racial stereotype that should have been gone from movies _ especially children's movies _ by now. Bluth, who led a dozen young artists out of Disney in 1979 and set up his own company, is a talented animator but he misses with his backgrounds and scenery. There is no three-dimensional richness, just painted flats that look washed-out and ordinary. He's good with action, but often it is too busy. In a scene at Carface's club, there's so much going on and so many dogs romping about that much of the scene is missed. Burt Reynolds provides the voice for Charlie and Dom De Luise does Itchy. Other voices include Melba Moore, Whippet Angel; Charles Nelson Reilly, Killer; Judith Barsi, Anne-Marie; Loni Anderson, Flo; Candy Devine, Vera. Serviceable but unmemorable tunes are provided by Charles Strouse and T.J. Kuenster. Ralph Burns did the score. ``All Dogs Go to Heaven'' will never be an animated classic, such as ``Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' or ``Bambi,'' but it is enjoyable entertainment for the entire family. The United Artists release, in association with Goldcrest Films, is produced by Sullivan Bluth Studios Ireland Ltd. The rating is G, but small youngsters might be unnerved by some scenes and probably won't understand much of the plot.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove
DOC.TEXT:
Dmitri Hvorostovksy sings Tchaikovsky and Verdi Arias (Philips) _ The Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Valery Gergiev _ compact disc
A year ago, no one had heard of Dmitri Hvorostovsky. Now, on the strength of a few concerts, the name of the 28-year-old baritone from Siberia is in the air as the next sensation about to hit major opera houses around the world. Is it all hype or is the fuss justified? Based on his first recording, a collection of Tchaikovsky and Verdi arias, it's by no means hype. He possesses a baritone voice of unusual beauty. It's a good-size voice, too, one that should be capable of nicely filling even the biggest houses. He's got phenomenal breath control, spinning out the longest phrases with no apparent difficulty. And he's an artist, using his voice with considerable sensitivity and attention to the meaning of the words. If there's a ``But,'' it's some doubt about his upper register, which is impressive but doesn't have quite the same mellow sound as the rest of his voice. It may be that it will fill out in time _ or it may be a sign of vocal dangers ahead. Hvorostovsky, just 28, won the BBC's Cardiff Singer of the World Competition last summer in a nationally televised performance. He has since drawn ecstatic reviews for concerts at London's Wigmore Hall and at New York's Avery Fisher Hall and will soon be making opera debuts at Covent Garden, La Scala and San Francisco. His debut album is a collection of mostly familiar arias. The biggest rarities are from Tchaikovsky's ``Sorceress'' and ``Iolanthe.'' When it comes to the Verdi, Hvorostovsky makes even the warhorses sound fresh _ the elder Germont's ``Di Provenza il mar'' from ``La Traviata,'' for example. Great Verdi baritones have been in short supply since the days of the late Leonard Warren and Tito Gobbi. Robert Merrill and Cornell MacNeil were among the best of his successors, and now, at last, there may be another. _ By Mike Silverman, Associated Press Writer.

``A Round and a Bout'' (IRS) _ Squeeze
When Squeeze came onto the pop scene more than a decade ago, critics hailed songwriters Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrook as their generation's Lennon and McCartney. But record sales have failed to match Squeeze's lofty reputation, and promising young songwriting teams today are rarely referred to as the new Difford and Tilbrook. Blame the fickle music marketplace, because ``A Round and a Bout,'' a live album of main Squeeze favorites from as far back as 1978, shows that Difford and Tilbrook lived up to their early billing. These songs are terrific, and it's likely that if one of the older ones had broken into the Top 40, others would have followed. ``A Round and a Bout'' also shows that Squeeze remains a top-notch act. The band, recorded at two concerts in January, performs 15 songs with both respect for the original versions and a playfulness that puts a new twist on the arrangements. Given that Squeeze has played about 900 concerts since 1974 _ the date and site of each is listed in the liner notes _ it's no surprise that the band is terrific live. Helping to make it that way are the diverse piano stylings of Jools Holland (who has since left the band), and some remarkable vocal harmonies, particularly on ``Black Coffee in Bed'' and ``Hour Glass.'' Milli Vanilli this ain't. But the band's strength is the songs themselves. One bright, catchy melody gives way to another, while the themes vary from the sublime (``Up the Junction'') to the ridiculous (``She Doesn't Have to Shave''). A quibble: Because lead singers Difford and Tilbrook are difficult to understand, their clever couplets are easy to miss. The album should have included printed lyrics. Still, for the many millions who have yet to buy their first Squeeze record, ``A Round and a Bout'' is a good primer. _ By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer.

Boat Songs of 18th Century Venice (Tactus) _ Cristina Miatello, soprano; Carlo Gaifa, tenor; Enrico Gatti, baroque violin; Massimo Lonardi, lute and guitar; Ugo Nastrucci, theorbo and baroque guitar; Guido Morini, clavicembalo
This Italian compact disc is a complete delight. The songs and instrumental works expertly performed here presumably were played in gondolas floating down the canals of Venice, and with their light-hearted romance and easy charm that's not hard to imagine. The pieces fall somewhere between ``serious'' and popular music, with the song texts in Venetian dialect. The singers are excellent _ and native Venetians, to boot. _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.
