DOC.HEAD: Hair-Growing Company Doesn't Cut It
DOC.TEXT: An anti-baldness drug isn't the only way Upjohn Co. is promoting fuller scalps. The pharmaceutical giant is ending a four-decade tradition this year by eliminating staff barber shops. Giving a new meaning to corporate cost-clipping, Upjohn said the barber shops at its main manufacturing plant and Kalamazoo corporate headquarters will close by Dec. 31 as part of a company-wide effort to reduce expenses. Upjohn has offered employees subsidized haircuts since 1951. A basic cut costs $8. In recent years, the shops were providing about 14,000 haircuts annually to male and female employees and retirees, Upjohn spokesman Robert McDonough said. The two shops employ five hair stylists. Upjohn is the manufacturer of a hair-growing product known as Rogaine, sold by prescription for men in more than 60 countries including the United States. It has been shown to grow hair in about 39 percent of young men in the early stages of baldness.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Income Up 16.4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: W.R. Grace & Co. on Monday reported a 16.4 percent increase in its second quarter profit, boosted by 7.8 percent growth in revenue. The chemical and diversified industrial company said improved results at several of its divisions contributed to the good overall results and will strengthen the company's future financial performance. Grace earned $51.29 million, or 60 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30, up from $44.07 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $1.63 billion from $1.51 billion. For the first half of this year, Grace's earnings amounted to $83.90 million, or 98 cents a share, up 14.2 percent from $73.48 million, or 88 cents a share, in the first six months of 1989. Half-year revenue grew 7.8 percent to $3.14 billion from $2.91 billion in 1989. The largest operating unit of the company, Grace Specialty Chemicals Co., posted a 10 percent after-tax gain in operating income, helped by advances in its packaging operations business and higher sales of high-speed drying equipment used by the printing industry. But Grace's energy business had a sharp drop in its operating income due largely to the bankruptcy of a long-term customer of a coal company in which Grace has a 50 percent interest. Commenting on the quarterly results, Chairman and Chief Executive J. Peter Grace said: ``There were improvements in several sectors of our businesses that will help further strengthen our results in the future.'' Grace, based in New York, is a major international specialty chemicals company and also has interests in energy, health care, manufacturing and services.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Forecasts Pressure Corn, Bean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices fell in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after the National Weather Service forecast a continuation of ideal crop weather for the Midwest. Wheat futures were narrowly mixed in early trading. In a pair of forecasts issued late Friday, the weather service predicted normal to above-normal rainfall and temperatures for Midwestern growing regions this weekend and early next week, and normal conditions through mid-August. This afternoon's weekly Agriculture Department crop-progress report was expected to show corn pollination off to a good start. Martyn Foreman, a corn market analyst with AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill., said the critical pollination phase will last longer this year because heavy springtime rains delayed some corn planting. ``We probably will see some weather anxieties resurface,'' he said, ``but right now peope seem pretty confident about what we've gotten so far.'' In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.06{ a bushel; corn futures were 1} cents to 4} cents lower with July at $2.75{ a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2} cents lower with July at $1.23{ a bushel; soybeans were 6{ cents to 11 cents lower with July at $5.99} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .15 cent higher with August at 75.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .22 cent lower to .28 cent higher with August at 87.57 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent to 1.08 cents higher with July at 62.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .32 cent to 1.15 cents lower with July at 48.20 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: National Rig Count Declines for Third Week
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States decreased for the third consecutive week to total 1,001, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The count declined by 10 this week after drops of nine and one in the previous respective weeks. A year ago this week, the count was 820, Baker Hughes said. Baker Hughes' rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. The Houston-based oil toolmaker company has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Texas had the biggest decline with nine. California, Colorado and Kansas all reported a loss of five followed by Pennsylvania, three; and Michigan, New Mexico and Wyoming, one each. Oklahoma had the biggest gain with seven, followed by North Dakota, five; and Louisiana, one. Ohio remained unchanged from last week.

DOC.HEAD: Alcoa Earnings Down 43 Percent In Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Aluminum Company of America reported Monday that its second quarter profit plunged 43 percent due to decreased prices and reduced income from the company's Brazilian affiliate. The world's largest aluminum producer said it earned $161.9 million, or $1.86 a share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with $285.2 million, or $3.21 a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Sales fell to $2.69 billion from $2.76 billion. For the first half of 1990, Alcoa's earnings fell nearly 45 percent to $310.5 million, or $3.55 a share, from $561.2 million, or $6.33 a share. Half-year sales also fell, to $5.33 billion from $5.38 billion. Alcoa said the drop in earnings reflect a 24 percent drop in aluminum ingot prices and lower fabricated product sales. In addition, the company's Brazilian affiliate, Alcoa Aluminio, reported sharply lower earnings, $6 million in the first half, compared with $61 million in 1989. The decrease was attributed to government actions taken to improve that country's economy.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing prices. CORRECTS retail sales month to June in 4th graf, The government ...
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher Monday on London's Stock Exchange, as a drop in British retail sales figures led to optimism about chances for an interest rate cut. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 24.3 points, or 1 percent, to 2,406.5. Volume came to 346.9 million shares compared with 399.2 million shares Friday. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 20.8 points at 1,900.9 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 11.36 points to close at 1,295.58. The government said retail sales fell 2.8 percent in June, improving prospects for lower interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Bayer to Acquire Citric Acid Business
DOC.TEXT: Bayer USA Inc. said Monday its parent company has signed a contract to buy the citric acid business and assets of a plant in the United Kingdom for about $100 million. The agreement would give Bayer AG of West Germany the ability to make 23,000 tons of citric acid in Europe, increasing the company's worldwide capacity to 150,000 tons of the chemical per year, the company said. Bayer _ a diversified company which makes health-care, organic and industrial products _ said Rhone-Poulenc's Sturge plant in Shelby, Yorkshire, could be expanded to produce 36,000 tons of citric acid with ``relatively minor investment.'' The company said it would integrate the business into the Haarmann & Reimer Food Ingredients Division of Bayer UK Ltd. Citric acid is used in the food, beverage, pharmeceutical and detergent industries.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Reports Record Income
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. said Monday that record revenue and efforts to contain costs helped the cash register and computer company increase earnings by 5 percent to a record level in the second quarter. Earnings totaled $155 million, compared with $110 million for the same period last year. Earnings per share increased by 17 percent to $1.66, also a record, the company said, compared with $1.42 in 1989's second quarter. NCR's repurchase of 2.2 million shares during the second quarter helped per-share earnings but lessened the increase in net income. The company said second-quarter revenue increased 5 percent to $1.60 billion, compared with $1.53 billion for the year-earlier period. Charles E. Exley Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said the higher revenue as well as efforts to contain expenses contributed to the increased earnings. But he said they were partially offset by the share repurchase program and increased research and development spending. Earnings for the first six months totaled $167 million, down 2 percent from $171 million during the same period a year ago. Earnings per share were $2.38, down from $2.17. Revenue increased to a record $2.87 billion for the six months, up 3 percent from $2.78 billion a year ago. The company said the dollar value of its orders abroad set a second-quarter record, offsetting a decline in U.S. orders. NCR develops, makes, markets, installs and services business information processing systems worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Dates for the Dow Jones Industrial Average
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated if Dow average sets a new record.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of historic dates for the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks: 1896 _ First appears in the Wall Street Journal. Jan. 12, 1906 _ Closes above 100 for the first time, at 100.25. Sept. 3, 1929 _ Reaches its closing peak for the bull market of the 1920s, at 381.17, less than two months before the Great Crash. Oct. 28, 1929 _ Plummets 38.33 points, the worst drop on record until 1986, cutting nearly 13 percent of the average's value, closing at 260.64. July 8, 1932 _ Closes at its Depression low of 41.22, having fallen 89 percent in less than three years. March 12, 1956 _ Closes above 500 for the first time, at 500.24. Jan. 18, 1966 _ Reaches 1,000 for the first time in mid-session, but drops back to close at 994.20. Nov. 14, 1972 _ Closes above 1,000 for the first time, at 1,003.16. Jan. 11, 1973 _ Peaks at 1,051.70. Dec. 6, 1974 _ Closes at a 12-year low of 577.60, ending the worst bear market since the '30s. April 27, 1981 _ Closes at an eight-year high of 1,024.05. Aug. 12, 1982 _ Closes at a two-year low of 776.92, just prior to the start of a historic rally. Aug. 17, 1982 _ Rises 38.81 points, to 831.24, in its then-largest one-day gain as the long rally begins on Wall Street. Dec. 11, 1985 _ Increases 12.50 points to close at 1,511.70, its first finish above 1,500. Jan. 8, 1987 _ Breaks the 2,000 level for the first time, rising 8.30 to 2,002.25. Jan. 23, 1987 _ Plunges to end day down 44.15 points at 2,101.52, after being up 64 points at midafternoon; NYSE volume hits a record 302.39 million. July 17, 1987 _ Climbs 13.07 to 2,510.04, closing above 2,500 for the first time. Oct. 16, 1987 _ Plunges 108.36 points to 2,246.73, falling more than 100 points for the first time. Oct. 19, 1987 _ Dives a record 508.00 points to 1,738.74, a drop of 22.6 percent that dwarfs the drop on Oct. 28, 1929, in the market's Great Crash. Oct. 21, 1987 _ Soars a record 186.84 to 2,027.85, a climb of 10.1 percent in the second day of the rebound from the Oct. 19 collapse. The broader market also rebounds. Feb. 4, 1988 _ Falls 5.63 to 2,057.86, the same day New York Stock Exchange announces it will experiment with a 50-point ``collar'' on program trading. The exchange bars the use of its computers for index arbitrage on days the Dow rises or falls 50 points or more from its previous close. Feb. 8, 1988 _ Falls 14.76 to 1,895.72, its low for the year. March 25, 1988 _ Closes down 44.92 to 1,978.95; the 50-point ``collar'' is triggered on the down side for the first time during the session. April 6, 1988 _ Jumps 64.16 to 2,061.67, triggering the collar on the up side for the first time. Jan. 24, 1989 _ Gains 38.04 to 2,256.43, regaining its Oct. 16, 1987 level for the first time since the Black Monday crash on Oct. 19, 1987. Oct. 9, 1989 _ Gains 5.89 to 2,791.41, its high for the year. Oct. 13, 1989 _ Falls 190.58 to 2,569.26 on Friday the 13th selloff sparked by failure of UAL Corp. buyout group to get financing. Oct. 16, 1989 _ Gains 88.12 to 2,657.38 in rally led by Dow industrials. Jan. 2, 1990 _ Gains 56.95 to 2,810.15, reaching a record high for the first time since the Oct. 13 plunge. Jan. 12, 1990 _ Falls 71.46 to 2,689.21 on worries about higher inflation and earlier declines in the Tokyo and London stock markets. Jan. 22, 1990 _ Falls 77.45 to 2,600.45, putting the Dow industrials 7.47 percent below its record high of Jan. 2. May 11, 1990 _ Rises 63.07 to 2,801.58 in rally sparked by economic reports suggesting mild inflation. May 14, 1990 _ Gains 19.95 to 2,821.53, topping the Jan. 2 record close for the first time. May 29, 1990 _ Jumps 49.57 to record 2,870.49. June 1, 1990 _ Gains 24.31 to 2,900.97, first close above 2,900. July 13, 1990 _ Crosses 3,000-point level during the session for the first time before slipping back in later trading. Finishes at 2,980.20, a new record high.

DOC.HEAD: Vegas To Los Angeles Train Project Passes One Hurdle, Faces Many Others
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with bid presented. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Koenig said... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A decade after a high-speed train linking this gaming community and Southern California was first proposed, a partnership today plunked down $500,000 along with the first formal bid on the $5 billion project. Bechtel International Inc. of San Francisco and Transrapid of West Germany are expected to be the only bidders for the right to build a train that would cruise up to 300 mph on elevated track running alongside interstate highways between Las Vegas and Anaheim, Calif. The bidding deadline is later today. Company officials presented the California-Nevada Super Speed Train Commission with a 3-inc-thick proposal detailing the 272-mile route. ``We feel we are about to revolutionize ground transportation in the United States,'' said Arnie Adamsen, a Las Vegas city councilman and chairman of the commission. Bechtel Vice President Erv Koenig told the group that the proposed high-tech train, using magnetic force to propel the trains, will be ``a pilot system that will be the first part of a network that will eventually encompass the southwest and the nation.'' Once opposed by many alifornia officials as a ``gambler's special'' of little benefit to the Los Angeles area, the train is seen now by some as the possible beginning of a mass transit system that could link large portions of Southern California. But even its strongest backers are not buying tickets quite yet. The proposed train faces enormous hurdles, not the least of which is its massive price tag and the uncertainty it would attract enough riders to be profitable. The earliest it could be in operation is the late 1990s. Bechtel officials themselves say they will need to study the project at least another 16 months before deciding whether to proceed. ``A lot depends on what we find in our own feasibility study,'' Koenig said last week. ``All we're working on now is the existing data, and we have to go out and confirm or deny that data.'' The proposed service would whisk passengers between the two cities in little more than an hour. It now takes five hours by car. ``I think it has a three-out-of-four chance of succeeding,'' said Paul Taylor, executive director of the train commission. ``But anything like this has potential for environmental delay which could foul up the financing.'' Koenig said Bechtel is taking a cautious approach to the project by applying for the franchise so it can do its own ridership surveys and other studies before deciding whether to go futher. ``We're famous for doing large projects,'' said Koenig, citing the BART mass transit system in San Francico. ``But a project of this magnitude, you have to take one step at a time.'' A ridership survey done earlier by a consulting firm for the commission suggested that an Anaheim to Las Vegas run would get 6.5 million round trip passengers a year at a cost of about $110. As projected by Bechtel, the train would also provide several Southern California stops for commuters, and could later be expanded to link other California communities. Aside from financing, Bechtel also faces major obstacles in its plan to use trains powered by magnetic levitation. Maglev trains float one to four inches above a single guideway, lifted and propelled along by a wave of magnetic energy. The only maglev train in existence is in Emsland, West Germany, where Transrapid's prototype glides along a 20-mile test track at speeds of about 250 mph. Members of the bistate rail commission were impressed by the train during a visit to Germany in March, but questioned whether the technology was in place to build such an ambitious project. ``I've tried to ride the maglev three times now and I've never been on the entire track because it wasn't certified for operation,'' said California state Sen. Bill Leonard. ``I need a better level of confidence that it can be done.'' The idea of a speedy train linking Las Vegas with the lucrative Southern California market that provides the bulk of the 18 million tourists who visit each year was first raised in 1979 by then-Mayor Bill Briare. It wasn't until 1988, however, after a federally funded study showed the project was feasible, that the bistate train commission was established. Since the train project received its first serious studies in the mid-1980s, the projected price tag has doubled from an estimated $2.5 billion to Bechtel's current estimate of $5.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Earnings Rise for 2nd-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: The BFGoodrich Co. said Monday its second-quarter earnings rose 5.9 percent from the same period last year, largely due to a gain on the sale of its rights in a tire venture. The company reported net income of $55.4 million, or $2.10 per share, for the three months ended June 30, compared with $52.3 million, or $1.98 per share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter edged up to $632.5 million from $628.8 million a year earlier. A key factor in the earnings rise was a $20.5 million after-tax gain resulting from the sale of The Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co. to Michelin, the company said. Uniroyal Goodrich Tire was formed as a joint venture in 1986 when BF Goodrich and Uniroyal Holdings combined their tire operations. Goodrich sold its 50 percent stake in the venture in June 1988, and received cash plus a warrant to buy equity in the company. But when Michelin bought Uniroyal Goodrich Tire in May, Goodrich surrendered its warrant to buy equity in Uniroyal Goodrich and the after-tax gain for the second quarter reflected what it was paid. Second-quarter income from continuing operations at BFGoodrich was $34.9 million, or $1.29 per share, down 34 percent from the same quarter of 1989. ``Our second-quarter results were in line with our expectations,'' said John D. Ong, BFGoodrich chairman and chief executive officer. ``While prices for vinyl products remained below last year's peak, we benefited significantly from the increased contribution from our specialty chemicals and aerospace businesses, which now account for half of the company's sales,'' he said. BFGoodrich said its geon vinyl products segment reported operating income of $24.7 million for the second period, compared with $57.3 million last year. Its specialty chemicals division had operating income of $27.3 million, up 13 percent from the second quarter of 1989. Its aerospace business reported $19.1 million in operating income, a 43 percent increase over the $13.4 million in last year's first quarter. For the first half of the year, Goodrich said it earned $71.6 million, or $2.66 per share, down 32 percent from $105.3 milliopn, or $4 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the half from continuing operations slipped to $1.22 billion from $1.24 billion a year earlier.

The stock market advanced to another record level today and pushed the Dow Jones industrial average within a hair of breaking the 3,000-point barrier, but sellers kept that psychological hurdle beyond reach. The best-known barometer of the stock market remained well above 3,000 for much of the session, buoyed partly by a better-than-expected midyear earnings report from International Business Machines Corp., an important component of the 30 big-name stocks that comprise the Dow average. But late-afternoon selling pushed prices off their highest levels of the day, in indication to many professional strategists that a good deal of pessimism persists about the vitality and duration of the market's recent strength. The volume and breadth of trading remained relatively light. ``I don't see across the board participation. I see participation in stocks that are in the big indices,'' said John Eberley, equity trader at the Chicago Corp. investment firm, ``Somebody's going to catch up or somebody's going to come down, one of the two.'' DOC.HEAD: Lower Prices, Other Problems Send Second Quarter Profits Plunging
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, ``Prospects for ... to restore dropped words `capital-related.'
DOC.TEXT: Boise Cascade Corp. said Monday it second-quarter profit tumbled 69.5 percent, mainly due to falling prices. The wood product manufacturer reported Monday that earnings in the April-June period totaled $23 million, or 52 cents a share, down from $75.3 million, or $1.68 a share, for the same quarter a year ago. Sales slipped to $1.06 billion from $1.10 billion a year earlier. That left profits for the first half of 1990 at $56.6 million, or $1.31 a share, down from $153.5 million, or $3.42 a share, a year earlier. First-half sales slipped to $2.13 billion from $2.20 billion a year earlier. Chairman John Fery said lower prices for products in the company's paper, office and building segments were largely responsible for the earnings decline. Boise Cascade posted a gain from completing the sale of its Speciality Paperboard Division during the quarter, but it was largely offset by the cost of signing bonuses in connection with labor settlements at paper mills in Minnesota and Alabama. Fery also said the 59 percent drop in operating income from the paper segment, which accounts for over half of Boise Cascade's sales, was caused by operating problems at pulp and paper mills in Maine, Washington, Alabama and Louisiana that occurred during routine maintenance or capital improvements. Higher delivered log costs coupled with weaker prices for ponderosa pine, which accounts for over half the company's lumber production, contributed to the 43 percent decline in operating income from the building products segment, Fery said. And slowing sales growth in the office products area along with lower-than-anticipated margins forced operating income from that segment to retreat slightly from last year's record level, he said. ``Prospects for our building products business are uncertain as a result of weaker housing starts and high Northwest wood costs,'' Fery said. ``And we have planned major capital-related downtime at our paper mills in International Falls, Minn., and Rumford, Maine. However, we believe we are at or near the cyclical trough for newsprint and uncoated papers.''

DOC.HEAD: Chase, First Chicago Profit Down; Morgan Flat, Security Pacific, NCNB Higher
DOC.TEXT: Chase Manhattan Corp. said Monday its second quarter profit plunged 62 percent from a year earlier, partly because it raised its loan-loss provision to cover problem commercial real estate loans. First Chicago Corp. also posted lower results, with its second quarter net income dropping by 35 percent due to higher expenses and a big addition to its loan loss reserve. J.P. Morgan & Co. Inc. posted flat earnings, while two other major banking companies, Security Pacific Corp. and NCNB Corp., reported higher income. Chase, based in New York, said its quarterly income fell to $52 million, or 24 cents per share, from $137 million, or $1.31 a share, in 1989. For the first half of 1990, Chase netted $96 million, or 44 cents a share, down 64 percent from $269 million, or $2.59 per share, last year. First Chicago said its profit fell to $87.4 million, or $1.22 per share, in the three months ended June 30, from $134.4 million, or $1.98 per share, for the same period a year ago. Six month profit fell 39.8 percent to $156 million, or $2.15 per share, from $259.1 million, or $3.83 per share, a year earlier. New York-based Morgan earned $207 million, or $1.06 per share, in the quarter, compared with earnings of $206 million, or $1.09 a share. Half-year income totaled $606 million, or $3.16 per share, up 57 percent from earnings of $386 million, or $2.05. Los Angeles-based Security Pacific reported a 6 percent rise in its quarterly profit to $195.2 million, or $1.59 per share, from $184.5 million, or $1.58 per share. For the half year, it earned $386.6 million, or $3.13 per share, up 5 percent from $363.88 million, or $3.12 per share. NCNB's net income totaled $137.4 million, or $1.30 per share, a 50 percent increase over earnings of $91.5 million, or $1 a share, in 1989. In the first half, the Charlotte, N.C.-based company earned $277.48 million, or $2.64 per share, up 66 percent from $167.32 million, or $1.82. Chase, one of the nation's largest commercial construction lenders, said its quarterly income was hurt by its decision to raise its credit-loss provision by $75 million to $225 million. All of the increase was to protect itself from declining real estate values in commercial markets. The company said declines in foreign exchange trading revenue and higher operating costs also offset gains in net interest revenue and in fees and commissions. First Chicago increased its second-quarter provision against credit losses to $85 million from $60 million. Of the total, $32 million was allocated for commercial loan exposure and $53 million for consumer exposure. Net interest income slipped slightly during the quarter to $332.6 million from $333.6 million while noninterest income rose 3 percent to $282 million from $272.5 million, the Chicago-based bank holding company said in a statement. First Chicago said it reduced its exposure to troubled Third World loans to $465 million on June 30 compared with $693 million on March 31 through a combination of charge-offs and loan sales. Morgan said its revenue rose from various trading activities, such as dealings in foreign exchange, precious metals and U.S. and foreign debt securities. However, that was offset by lower corporate finance fees and net interest income and a 10 percent jump in operating expenses, it said. Security Pacific attributed its higher quarterly profit to strength in its primary markets, California and Washington state. Those areas have outpaced other parts of the country in economic growth, particularly the Northeast, which is served by banks like Chase. The company said non-interest income grew by 12 percent while non-interest expenses were up only 2 percent. NCNB also said it was affected by weakness in certain real estate markets. But while there was an increase in reported nonperforming loans, it said, net interest income and non-interest income rose significantly.
