DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Higher; Wholesale Gasoline Surges
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures finished sharply higher in heavy trading Monday led by a surge in wholesale gasoline prices. Reports of a weekend pipeline accident in the Soviet Union buoyed prices in London and the buying enthusiasm spilled over into the oil futures pits on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil prices also got a boost from continuing speculation about output reductions planned by OPEC members. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, jumped 31 cents to $18.67 a 42-gallon barrel, more than making up for Friday's 10-cent loss. Later crude contracts posted even stronger gains, with the September contract up 50 cents, to $19.85. Gasoline prices shot up. The August contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline soared 2.49 cents to 64.44 cents a gallon, which expanded on Friday's gain of 1.38 cents. The contracts for delivery during September through November also climbed higher. Home heating oil for August delivery gained 2.03 cents to 56.24 cents a gallon after adding 1.17 cents on Friday. Subsequent contracts posted similarly sized increases. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.495 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.500 Friday. Mary Haskins, an energy trader at PaineWebber Inc., said sketchy news accounts of incidents in the Soviet Union that disrupted production of natural gas touched off a rally in London, which spread to New York. She cited two reports: one of a natural gas pipeline accident and another of an explosion causing an oil field fire. Details were unavailable but the disruptions in Soviet output were expected to be temporary, she said. Meanwhile, the possibility that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries soon might undertake some effective steps to prop up world oil prices continued to encourage buying, she said. Oil traders are paying close attention to the oil cartel as it prepares for a meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, on July 25. The cartel's inability to rein in its members' oil output has weighed down prices for months.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor Cutting 11 Percent Of Its Jobs
LaserPhotos STS2, NY20
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. announced plans Monday to reduce its workforce by up to 11 percent, about 17,000 jobs, and cut other costs in an effort to shore up the aerospace giant's sagging bottom line. John F. McDonnell, chairman and chief executive officer, said the measures should save the company more than $700 million this year, or about 5 percent of annual expenses, and put the nation's largest defense contractor on ``very solid footing.'' He said the company has to become more efficient and profitable in order to ensure that its record backlog of commercial jet orders and other business opportunities were part of a bright future, not a nagging nightmare. ``We tried to work it without having significant job reductions, but in the final analysis we had to come to this,'' McDonnell told a news conference. McDonnell Douglas stock fell $2.50 to $42.37{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Company officials had said in June that they planned substantial layoffs, although some securities analysts and union officials said the cuts were a little deeper than they expected. ``We've seen a lot of changes at McDonnell Douglas and most of them have been rather ineffectual. But positive effects from this plan should start showing up right away and that's when we'll become believers,'' said Paul Nisbet, a stock analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Nisbet said he would have liked to see McDonnell Douglas embark on a long-term cost-cutting program, as competitor Boeing Co. did several years ago with a five-year, 25 percent cost-reduction plan. ``That's why Boeing's making a lot of money and McDonnell Douglas isn't,'' Nisbet said. McDonnell Douglas reported a $2 million profit for the first quarter of the year, down 98 percent from the same period a year earlier. For 1989, profit fell 37 percent to $219 million and would have been much lower if not for a one-time $178 million gain from an accounting change. Much of the financial weakness stems from losses at Douglas Aircraft Co., the company's Long Beach, Calif. subsidiary, which has been struggling with an overwhelming commercial jet order backlog, cost overruns and a major overhaul in corporate work rules. The company faces large investment costs in its not-yet-certified MD-11 commercial jumbo jet and has experienced production problems with its MD-80 commercial airliners. McDonnell Douglas also has had problems with defense aircraft and faces the prospect of major cuts in defense spending. The Senate Armed Service Committee on Friday approved a $289 billion defense authorization bill that would slash the Pentagon's proposed budget and cloud the future of several major aircraft programs. The company faces serious cost problems on three military programs, the C-17 cargo plane, the A-12 advanced tactical aircraft and the T-45 Goshawk trainer. Lawrence Harris, an analyst with Bateman, Eichler, Hill, Richards in Los Angeles, said he was taking a cautious view of the cost-cutting plan's chances of success. ``To be sure, McDonnell Douglas faces a number of challenges. Several of their mature defense programs could be coming to an end and, at the same time, newer programs are incurring cost growth. Also, the effort to turn around Douglas Aircraft is unfinished,'' Harris said. The company expects to eliminate between 14,000 and 17,000 jobs through layoffs and attrition, McDonnell said. The bulk of the cuts will be made in St. Louis and Long Beach, Calif. About 4,500 jobs will be cut in the St. Louis area, where McDonnell employs about 40,500 workers and does much of its defense work. About 8,000 jobs will be cut in Long Beach, where the company employs 47,000 and makes commercial aircraft and does some defense work. Another 800 jobs will be trimmed at a helicopter operation in Mesa, Ariz., and another 1,000 jobs will be eliminated elsewhere in the country, the company said. When attrition and job elimination are included, the company said, up to 17,000 positions could be trimmed under the plan. The cost-cutting plan also includes reduced capital budgets, significant cuts in budgets for travel, consultants, advertising and other support activities, restrictions on overtime and a 50 percent reduction in company contributions to the salaried savings plans. McDonnell said job fairs, resume services and counseling would be offered to help laid off workers find new jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Health Care Benefits Will Take Plenty of Time at Bargaining Table
DOC.TEXT: Health care cost issues will take up a lot of time in this summer's auto industry labor negotiations, a Ford Motor Co. executive said Monday. ``Health care is just a mega-issue,'' said the executive, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Ford has three bargaining priorities during talks with the United Auto Workers union: improving vehicle quality, holding down costs and getting the union to agree to flexibility in how cars are made. The union has said protecting current jobs for its members is the top bargaining priority for each of the automakers. Improvements in pensions, wages and health care benefits follow. Negotiations between the UAW and Ford open Thursday. Talks between the union and General Motors Corp. open Wednesday. Chrysler Corp. and the UAW open talks Friday. UAW contracts with each of the Big Three expire Sept. 14. The Ford executive estimated his company pays about $4,200 annually in health care for each of its 175,000 active and retired employees. That's less than Chrysler's $4,600 for its approximately 60,000 workers and slightly more than the $3,800 a year that GM pays for each of its 400,000 unionized workers. Automakers long have complained their health care costs put them in a hole compared with Japanese companies making cars and trucks in the United States. The average age of UAW workers at the Big Three is about 42 years. The estimated average age of a worker in the so called transplant companies is in the mid- to upper-20s. Chrysler chief negotiator Anthony St. John has said simply continuing the current level of company-paid health benefits for its workers would add 16 percent to Chrysler's labor costs. Automakers and the union have been looking for ways to cut health-care costs while maintaining benefits. One is for employees to switch from traditional health-care coverage, such as Blue Cross and Blue Shield, to health maintenance organizations or preferred provider organizations. ``There is no doubt that the HMOs are a cost savings,'' the Ford executive said. Thirty percent to 40 percent of UAW-covered employees at the Big Three are members of HMOs or PPOs. Another expensive issue will be how to get cost of living protection for UAW retirees, whose numbers nearly equal the union's active Big Three membership of about 500,000. Union leaders are being pressured by the retirees to push for cost-of-living protection keyed to the inflation rate. Both sides say that could cost billions of dollars. ``Maybe the clue to pensions is what has been done in the last couple of agreements,'' the Ford executive said. Lump-sum payments have been used in the past to offset inflation-spurred erosion of retirement benefits. Ford also wants more flexibility in its manufacturing plants and how they are supplied. The executive said quality, cost and delivery speed determine whether a part or component will be made at a Ford plant. The union wants that work done at plants rather than having the work sent to a company where labor is cheaper. If negotiations proceed as they have in the past, the union will bargain with each of the Big Three through July and August. Sometime around Labor Day, the UAW will pick a ``target'' company. Talks will be suspended at the other two and focused at the target. An agreement at that company then will be taken to the others resulting in similar contracts at each of the Big Three. The Ford executive said would like to see Ford picked as the target because the No. 2 automaker would be able to tailor the contract to its needs. But he thinks the union will pick GM.

DOC.HEAD: RJR Nabisco Announces Recapitalization Details
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of von der Heyden in grafs 6, 7, 8, 14 and 15.
DOC.TEXT: RJR Nabisco Inc. announced Monday the details of a $6.9 billion recapitalization plan the company says will include the retirement of more than $3 billion in junk bonds and a $1.15 billion bridge loan. The recapitalization is aimed at reducing RJR Nabisco's most expensive debt, leaving the firm less vulnerable to the problems that have undermined other debt-burdened companies over the past year. Under the plan, RJR Nabisco's debt will be reduced to less than $20 billion from the current level of approximately $23 million, said Karl von der Heyden, the company's executive vice president and chief financial officer. The recapitalization includes a previously announced $1.7 billion cash infusion by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., the investment firm that engineered the record $24.53 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco last year. Kohlberg Kravis said last month it planned to recapitalize the food and tobacco company, but released few details of the plan. The plan will be financed with the $1.7 billion from Kohlberg Kravis plus $2.25 billion in new bank loans. The loans are expected to carry interest rates of 12 percent to 13 percent, compared with the 16 percent to 17 percent rates that RJR Nabisco junk bonds will carry. RJR Nabisco plans to repurchase at least 51 percent of its junk bonds known as subordinated exchange debentures with a maturity date of 2007, von der Heyden said in a telephone interview. The company also expected to retire at least 85 percent of junk bonds called senior converting debentures that are due in 2009. Up to 85 percent of these securities will be exchanged for cash and a new issue of preferred stock in RJR Nabisco, with additional bonds possibly being acquired for cash, von der Heyden said. After the recapitalization, ``we will probably have something in excess of $3 billion of those two issues'' out of the $7 billion currently outstanding, von der Heyden said. RJR Nabisco said it hoped to complete the recapitalization by next April. The company also announced it was resetting the interest rates on the junk bonds from the current 14.07 percent to 17 percent for the subordinated exchange debentures and 17.375 percent for the senior converting debentures. By the terms under which the bonds were issued, RJR Nabisco had to reset the interest rate to make up for any price declines in the bonds. Because bond prices and interest rates move inversely, and the market price for the securities has declined since their issue, the company had to offer a higher rate at the reset. The recapitalization also will allow RJR Nabisco to repay the $1.15 billion bridge loan used to complete the leveraged buyout. In return for its $1.7 billion cash infusion, Kohlberg Kravis will receive a new issue of common stock in RJR Nabisco valued at $6.25 a share, RJR Nabisco said. Kohlberg Kravis also was exchanging $200 million of its own bridge loan to RJR Nabisco for $200 million in preferred stock. Von der Heyden said RJR Nabisco planned to reduce its debt load steadily during the next few years. ``One of the things that will help us is we're retiring a lot of junk debt,'' he said. After this recapitalization is completed the company will consider further debt retirement, but ``this will not come up for quite a while,'' von der Heyden said. ``We will always look at ways to bring down our effective interest rates and try to tackle the most expensive debt first,'' he said, referring to the remaining junk bonds. He noted that junk bond debt cannot be retired without the agreement of RJR Nabisco's bankers. The company's bank loans have a higher repayment priority than do junk bondholders.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher While Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved higher against most major foreign currencies Monday although traders continued to worry about the direction of U.S. interest rates. Gold prices fell. Analysts said the dollar continued to recover from a midday decline on Friday, when the Federal Reserve added funds to the banking system and financial markets interpreted the move as a relaxation of the Fed's credit policy. When the Fed relaxes credit and allows interest rates to fall, the dollar tends to decline because it is supported by higher U.S. rates. Trading was light. James T. McGroarty, senior vice president with Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Connecticut, said the market was uncertain about what Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan might say Wednesday about the central bank's policy when he testifies before the Senate Banking Committee. ``I think the market's a little fearful of getting too far ahead of itself until they can understand why he's done what he's done and and how far he's going to go,'' McGroarty said. Overseas dealers reported continuing speculation that U.S. interest rates might be lowered after the May trade deficit figures are released Wednesday. Some growth in the trade deficit is expected from the previously reported $6.94 billion in April. The dollar put in a mixed performance against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8033 from late Friday's $1.8005, but in earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.8040 from $1.8055 late Friday. The dollar was unchanged against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 148.15 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 148.43 yen from 147.42 yen at Friday's close, and it was quoted in London at 148.05 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6545 West German marks, up from 1.6510; 1.4180 Swiss francs, up from 1.4025; 5.5500 French francs, up from 5.5390; 1,211.00 Italian lire, up from 1,208.75; and 1.15865 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15785. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday's late rates, included: 1.6535 West German marks, up from 1.6430; 1.4165 Swiss francs, up from 1.3925; 5.5460 French francs, up from 5.5115; 1.8640 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8520; 1,210.75 Italian lire, up from 1,203.25, and 1.1587 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1576. Gold prices slipped lower in New York, closing at $363.30 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, down $1.10 from late Friday. Republic National Bank recorded a late bid of $362.50, down $1.50. Gold traded in London late Monday at $362.75 a troy ounce, down from $364.55 late Friday. The late price in Zurich was $362.70, down from $364.20. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $363.11 an ounce, down from Saturday's $363.59. Silver prices also declined. In New York, a troy ounce of silver fell 6.1 cents to $4.847 a troy ounce. Earlier in London, silver was bid at a late price of $4.89, down from $4.93 late Friday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stocks hit record levels again Monday and the Dow Jones industrial average reached its third straight all-time high, tantalizing Wall Streeters by closing within a hair of 3,000 for the first time. But trading was light in what some strategists regarded as an uncertain market. Many investors didn't participate and some expressed cynicism about an obsession with the behavior of the Dow index, which can move sharply if any one of its 30 big-name components rises or falls in one large trade. The best-known stock barometer, which has risen nearly 100 points this month and briefly forayed aboved 3,000 for the first time Friday, remained in that territory for much of the session Monday. But it weakened in a bout of selling in the late afternoon and finished at 2,999.75, up 19.55. ``It's just another number, another barrier,'' said Peter J. DaPuzzo, head of world equities for Lehman Brothers in New York. Philip Rettew, a vice president at Merrill Lynch & Co., called the Dow-3,000 barrier ``about as important as your 50th birthday.'' Strategists said buying was largely motivated by the influences that drove the market last week and pushed the Dow index to record closes Thursday and Friday: indications that the Federal Reseve was easing interest rates to forestall a recession, and an improved outlook for corporate earnings. International Business Machines's announcement of higher-than-expected second-quarter earnings Monday bolstered the optimism and set the tone for much of the day. Some other leading companies also reported strong earnings results. ``The market's come a long way. It barreled ahead, got tired and backed away,'' said Lawrence Wachtel, a senior strategist for Prudential Bache Securities Inc. ``And then there's the Dow 3,000, oh boy,'' he said. ``Some people feel 2,999.75 is the pits, but 3,000.15 would be salvation. There's too much hype about it.'' Some brokers said events that could have hurt the market, like a weakening dollar and word of a drastically higher federal budget deficit, had little or no influence on stock prices, an indication of market strength. But others said the market's indecisive move higher, as reflected in the Dow average's inability to close above 3,000, showed that many investors are nervous and unwilling to commit money to stocks. ``The only thing that worries me is the lack of volume,'' said Blake Stephens, vice president of over-the-counter trading at Interstate Johnson Lane Securities in Charlotte, N.C. ``If it closes above 3,000 with good volume, you'll see come money come out of the woodwork.'' Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 868 up, 678 down and 495 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 149.43 million shares, down substantially from the 215.60 million traded the previous session. Among the most prominent issues was IBM, which announced before the market opened that second-quarter earnings rose 5.2 percent from a year earlier, better than many had expected. IBM finished at 122], up 1]. Other technology stocks also did well on strong second-quarter earnings results. NCR, which said earnings advanced 5 percent to a record, jumped 3~ to 68. Banking stocks, considered vulnerable because of the weak real estate market in much of the country, also did surprisingly well on better-than expected earnings results. J.P. Morgan rose 2[ to 37~, and NCNB rose 1} to 36{. But Chase Manhattan, one of the biggest banking companies, fell { to 20} in heavy trading after reporting a 62 percent drop in second-quarter results. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 183.86 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $12.67 billion, or 0.36 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.80 to 201.13. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.99 to 437.37, and S&P's 500-stock composite index hit a record 368.95, up 1.64, eclipsing the 367.40 record set June 4. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.16 to 469.60. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.59 to 365.58.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Futures Hit 3-Month Low On Fine Weather, Slack Demand
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices sank Monday to their lowest levels in three months on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting forecasts for more good growing weather and a lack of strong export demand. Other grain and soybean futures also ended lower. On other commodity markets, energy futures rose sharply; hog futures soared; cattle futures were mixed; and precious metals retreated. Corn futures settled 6\ cents lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in July down 5{ cents at $2.73{ a bushel, the lowest closing price for a near-month corn contract since April 16. Wheat futures finished 4 cents to 5} cents lower with July at $3.02{ a bushel; oats were 4 cents to 5{ cents lower with July at at $1.21{ a bushel; soybeans were 8{ cents to 15 cents lower with July at $5.97\ a bushel. The steep losses in the corn and soybean markets reflected Friday's National Weather Service forecast for normal temperatures and rainfall in the Midwest through mid-August. After Monday's close, the weather service issued a six-to-10-day forecast predicting more good crop weather in the Midwest: above-normal rainfall and normal to below-normal temperatures July 22-26. That kind of weather would help the corn crop through its critical pollination phase, which was under way in about 12 percent of the crop as of Sunday, according to a weekly Agriculture Department report issued after the close. Pollination is lagging behind the normal pace of 38 percent, though, and is likely to go on for an unusually long period this year because heavy spring rains delayed some corn planting, said Marty Foreman, a corn market analyst with AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill. ``We probably will see some weather anxieties resurface,'' he said, ``but right now people seem pretty confident about what we've gotten so far.'' The crop-progress report also showed 19 percent of soybeans blooming compared with a 40 percent average. The USDA rated 75 percent of the corn crop good to excellent compared with 68 percent a week ago. The portion of the soybean crop rated good to excellent was 58 percent compared with 54 percent a week ago. Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the Board of Trade, said slack export demand for U.S. grain also contributed to Monday's price drop. He said the absence of China and the Soviet Union from the market was especially apparent. ``Typically, they're in here buying corn and wheat at this time of year and they have not shown up,'' he said. Petroleum futures rose strongly on the New York Mercantile Exchange, paced by strong gains in the refined products amid more bullish news from OPEC. Oil-producing countries Abu Dhabi and Saudi Ababia announced cutbacks in allocations to customers, and Iranian oil minister Aghazadeh continued to express confidence in the cartel's ability to reach a price-support agreement at their mid-year conference, beginning July 26. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 23 cents to 50 cents higher with the contract for delivery in August at $18.67 a barrel; heating oil surged 1.07 cents to 2.03 cents with August at 56.24 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.8 cents to 2.49 cents higher with August at 64.44 cents a gallon. Near-term hog futures soared the 2-cents-a-pound permitted daily limit on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with gains in the cash market prompted by relatively tight supplies of market-ready hogs. Livestock and meat futures also were supported by expectations that two USDA reports due out Friday will show a continued decline in frozen pork belly stocks and a slowdown in placements of cattle onto feedlots, said Charles K. Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .22 cent lower with August at 75.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 87.37 cents a pound; live hogs were .85 cent to 1.5 cents higher with July at 62.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent to .90 cent higher with July at 49.50 cents a pound. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $1.10 to $1.30 lower with August at $364.50 a troy ounce; silver futures were 6.1 cents to 6.3 cents lower with July at $4.847 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Deficit Estimate Soars; Warnings of Huge Program Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with congressional comment, subbing 2 grafs for 9th graf pvs, In fact ...; SUBS grafs 15-18 pvs, Monday's estimates ... with i graf to tighten. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The White House hiked its forecast of next year's budget deficit to $168.8 billion on Monday _ $231.4 billion if savings and loan costs are counted _ and warned of devastating cuts in programs without a quick budget compromise with Congress. The new estimate was more than two-thirds higher than the administration's projection just six months ago. Airport control towers could be closed, student loans canceled, food inspections interrupted and military forces halved by cutting perhaps one million people as the government buckled under what could be over $100 billion in automatic cuts this October, said Budget Director Richard Darman. It seemed unlikely that Congress would permit cuts on such a huge scale. And White House officials conceded that easing was needed in the nation's deficit-reduction law, which mandates spending cuts across a broad range of programs if targets for reducing federal red ink are not met. But administration officials insisted they would support a watering down of the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law only if coupled with a $50 billion package of spending cuts and new taxes. Two-month-old ``budget summit'' talks between the administration and congressional leaders on a deficit-reduction package have seemed bogged down despite President Bush's reversal of his ``no new taxes'' pledge three weeks ago. House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said the consequences of a $100 billion Gramm-Rudman cut would be so severe that the budget negotiators must somehow work out a deal. ``The crisis is real,'' Panetta told reporters. ``These numbers should hit the White House, Congress and the summit like a fire alarm in the middle of the night.'' However, Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said the numbers were nothing new, and he contended the talks were stalled because of a lack of leadership from Bush. He called on the president to address the nation, explaining the extent of the budget problem, laying out his solution and explaining the consequences of failure. The ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, Pete Domenici, R-N.M., said the new deficit figures would serve as a warning to any lawmakers who want the budget talks to fail and to those he said are making ``ultimatums.'' Monday's revised deficit projection was up $10 billion from the administration's informal estimate just a month ago and up sharply from January's $100.5 billion estimate. The new figures, contained in the administration's annual midyear economic review, are based on the economic data that show slower economic growth than the administration expected. The White House now projects that the economy will grow by only 2.2 percent this year _ down from the 2.6 percent it predicted in January. In gloomy remarks that appeared directed partly at congressional budget negotiators, Darman spoke of ``across-the-board spending reductions of a totally unprecedented size'' if the $100 billion gap can't be bridged by a budget compromise. Added Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady: ``This problem is serious. The law is the law. And we're going to obey it. ... This is not a political wrestling match.'' President Bush issued a written statement saying that in light of the revised deficit estimate, ``it is, therefore, all the more important that the budget summit reach agreement promptly and Congress act responsibly to bring the deficit down.'' Any cuts under the Gramm-Rudman law would be split 50-50 between domestic and military spending. If Bush decides to include military personnel in the defense cuts, one million men and women could be removed from government payrolls, about half the force, Darman said. He gave these other examples of prospective cuts: _ Massive layoffs of air traffic controllers and the closing of 100 airport control towers, forcing sharp reductions in commercial flights and ``an increase in traveler delays of 400 to 600 percent.'' _ A halt to all new cleanups of toxic waste sites. _ Elimination of Pell grants to 1.2 million college students. _ A 40 percent reduction in Head Start enrollment for pre-schoolers from poor families. _ A 140-day curtailment of meat and poultry inspections, sharply reducing the supply of these products in supermarkets and driving up prices. _ Sharp cuts in programs involving children's vaccinations, the elderly, the war on drugs, and prisons. Despite Darman's warnings, few in the administration appeared to believe that cuts of the scope of $100 billion would actually be seen. Michael Boskin, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, told reporters that cuts in excess of $50 billion in one year could be destabilizing and possibly tip the economy into a recession. Boskin said to win the administration's support for a partial easing of the Gramm-Rudman targets, Congress must agree to a ``successful, multiyear enforceable deficit reduction'' plan. Figuring in the 1991 costs of rescuing the troubled savings and loan industry would add $62.6 billion to the total federal 1991 deficit, bringing it to a projected $231.4 billion, the administration said. There is considerable sentiment both in Congress and the administration to keep the costs of the savings and loan bailout out of the official budget calculations. The administration blamed the sharp deterioration in the deficit from January until now on the higher-than-expected S&L bailout and weaker economic growth that cuts into government revenues. It also cited higher interest rates that boost the cost of servicing the nation's $3 trillion national debt. The OMB projected a 4.8 percent rise in consumer prices this year, matching last year'sinflation increase, but up from the administration's estimate of a lower inflation figure of 4.4 percent. And it raised the government's projected cost of short-term borrowing short-term by a full percentage point to 7.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Safety Group Asks For Chrysler Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT victim's name, Johnson sted Hanson. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: An auto safety group asked the government Monday to investigate and recall 5.5 million Chrysler cars and vans after 76 reports of vehicles moving into gear while the transmission was in park. The Center for Auto Safety said in a letter to National Highway Traffic Safety Administrator Jerry Curry that two people had been killed and 20 injured in accidents involving the problem with several Chrysler models from 1981 to 1989. The center said the incidents indicate ``a pervasive and dangerous defect.'' NHTSA spokesman Tim Hurd said the agency had just received the letter and would review it before deciding whether to open an investigation. NHTSA conducts engineering analyses of vehicle defects when officials determine that complaints warrant it. James Kenyon, spokesman for Chrysler Corp., said the company was not aware of any problem with the models cited in the petition. He said the company had not seen the complaint, which was sent to members of the news media. The center, which describes itself as an independent consumer group formed in 1970 to improve vehicle and highway safety, said its petition covers 1981-89 Dodge Aries and Plymouth Reliants; 1982-87 Dodge 400s and Chrysler LeBarons; 1983-88 Dodge 600s, Plymouth Caravelles and Chrysler New Yorkers; and 1984-89 Dodge Caravans and Plymouth Voyagers. All of the cars share the same type of engine and transmission, the center said. Deaths cited in the petition include that of Charles C. Davie of Concord, N.H., who the center said died May 5, 1987, after he left his 1985 Plymouth Reliant idling in park on a hill near his home. The vehicle rolled down the hill, pinning Davie against a tree, the center said. The other death noted in the petition occurred when a 1987 Dodge 600 moved backward into a woman the center identified as Agnes Johnson, 92, of Brooklyn Center, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 12 Percent Profit Rise in 2nd-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. said Monday its second quarter earnings jumped 12 percent due to increased sales of aircraft engines, gas turbines and X-ray equipment. GE said in a statement the increase marks the 15th consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings growth. The company is best known to consumers as a manufacturer of major appliances and the owner of the NBC Television Network. For the second quarter, its after-tax profit totaled $1.09 billion, or $1.22 a share, on revenue of $14.4 billion. That compared with earnings of $972 million, or $1.08 a share, on revenue of $13.5 billion in the same 1989 period. GE said it had a 12.9 percent operating margin, the best rate ever achieved by GE in a quarter, GE Chairman John F. Welch Jr. said. The previous all-time high was 12.1 percent in the same quarter last year. GE's aircraft engine business, which had a $35 billion backlog at the end of June, also received a $1.8 billion, 200-engine order in the second quarter from Japan Air Lines. Spokesman Bruce Bunch said the backlog means GE has enough orders to hold production for five years. The company's power generation business, which makes turbines and electrical equipment, also has seen an increase in sales, especially in the gas turbine market. Sales of X-ray equipment in Europe and magnetic resonance imaging equipment in the United States were up 15 percent compared to 1989. Second quarter earnings jumped 16 percent over the same period last year at GE Capital Corp., the financial subsidiary of GE. GE's transportation systems business received its largest export order for locomotives in recent years, with a $168 million contract from Mexico. GE's broadcasting business saw a drop in revenue for the second quarter which the company attributed to ``market softness.'' The company also makes plastic products, lighting, aerospace equipment, industrial systems and motors and provides communications services. For the first half, GE said it earned $2.04 billion, or $2.28 a share, up 12 percent from $1.82 billion, or $2.02 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the half rose 6 percent to $27.0 billion from $25.4 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Quarterly Income Up 5.2 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `IBM stock ...,' to UPDATE with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. said Monday its profit rose 5.2 percent in the second quarter as revenue grew 8.4 percent, results that generally pleased industry analysts. ``Demand across our product line remains good worldwide,'' IBM Chairman John F. Akers said. ``Revenue and earnings growth was led by software, benefits from leasing activities and early results from our restructuring actions.'' The world's largest computer company said it earned $1.41 billion, or $2.45 a share, in the three months ended June 30, up from $1.34 billion, or $2.31 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $16.49 billion from $15.21 billion. ``It was a very good quarter,'' said John Jones, who follows IBM for Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco. ``They saw (revenue) growth in all major geographic areas.'' IBM, which makes and sells its products worldwide, derives more than half its revenue from non-U.S. operations. About $300 million of IBM's second-quarter revenue stemmed from favorable exchange rates in its overseas sales, analysts said. Last year, a rise in the value of the dollar hurt IBM's financial results. For the first half of the year, IBM had net income of $2.45 billion, or $4.26 a share, up 6.8 percent from $2.29 billion, or $3.92 a share, in the first six months of 1989. Revenue grew 9.8 percent to $30.68 billion from $27.94 billion. IBM stock closed at $122.37{ a share, up $1.37{, in New York Stock Exchange trading. In December, IBM announced a major restructuring in the face of unexpectedly sluggish domestic market growth. Among other steps, the Armonk, N.Y.-based company said it would trim its work force by 10,000 jobs and repurchase about $4 billion of its stock. IBM said the job cuts were expected to bring its U.S. work force to 206,000 by the end of this year, down by more than 37,000 since 1985. IBM took a $2.3 billion pre-tax charge against 1989's fourth-quarter earnings to pay for the restructuring. The company has been paring its operations since 1985, when growth in the computer industry began slowing. Jones said IBM is just beginning to see the benefits from the most recent employee reductions. ``Most of the results are going to be felt in the second half of this year,'' he said. ``If they can keep revenue growing at 7 to 8 percent (a year), I don't think they'll need to downsize any more.'' David Korus, a computer industry analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Co., said IBM needs to keep on top of changing market conditions, adjusting its operations to fit the industry. Jones said one potential future trouble spot is the company's planned introduction of new high-end mainframe computers call the Summit line. IBM is expected to announce the line sometime next year. Jones said he expects the company in the meantime to announce new models of its existing mainframes that can be upgraded to Summit models once they are available. ``By doing that it will offset the normal reaction of customers to stop buying before a major product rolls out the door,'' he said. But, he said, ``How that gets implemented will determine whether they can grow through the product transition or take a temporary slowing as their mainframe transition unfolds.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Lawyers Meet With Feds
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines, facing possible criminal charges for allegedly falsifying aircraft maintenance records, sent a team of lawyers Monday to meet with federal prosecutors in Brooklyn. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney said he expected talks to continue for at least several days. He declined to comment on whether a plea bargain was in the works. Eastern spokesman Jim Ashlock in Miami also refused to say what was being discussed. Martin R. Shugrue, Eastern's bankruptcy trustee, met June 1 with Maloney in what one source described as an effort to head off possible criminal charges. The source spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. Shugrue reportedly is worried that any indictments would scare away passengers and possibly torpedo his efforts to save the strikebound airline. According to published reports, the grand jury is looking into allegations that Eastern altered maintenance and safety records early last year at three airports _ Kennedy International and La Guardia in New York and Hartsfield International in Atlanta. Mechanics allegedly were ordered to disregard safety guidelines and then falsified log books to show that proper checks were made. The investigation began last year after the Federal Aviation Administration fined Eastern $839,000 for alleged maintenance violations, primarily at Kennedy. The FAA regularly fines airlines for improper maintenance practices, but does not seek criminal charges. Maloney said the filing of criminal charges against an airline would be unprecedented. Eastern's Machinists union struck the airline March 4, 1989, and the company filed for bankruptcy protection five days later. The strike is continuing. A federal bankruptcy judge appointed Shugrue on April 18 to run the airline in place of Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of Eastern's parent company, the former Texas Air Corp., now known as Continental Airlines Holdings Inc.

DOC.HEAD: GAF Announces $800 Million Refinancing Agreement
DOC.TEXT: GAF Corp. announced Monday that four banks have agreed to provide the company $800 million in long-term financing primarily to pay off debt incurred when a management group bought out shareholders in March 1989. Banks involved in the agreement are Chase Manhattan Bank, the Bank of New York, the Bank of Nova Scotia and the Banque Paribas, of Paris. The refinancing arrangement is expected to be completed next month, the specialty chemicals and building materials company said. A management group led by Samuel J. Heyman, chairman and chief executive officer, paid $1.46 billion in the buyout. The refinancing will enable GAF to redeem $50 million of outstanding senior subordinated increasing rate notes that are due March 15, 1994, the company said in a statement. GAF will also be able to exchange new debentures for the company's subordinated merger debentures, which shareholders received in the buyout. The debentures and interest totalled $239 million as of June 30, the company said. GAF has not decided whether to make an exchange offer.

DOC.HEAD: `Crazy' Eddie Antar Ordered To Turn Over $73 Million; He's Still Missing
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Monday ordered Eddie Antar to turn over $73 million he made through his Crazy Eddie electronics empire. Federal officials say the elusive fugitive, who has been missing since he appeared in court Feb. 13, made the money through fraudulent record keeping and insider trading at the now defunct Crazy Eddie Inc. His assets in the United States have been frozen, but a deposit of about $52 million had been made in an Israeli bank account, said Richard Simpson, an attorney for the Securities and Exchange Commission. Simpson said he could not estimate how much in U.S. assets have been frozen and said the SEC is working through diplomatic channels to freeze funds in Israel. He added that the SEC does not know how much money, if any, may be in the Israeli bank account because the money may have been transferred. Antar has missed several court dates on civil actions brought by the SEC. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan has ordered federal marshals to hunt down the Brooklyn, N.Y.-bred businessman and bring him to court. ``Eddie Antar's whereabouts are presently unknown, but I think there's a 90 percent chance that they will become known at some point,'' Simpson said. ``At that time we're going to make him pay $73 million.'' Antar's attorney, Justin N. Feldman of New York, said he could not comment because he was not in court when the judgment against his client was issued. Antar built a single outlet in New York into a chain with 43 stores in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Television and radio commercials touted ``insane'' prices, and promised to beat the deals of any of his competitors.

DOC.HEAD: Union Negotiators Seek Permission To Strike In August
DOC.TEXT: United Steelworkers of America negotiators said Monday they are seeking authorization for 5,500 employees to strike Wheeling Pittsburgh Steel Corp. on Aug. 16. The negotiators unanimously approved a resolution to seek permission from union President Lynn R. Williams for a strike over terms of the company's bankruptcy reorganization plan, said Andrew ``Lefty'' Palm, director of USW District 15 and the union's chief Wheeling-Pittsburgh negotiator. ``We have a pretty good idea that we will get authorization,'' Palm said at a news conference held in this Washington County community. The request was to be presented by Tuesday to Williams, whose approval is needed under union rules. An answer is expected within a few days, Palm said. The workers' current contract was negotiated following a 98-day work stoppage that began in 1985 after Wheeling-Pittsburgh filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws. It will expire 10 days after a plan of reorganization is approved. The union's membership, unhappy with terms of the reorganization plan, recently completed polling that gave negotiators the authority to strike. The union claims the plan, supported in bankruptcy court by the company and creditors, treats employee bankruptcy claims unfairly. Palm said the plan offers union members 13 percent of the value of their stock, which is worth about $26 million. At the same time, the average creditor would get 74 percent of the value of its stock, he said. Palm said the workers made concessions in 1985 and lawyers for the company and creditors are asking them to give up more than their fair share under the reorganization plan. ``They've watched the bankruptcy lawyers for creditors and the company raise fees by as much as $100 an hour,'' said Jim Smith, an assistant to Williams. ``The cost of living is increasing for our members too.'' Galvie Gardner, president of Local 1187 in Allenport, Washington County, said all the workers want is what other steel workers have. ``We give and give and give,'' he said. ``If we don't get it we're on the street.'' He was among 13 local presidents who stood behind Palm at the news conference. Little progress was made when union negotiators last met with the company June 12, Palm said. Wheeling-Pittsburgh spokesman Ray Johnson said company negotiators are eager to resume talks. ``We'll do whatever we can to avoid a strike,'' Johnson said. ``That's why we're ready to meet at any time.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Hints at Veto Recommendation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf: ``The reality is,'' to CORRECT figure in quote from $1 billion to $6 billion. Also moving on general news wires. ^By DIANE DUSTON
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told the Senate Monday he would recommend that President Bush veto the 1990 farm bill if its cost to the government is not reduced. The threat brought an immediate charge from Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., that the Bush administration was trying to kill the farm bill to have a freer hand in international trade talks aimed at cutting agriculture subsidies around the world. ``From a budget standpoint, the cost of the bill is excessive,'' Yeutter said in a letter that is deeply critical of the commodities subsidies in the legislation expected to be taken up by the full Senate this week. The committee has estimated that the commodity programs in the bill would cost $55 billion over five years, but Yeutter said its spending requirements amount to $59 billion. About $79 billion was spent over the last five years under the 1985 law expiring this year. The government subsidizes farmers who produce wheat, corn, rice, cotton, soybeans, sugar, dairy products, wool and mohair, honey and peanuts either by direct payment or manipulation of the market. ``The bill authorizes appropriations for a number of new programs and authorities which could result in over $3 billion of additional outlays,'' said Yeutter. His letter criticized every government subsidy program in the Senate bill. Leahy said in a statement the administration had ``cooked up new numbers'' in estimating the bill's impact on the budget. ``The reality is that the Senate farm bill is over $6 billion less than what the president proposed in January for current services,'' he said. ``The administration's veto threat is a thinly veiled effort to kill the farm bill so the administration can cut a back-room deal in Geneva, out of sight from American farmers.'' Yeutter never mentioned the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks being conducted in Geneva, Switzerland, in his letter, but criticized the bill as departing from the ``market-oriented'' approach of the 1985 law. The Bush administration's appeal to the countries covered by GATT is that they allow the market to operate free of price-distorting subsidies. ``America's farmers will see this for what it is, a strong-arm effort to sabotage the farm bill suppported by a majority of both Democrats and Republicans on the Senate Agricultture Committee,'' said Leahy. But Yeutter said, ``The instability of the commodity markets dictates that we must consider the variability as well as the absolute dollar estimate of spending for these programs.''

DOC.HEAD: Bribery Case Dismissed Against Drugstore Company, President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, During the ... over drugstores, to CORRECT date of trial start to July 2; PICK UP 13th graf, Defense attorneys ...
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Monday tossed out all charges against Rite Aid Corp. and its president after ruling the evidence against them in a bribery case was circumstantial. Martin L. Grass, 36, and Rite Aid were accused of bribing a member of Ohio's Board of Pharmacy to resign so the panel would have a makeup more favorable to the drugstore company. Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Judge Lillian Greene granted a defense motion asking for a judgment of acquittal after the prosecution rested its case. Greene said prosecution evidence was circumstantial and did not substantiate a case of willful intent to bribe. Some of the spectators in the courtroom gallery applauded and several hugged the smiling Grass and congratulated him. Grass said he was sure he would be found innocent. ``I never had a doubt. It was a ridiculous prosecution,'' he said. Grass and Rite Aid, based in Shiremanstown, Pa., were charged in an indictment unsealed in August with bribery and possession of criminal tools, described as a corporate aircraft. Both charges are felonies. The bribery charge is punishable by up to 10 years in prison and a maximum fine of $5,000. The possession of criminal tools charge carries a maximum sentence of five years and a fine up to $2,500. Grass was accused of trying to bribe pharmacy board member Melvin Wilczynski, 61, to step down so a new board member more to Rite Aid's liking could be appointed. Grass gave Wilczynski a check worth more than $33,000. The defense had argued the payment was in fact a legal buyout of Wilczynski's consulting contract for another drug store company, Lane Drug Co., a division of Peoples Drug Stores Inc. acquired by Rite Aid last year. During the trial, which began July 9, prosecutors contended that Grass offered the buyout only on condition that Wilczynski step down as a voting member of the board. The government said Rite Aid had complained the pharmacy board harassed the company when enforcing state regulations over drugstores. Defense attorneys have said the state pharmacy board had a vendetta against Rite Aid because it challenged some rules and decisions which it thought were unreasonable. The prosecutors had the jury hear and watch two secretly-made tapes _ a recorded telephone conversation between Wilczynski and Grass on April 26, 1989, and a videotape the following day in a hotel room near Cleveland Hopkins International Airport. Grass was arrested at the hotel room. In the telephone tape, Wilczynski is heard arranging the following-day meeting with Grass at the hotel to discuss the contract buyout and Rite Aid's provision of health insurance after the buyout. In the videotape, Wilczynski and Grass are seen in the motel room, leafing through papers, some of which Wilczynski signs. Prosecutors said the papers included six undated letters of resignation, addressed to Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, from which Wilczynski was supposed to select for signing. Wilczynski remains a voting member of the pharmacy board, which oversees drugstores' adherence to state rules. Celeste has said he knew of no plans to get any Rite Aid officials or supporters appointed to the pharmacy board. Before the trial began, Greene dismissed as evidence three other taped conversations which the prosecution wanted to use. The judge said they were made by pharmacy board investigators, who did not have jurisdiction in the criminal case. The two tapes that were allowed were made by Cuyahoga County sheriff's officers.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Say They Lack Votes to Win in House
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 4-5: ``Bush sent,'' with president's letter. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soaring Deficit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution said Monday they were short of the votes needed to win House passage. ``We're not doing as well as I'd hoped right now,'' said Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas. However, Stenholm said he and other supporters were lobbying hard and expected to come closer than ever Tuesday to the required two-thirds majority. President Bush sent a letter to Capitol Hill urging support of the amendment and calling for a line-item veto and greater authority for the president to impound funds. ``Together with political courage and discipline, these tools are vital to solving the problem of budget deficits,'' Bush said. He called the balanced budget amendment ``crucial to our nation's long-term economic health and properity.'' Stenholm, prime Democratic sponsor of the amendment, said he was about 18 votes short of victory but that there were enough undecided votes to put it over the top. The amendment, if approved by a two-thirds vote of the Congress and three-fourths of the states, would ban the government from spending more than it takes in unless three-fifths of the Congress voted to waive the requirement. The balanced budget rules would not take effect before fiscal 1993, and would be set aside in time of war. Rep. Joe Barton, R-Texas, said he would try to change the amendment to require a super-majority vote also to raise taxes above the rate of growth in national income. The House last voted on a balanced budget amendment in 1982; it fell short by more than 40 votes. The House Democratic leadership opposes the amendment. ``Members as always are trying to reach for simple answers to what are very tough problems,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee. ``I've never seen a process change in the world that is going to produce the courage and guts you need to make tough choices. ``Some of my colleagues will find it a refuge,'' he said. ``I think we have a very good chance of beating the amendment.''

DOC.HEAD: CBOT Chief's Firm Ordered To Adjust Finances
DOC.TEXT: The commodities trading firm headed by Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann said Monday it is seeking an outside investor and parceling out some accounts to get its books in order. The firm, Stotler and Co., has been directed by the Board of Trade to bring its amount of cash-on-hand up to 4 percent of customer funds, as required by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, by the close of business Wednesday, according to a statement issued by the firm's parent company, Stotler Group Inc. If a brokerage does not maintain the required amount of capital, the exchange can restrict the brokerage to trading only for the purpose of liquidation and can transfer that brokerage's customer accounts to other firms, said Michael O'Connell, a Board of Trade spokesman. He referred questions about the specifics of the case to Chicago-based Stotler Group, where spokesman Vito Piazza declined to comment beyond the prepared statement. The statement said Stotler planned to meet the requirement by transferring a portion of its customer accounts and stake in the market to other brokerages and by seeking ``a capital infusion from various parties.'' The moves are likely to reduce the firm's revenue and net income, Stotler said. ``Without a capital infusion, Stotler Group may be unable to meet its debt obligations unless those obligations are refinanced or restructured,'' the company said. The Chicago Tribune reported Saturday that Stotler, one of the nation's 10 biggest futures brokerages, may have run afoul of capital requirements because of its recent rapid growth. Stotler Group said another subsidiary brokerage, R.G. Dickinson & Co. of Des Moines, Iowa, was not affected by the compliance problems at Stotler and Co. Mahlman is serving his fourth consecutive one-year term as chairman of the BOT. Stotler is one of the nation's 10 largest futures brokers.

DOC.HEAD: Examiner Finds Legal Action Could Result From Revco LBO
DOC.TEXT: An outside examiner appointed by a federal bankruptcy judge to look into the 1986 junk-bond financed buyout of Revco D.S. Inc. said Monday he believes successful lawsuits could arise from the deal. However, the examiner, Barry L. Zaretsky, said lawsuits should not be filed to avoid interfering with bankruptcy court proceedings. ``Our preliminary finding that the Revco (leveraged buyout) amounted to a fraudulent conveyance is likely to lead to greater scrutiny of the financial condition of junk bond-financed deals,'' said Zaretsky, who was appointed examiner by U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Harold F. White last month. Zaretsky said his examination has not found actual fraud, but that the deal was made with either fraudulent intent or without fair consideration of whether the company could pay its debts. The examiner also said state law tort claims and other actions could arise from the buyout. Zaretsky is a Brooklyn Law School professor and counsel to the New York-based law firm of Kelly Drye & Warren. Revco went from a publicly held company to a private one during a $1.5 billion, management-led leveraged buyout. The Revco buyout failed in 1988. Revco's was the first major debt-financed buyout to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws. This year the suburban Cleveland-based drugstore chain, one of the country's largest, decided to sell more than 700 of its 2,000 stores in order to concentrate on eastern operations, where sales are strongest. The appointment of an examiner was requested by U.S. Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern, who supervised the Revco bankruptcy case.
